DOC.HEAD: Greenhouse Effect Could Sink Idyllic Islands
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report. ^By ARTHUR MAX
DOC.TEXT: Welcome to paradise - for as long as it stays above water. The people of this chain of palm-studded islands fear global warming could condemn their nation to geological history. If the earth gets hotter, as some scientists predict, the Maldives could be swamped by rising seas and violent storms. The Indian Ocean archipelago almost certainly would be among the first casualties of the greenhouse effect. ``We may have some islands just disappear. That is according to the business-as-usual scenario. I would hope that the international community would take note and do something before that happens,'' said Hussain Shihab, the Maldives' director of environment affairs. According to some estimates, unchecked emissions of carbon dioxide and other heat-trapping greenhouse gases will raise the sea level by a foot in the next 40 years - submerging much of the Maldives' 175 square miles of land. The Maldives, about 400 miles south of India and the same distance west of Sri Lanka, are little more than clumps of coconut palms fringed by white sand in a nest of coral reefs. The 1,190 islands are clustered in atolls in an archipelago 510 miles long. Just 200 islands are inhabited and a quarter of the nation's 200,000 people live on Male island, which covers barely one square mile. Few of the islands are more than 6 feet above sea level, so a big splash can be devastating, as demonstrated in April 1987 when a tidal wave rolled over the island nation. ``We had a storm that was more severe than anyone could ever remember,'' Shihab said. ``This really woke us up.'' Two-thirds of Male, the Maldivian capital, was flooded by sea water. The international airport on neighboring Hulule was closed for two days, and entire fishing villages were under water. Shihab said damage totaled $40 million - half this nation's annual gross domestic product. Some experts said the freak storm originated 4,000 miles away in the south Indian Ocean, underlining the Maldives' vulnerability to far-away calamities. The disaster forced Maldivians to take a more appreciative look at their coral reefs, the feeding grounds for a stunning array of tropical fish. The reefs provide a natural barrier from an often hostile sea. The mining of coral, the basic building material for most houses here, was forbidden on reefs connected to islands. The ban eventually will be extended to unattached atolls, although importing cement will be costly, Shihab said. Traditionally dependent on fishing and tuna exports, the islands' energy needs are small. There is no heavy industry and Male has only a few dozen cars. Experiments with solar power promise to further decrease dependency on polluting fossile fuels. As a result, the Maldivians have felt few constraints about pressing for worldwide controls on emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases that threaten the islands. These gases build a shield in the atmosphere which traps heat, and many experts predict higher temperatures will change weather patterns and raise sea levels, endangering coastal areas and low-lying countries. Some experts disagree, arguing that such long-term effects are unclear. ``It is the small island states who contribute the least (in heat-trapping pollutants) which will suffer the most,'' Shihab said. The tropical beauty of the islands is the Maldives' only natural asset and major source of income other than the sea. When the first tourist resort opened in 1972, the Maldives were virtually unknown except as a staging post for the British air force dating from World War II. The British left in 1976. This year the number of tourists is expected to equal the resident population. Resorts have gone up on 59 previously uninhabited islands, catering to scuba divers and sun worshipers. The influx of tourists has aroused fears of cultural pollution in this strict Sunni Moslem society which has its own unique language and script. Travelers are discouraged from visiting all but a few fishing villages outside the resort islands. Passengers arriving on international flights are cautioned not to bring alcohol, pigs, dogs, statues for worship, pornography, explosives, guns or drugs - in that order. Shihab said the loss of cultural identity would be the real tragedy if the Maldives were overwhelmed by the environment. ``We don't want to be refugees of the greenhouse effect,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Threat of War Strips Iraq of Its Youth
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report. ^By TERRY LEONARD
DOC.TEXT: Young, able-bodied men seem in short supply in the teeming markets and streets of Baghdad. The threat of war has stripped Iraq of its youth and sent many of them to the front. The government announced this week it would call up an additional 150,000 men for duty in Kuwait. But some Western diplomats question the numbers and expressed doubts about Iraq's ability to wage a war, claiming troop morale is low, strategic fuel supplies inadequate and vital spare parts are in dwindling supply. Highways in Kuwait are littered with broken-down tanks and disabled military vehicles, Western diplomats claimed. The country has 18 million people, a regular army of 550,000 and 480,000 reservists, as well as a Popular Army militia of about 850,000, according to diplomats in Baghdad who spoke on condition of anonymity. Iraq claims more than 8 million volunteers in the Popular Army. Its air force, with more than 500 combat jets, is fairly sophisticated and its army well-equipped. A weakness, the diplomats say, is the soldiers, whose morale is eroding because of months maintaining the alert in the desert and food shortages brought about by distribution problems. Men going absent while on leave is another ``big problem,'' one European diplomat said, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``One estimate is 40 percent of those who go on leave don't go back to Kuwait. The president had to decree that it's the same as desertion,'' the diplomat said. Also, the diplomats noted that small numbers of Iraqi soldiers have deserted along the Turkish border. Besides the expected reinforcements, Iraq has an estimated 430,000 troops in southern Iraq and Kuwait, which Iraq invaded Aug. 2. There are about 330,000 soldiers in Persian Gulf from the multinational force, including about 230,000 U.S. troops. The United States plans to increase its troop strength to about 430,000 by January. About 1 million Iraqis and Iranian troops died during their eight-year war, according to U.N. estimates. Iraq expelled all Western military attaches last month, making it more difficult to accurately assess Iraq's readiness for war. ``We're getting a lot of technical intelligence, but we can no longer get the assessments of individual units, commanders and their fighting ability,'' said one Western diplomat with long military experience. Others say many of the troops in Kuwait belong to the Popular Army, a ragtag outfit of ill-trained irregulars. Iraqi troops in the south also include the crack, battle-hardened Republican Guards, whose ability and willingness to fight remains unchallenged to Western observers. But Iraq is also a victim of its military system, said the diplomat with military experience. He said the army is dug in along a Maginot-type line on the border which is vulnerable to massive air strikes from multinational forces. The Maginot line was a French fortification that failed to repel Germany's invasion in World War II. ``They don't realize what they're facing,'' the diplomat said. ``This time, the Americans have the proper weapon for the proper target.'' Western diplomats increasingly feel that a limited war, coupled with economic sanctions, might be enough to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. Iraq, meanwhile, is hoping it can endure the economic embargo and break the international coalition against it, the diplomats said. ``The Iraqi leadership believes that unless they give him a reason to go to war, President Bush, like all presidents, will look for a way to avoid doing it,'' the European diplomat said. Iraqi officials say they want peace but insist they're prepared for war. ``We expect war at any moment. This is a fact, not just propaganda,'' said Information Minister Latif Nassayif Jassim. ``One hopes a war will never erupt.'' Diplomats contend the timing of Iraq's planned Dec. 25 to March 25 release of Western hostages reflects Baghdad's fear of fighting the United States. The winter is considered the best time for military operations in the gulf because of lower temperatures and frequent spells of good weather. Also, diplomats say the West may face political pressure to avoid war during the Moslem fasting month of Ramadan beginning in March.

DOC.HEAD: Milken Still Wealthy Despite Stiff Sentence
With PM-Milken, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Michael Milken, sentenced to 10 years in prison for securities and tax violations, is no longer a billionaire. But he remains one of the country's richest people. His net worth was estimated in October by Forbes magazine at $700 million, good enough for 115th place on the register of America's 400 wealthiest people. That's after paying $600 million in fines and restitution as part of his guilty plea to six felonies in April. Forbes also estimated that he lost $250 million from the collapse of the junk-bond market and his employer, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., which filed for bankruptcy earlier this year. At Drexel, Milken made more than $1.1 billion from 1983-87, including $550 million in 1987 alone. But he faces more than 50 civil lawsuits seeking billions of dollars in damages as a result of his wrongdoing and Drexel's collapse. And he was sentenced to prison Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Desert Duty Puts Strain on Civilian Soldiers
DOC.TEXT: Life was good for Johnny Spell until Saddam Hussein absorbed Kuwait. Spell was busy running an appliance store founded by his late father in rural North Carolina, and he was settling down with his bride of three months. Then he was called to active duty with his National Guard unit. Now, his original 90-day tour has been extended for another 90 days, so he won't be home for the holidays. ``When this is over, I hope I've got a business to go back to. I hope my business don't go bankrupt because I'm gone,'' said Spell, 46, of Autryville, N.C., and a staff sergeant with the 382nd Public Affairs Unit. ``I've got that to worry about plus breaking away from a new family. We were just getting started, and all of a sudden this thing comes along. That has been the hardest thing for me to cope with,'' Spell said in an interview. More than 51,000 citizen soldiers have been called to active duty under Operation Desert Shield. With an extension, they can serve for 180 days or even longer if Congress authorizes it. By law, employers must keep a job open for reservists doing their duty. But small businessmen such as Spell can only hope their trade will survive in their absence. ``It's harder on the citizen soldier. We had to leave a job and we had to leave our families,'' Spell said. ``Being self-employed, it's just a tough situation to deal with. In my absence, I feel like I am going to lose some business.'' Spell, an 18-year veteran of the National Guard, says not to misinterpret the strain of being away as an unwillingness to serve. He won't shirk his duty, no matter how much it hurts financially and personally. ``When you sign the dotted line, you know if a time comes like this you have to go and do your duty. I'm not bitter about being here. I just miss home and I miss my business like every person does, and I need to be back,'' Spell said. ``This may sound corny, but I wanted to do my patriotic American duty. I wanted to serve. We've got a job to do,'' he said. ``But everyone over here regrets they're not at home. I don't guess that can be helped.'' His father founded Spell's Furniture and Appliance Store in 1949, selling and repairing household furnishings, TVs and other electronic products in a town of 500 people. Spell's has eight full-time employees at two locations. Spell will be away for the Christmas rush, his busiest time of the year, and that's worrisome. ``I do the buying, the selling, the service, even some of the delivery. Someone else has to do it now,'' Spell said. ``The only way we've existed through the years is through repeat business.'' Spell's wife and cousin are filling in as managers for the business while he's in Saudi Arabia, attached to the Army's 18th Airborne Corps. It would be impossible for him to try to run the shop from 7,000 miles away while he's wearing his desert camouflage fatigues and doing Uncle Sam's work. ``I need to give the Army 100 percent,'' he said. Spell was activated Aug. 31 and has been in Saudi Arabia since Sept. 13. He had barely enough time to straighten out some business details, change some things in his will and give his wife power of attorney. He'll miss Thanksgiving and Christmas with his family and his 75-year-old mother, and he'll be away for his wife's Dec. 7 birthday. And there just wasn't enough time to take care of some personal business, like selling his wife's former home while the couple settled in. ``Some things will just have to be put on hold,'' Spell said. ``There's only so much one person can do.''

DOC.HEAD: Congress Suspends Eight Supreme Court Justices in Beer Tax Dispute
DOC.TEXT: The lower house of Congress has temporarily suspended eight of twelve Supreme Court Justices in a dispute over a beer tax, aggravating political divisions in the country. In response, the justices threatened to annul the 1989 elections that put the current government in power. They asked the armed forces to intervene. The armed forces, which have staged more than 100 coups in Bolivia's 165-year history, declined. A statement said the conflict must be resolved according to the constitution. The government had said two weeks ago that it would try eight out of the twelve justices for incompetence after they ruled that a beer tax authorized by Congress was illegal. Charging the justices were influenced by beer companies, the government said the repeal of the tax threatened an economic stabilization plan by depriving the treasury of $50 million. The lower house temporarily suspended the justices on Tuesday, and the Senate was to consider a measure permanently removing them. The court responded by saying it would consider a petition presented in August 1989 by the Revolutionary Nationalist Movement calling for the annulment of the elections. The court is controlled by justices appointed under the previous Revolutionary Nationalist Movement government. Congressmen Tito Hoz de Vila, head of the Congressional Economic Committee, said the conflict ``threatens the country's political and economic stability.'' ``It is necessary for Bolivians to act with serenity,'' said Gen. Hugo Banzer Suarez, a member of the governing coalition. ``We must strengthen democracy, which is in danger.'' The Revolutionary Nationalist Movement placed first in the 1989 popular vote but lacked the required absolute majority. As a result, the president was elected by Congress. President Jaime Paz Zamora, of the Revolutionary Leftist Movement, finished third in the elections but was elected by Congress through an alliance with the conservative Nationalist Democratic Action party, headed by former dictator Banzer Suarez, whose party had finished second. The opposition accused the governing coalition of ``attempting to destroy the judicial power by subjugating it to act as a legal office and not as a separate branch of government.''

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Keating-Senators
DOC.TEXT:
Here are excerpts from Tuesday's testimony before the Senate Ethics Committee on the dealings five senators had with Charles H. Keating Jr., owner of the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan. Gwendolyn van Paasschen, economics assistant to Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., continued her testimony from Monday. She was questioned at one point by James Hamilton, the lawyer representing Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz.
Hamilton: I would like to go back to the question I asked you before about whether Sen. McCain was coaxed into the meeting (with four senators and Edwin Gray, then chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board). ... Now, who was coaxing Sen. McCain into this meeting? Van Paasschen: ... It was my view that what Sen. DeConcini had suggested was inappropriate. And I further went on to say that I believed that the reason that Sen. McCain was being involved in this ... was because Sen. McCain was a Republican and that would ensure that it was a bipartisan effort, and that Keating had raised more for Sen. McCain than he had for Sen. DeConcini at that time. So, if the press were to ever get a hold of it, it would be more embarrassing for Sen. McCain than for Sen. DeConcini. ... Hamilton: What fact led you to believe that Sen. DeConcini was coaxing Sen. McCain to this meeting because he was a Republican? ... Van Paasschen: His demeanor was very persuasive. He was coming to Sen. McCain instead of Mr. Keating himself. He was a Democrat, we were Republican. And as I said before, Keating had raised more for Sen. McCain than he had for Sen. DeConcini at that time. ...

In the afternoon session, Any Sabrin, special assistant to special counsel Robert Bennett, questioned Sen. McCain's administrative aide Christopher Koch.
Sabrin: Did you attend the meeting between Mr. Keating and Sen. McCain on the 24th? (March 24, 1987) Koch: I did. Sabrin: Can you tell us, with as much detail as you can recall, what happened? Koch: It would be a very difficult meeting to forget. ... I remember vividly him (McCain) telling Mr. Keating that he hadn't spent 5{ years of his life in a prisoner of war camp to have his courage or his integrity questioned - and he gave Mr. Keating a dressing down, the likes of which I, in my experience on the Hill, had never experienced a senator giving a major employer of his state. It was startling to me. I mean it was a very vivid impression. Sabrin: Can you recall with any detail what the substance was of what Mr. Keating was asking Sen. McCain to do and what his response was? Koch: Yes. John said that there's certain things he can do and there's certain things he couldn't do. He said he could find out if Mr. Keating's allegations ... had merit. He could look in and ask questions about if this investigation was taking so long, why it was taking so long. ... But he said, ``I can't go in and do your bidding for you. ... I can't go in and break arms and legs for you. I can find out if you're being treated fairly.'' ... Mr. Keating thought he was being treated very, very unfairly. ... it was almost as if he hadn't been listening to John because he again got into requests for him to get involved ... and again the meeting got a little bit hot. And John came back at him again and said he couldn't do that ... Sabrin: What was your understanding after ... Mr. Keating walked out of Sen. McCain's office of how the whole matter was left? Koch: I thought that the relationship had clearly in my opinion, come to a screeching halt. I had never heard two people ... have that kind of conversation and ever want to talk to each other again. ...

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Axl Rose, lead singer of the hard rock band Guns 'N Roses, won a temporary restraining order against the neighbor he is accused of hitting over the head with a wine bottle. Gabriella Kantor, who lives in the same condominium complex as the rock star, was ordered Tuesday to stay away from Rose, his wife, Erin, and their guests. A judge will decide Dec. 4 whether to make the order permanent. Rose was arrested Oct. 30 for investigation of assault after an altercation with Kantor. No charges have been filed, although Rose has been accused of hitting her with a bottle. Rose's lawyers described Kantor as ``a potentially dangerous rock 'n' roll groupie ... upset that she is not a part of (Rose's) social and or professional life.'' --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Madonna and a neighbor are suing each other over trees and shrubs in her back yard that block a city view, and the singer will get a chance to tell her side of the story in court. Madonna, singer of such hits as ``Like a Virgin'' and ``Material Girl,'' inherited the dispute from a previous owner when she moved into the Hollywood Hills home. Neighbor Donald Robinson sued the previous owner for allegedly failing to trim the foliage, then sued Madonna. Madonna's countersuit claims Robinson trespassed on her property in 1989, ``making threatening, abusive and derogatory statements'' and ``cutting various trees and plants.'' Trial has been scheduled for Nov. 30. Superior Court Judge Sally Disco ordered Madonna to be there. ---
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Version also moved on sports lines.
DOC.TEXT: Muhammad Ali flew to Iraq to share a Thangsgiving meal with U.S. hostages in Baghdad, an anti-war group said. The three-time heavyweight champion, who adopted the Moslem faith in the 1960s, was to arrive in the Iraqi capital today, said Gavrielle Gemma, spokeswoman for the Coalition to Stop U.S. Intervention in the Middle East. The Louisville, Ky., native will meet with unspecified Iraqi leaders before sharing a Thanksgiving meal with several Americans refused permission to leave Iraq, she said. Ali was not representing the coalition, but the group helped him with travel arrangements, Gemma said. --- BRISBANE, Australia (AP) - Prince Philip traded pomp and circumstance for a true taste of the Australian outback by camping out in the wild, sampling native food and even showering outdoors. The Duke of Edinburgh, in Australia for a 10-day visit, slept in a tent Tuesday night about 520 miles northwest of Brisbane on property recently bought by the Queensland state government. His overnight visit with Queensland's Environment Minister Pat Comben follows government initiatives to protect two wilderness areas, known as mulga lands. ---
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Version also moved on sports lines.
DOC.TEXT: A.J. Foyt, the all-time winningest Indy-car driver, says next year's Indianapolis 500 will be his last and that he'll ``finish the 1991 season and then call it quits.'' Foyt, 55, was badly injured in a race crash on Sept. 23 at Elkhart Lake, Wis., breaking and dislocating bones in his legs and feet. He has been recuperating in his home in Houston. Foyt had earlier hinted at retirement. ``Yes, this will be the last time,'' he said of next year's 500 in an interview with KHTV in Houston on Tuesday night. Foyt, who has won four Indy 500s, suffered several serious injuries in crashes, including two spinal fractures, broken ribs and broken feet. --- NEW YORK (AP) - NBC newswoman Faith Daniels, who appears on the early morning show ``Today,'' will have a longer work day after New Year's with her own show, network sources say. The program will occupy the daytime slot now filled by the low-rated soap opera ``Generations,'' sources who spoke on condition of anonymity said Tuesday. Daniels will continue on ``Today,'' sources said. NBC refused to confirm the report of Daniels' new job or the cancellation of ``Generations.'' --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Ed Begley Jr., who played a doctor on television's ``St. Elsewhere,'' is being called on to try to cure some of the traffic ills plaguing smoggy Southern California. Begley was named chairman Tuesday of an advisory committee to the Southern California Rapid Transit District, which runs buses and is building a subway system in the nation's most populous county. Begley, who now plays a dad on the new NBC series ``Parenthood,'' will convene the Citizens Advisory Committee once every three months beginning in December to make recommendations to the transit agency.

DOC.HEAD: Michelle and Rodney: Thanksgiving Anniversary Driving Trucks
DOC.TEXT: When Michelle and Rodney Lawrence got married, they really didn't anticipate spending their first anniversary on Thanksgiving Day driving trucks in different parts of Saudi Arabia, thousands of miles from their 3-month-old son. For Pvt. 1 Michelle Lawrence, the best Thanksgiving present would be to see her 25-year-old husband, a 3{-hour drive away in the northern desert, and to get home as quickly as possible to her infant son and two older children. Though some military couples have thrived here, others like the Lawrences have been torn between military duty and family commitments back home. The huge U.S. deployment in the Persian Gulf shattered Mrs. Lawrence's family, heightened her anxiety, and turned her against the Army, which ordered her to leave Rodney Jr. when he was only five weeks old. ``They said, you signed a contract, you have to go,'' she said. ``I don't think it's fair that they split families up like this because not everybody needs to be here. ... (It's) extremely heartless.'' If she had the opportunity, the 21-year-old from Battle Creek, Mich., said she would choose a peaceful, stateside job and quit the Army. ``When I joined the Army, I never believed I'd be in a place like this. Back home is such a beautiful place. When things come up like this, it brings reality to the job that you're actually doing,'' she said. Mrs. Lawrence candidly admits she joined the Army so she could go to college, become a lawyer, and get comprehensive health coverage for her children. She signed up for 6 years and has been in for 2{ years, driving trucks. On Nov. 22, 1989, she married fellow truck driver, Spec. Rodney Lawrence, and started a new life, excited at the prospect of completing more pre-law courses. ``We used to be in the same unit,'' she said. ``When we got married, according to military laws, they split us up.'' Their first child was born just after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Shortly afterward, Lawrence's 96th Transportation Company was ordered to Saudi Arabia. Then, 2{ weeks later, her 180th Transportation Battalion from Ft. Hood, Tex., was deployed here. ``I knew I had to go so I volunteered to come with our advance party so I could hurry up, get over here, get it over with, and get back home,'' she said. But with no rotations because of the additional U.S. troops being deployed here, she said, those who arrived first will end up staying longer. Before Lawrence left, he adopted her two oldest children, Tony, 3, and Brandon, 2. His mother is now looking after them and the baby, Rodney Jr. ``I've talked to them one time on the phone since I've been here. the oldest one isn't doing too bad. The middle one is really taking it hard. He's always talking about `Momma, I want you to come home. Momma, I miss you. Momma, come get me.' ``It's hard to talk to him. I try and talk to Tony as long as I can to make up for the tears that I shed with Brandon.'' Since her arrival about seven weeks ago, Mrs. Lawrence has been driving five-ton trucks. Some of her female colleagues have been run off the road or stoned by Saudi men unaccustomed to seeing women drivers, but she said so far she's been lucky. Her husband has been driving tank carriers. ``I've seen him three or four times and I get a letter about every two or three days,'' she said. ``We've tried to spend as much time alone as we possibly could, just talking and crying, and talking about our three children we have back home.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Creates `Invisible Judges' to Hear Drug Cases
DOC.TEXT: In a major step to reform Colombia's battered judicial system, the government has created a special corps of ``invisible judges'' to hear drug- and terrorism-related cases. Up to 500 judges will try cases without having their identities revealed, Justice Minister Jaime Giraldo told a news conference Tuesday. They will live in heavily protected fortresses in Colombia's four biggest cities. The reform measures Giraldo announced also provide anonymity for witnesses and have police, rather than judges, collect evidence in sensitive cases. They are part of President Cesar Gaviria's program to protect judges from intimidation by drug traffickers. Seventy-seven judges have been murdered by the cocaine bosses in the past 12 years. The magistrates often are given a choice between ``plata o plomo'' - a bribe or a bullet. So far, the country has been unable to keep any major drug trafficker in jail. Most of the top traffickers brought to justice were first taken to the United States, and tried and jailed there under a special extradition treaty. But the extraditions have created political problems because many consider them insults to national pride. Gaviria has said that fortifying the judicial system will allow the government to prosecute drug criminals in Colombia. In the present system, judges must act as investigators and prosecutors in addition to deciding guilt or innocence. They visit crime sites and collect witness testimony, thus becoming even bigger targets of the drug mafia. Under the new plan, such evidence will be collected by police. The Medellin cocaine cartel has been blamed by authorities for killing 550 Colombians since the government and the traffickers declared war on each other after a political assassination in August 1989. Among the dead were three presidential candidates. Most of the crimes have gone unpunished. Judicial reform will be among the topics discussed at an upcoming national assembly to reform Colombia's 104-year-old constitution.

DOC.HEAD: Arizona County Supervisors Vote to Give Employees King Day Off
SUBS 9th graf pvs, `The national...,' to CORRECT that national King holiday is third Monday in January sted second Monday.
DOC.TEXT: Reacting to a statewide vote against a holiday honoring the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., one Arizona county decided Tuesday to give its workers a paid holiday commemorating the slain civil rights leader. Pima County employees will be given time off on either of two days, but the county's offices will remain open on both days with at least skeleton crews, the Board of Supervisors decided by a unanimous vote. The county includes the city of Tucson and its environs. Voters in the state's general election on Nov. 6 rejected two propositions that would have created a paid holiday to honor King. One proposition called for creating a King Day while retaining Columbus Day and the other would have created a King Day while eliminating Columbus Day. The rejection led to a backlash of national criticism, with many organizers of conventions and sporting events threatening to boycott the state. A majority of the voters in Pima County supported creating an 11th state holiday in honor of King. The board had been advised by its lawyer that it could not simply declare a holiday because the county must abide by state status on when offices must be open. However, the board's action changes the county's personnel policy and does not conflict with state law, said Supervisor Raul Grijalva. The resolution the board passed calls for giving county employees eight hours' paid administrative leave to be taken on either the third Monday of January or on the Friday preceding that Monday, Grijalva said. The national holiday honoring King falls on the third Monday of January. Grijalva also said he will send the board's resolution to the Maricopa County Board of Supervisors in Phoenix in the hope that they will follow Pima County's example. ``I think that if the two largest counties in the state set the tone ... that will push the Legislature to either do something themselves, or put it back on the ballot for voters to decide,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Bush May Have Pushed Too Hard on Gulf Resolution
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: President Bush counseled ``just be patient'' when pressed on why the Soviet Union hadn't joined his call for a resolution authorizing military force against Kuwait. But in the end, Bush may have been the impatient one. By seeking support for a resolution dealing with war at a conference dedicated to peace, Bush may have given the impression of pushing too hard. That threatened to alienate some of those who stood with the United States in earlier United Nations actions against international outlaw Iraq. The president's hand on the Persian Gulf also may have been weakened by the political defeat delivered to British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on Tuesday by her own Conservative Party. Mrs. Thatcher, who was forced into a second party leadership vote next week, has been Bush's staunchest ally in insisting that the military option be left open in the gulf. Bush was heading to the Middle East - where he will meet with Saudi and exiled Kuwaiti officials today, U.S. forces on Thanksgiving and Egyptian officials on Friday - without the consensus he had hoped to forge in Paris. But not for lack of trying. Like lobbyists on Capitol Hill in search of votes, Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker III worked the halls and the elegant salons in which the 34-nation Conference on Cooperation and Security in Europe had gathered to celebrate the end of East-West hostilities. But the U.S. efforts failed to wring agreement from summit leaders on what to do next to dislodge Iraq's Saddam Hussein from Kuwait. When the summit leaders went into a closed-door session Tuesday for concluding discussions, the crisis in the Persian Gulf didn't even come up, participants said. After Bush's private dinner with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Monday night failed to produce a breakthrough, Baker continued to press the president's case during two meetings Tuesday with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. Speaking with reporters after the second meeting, Shevardnadze stressed past U.S.-Soviet cooperation on the gulf. He noted it was remarkable, considering the long history of rivalries. ``That unity and high level of solidarity that has been accomplished in the course of preparation and adoption of past Security Council resolutions is something that we cherish very much,'' he said. ``So please don't make me get ahead of time,'' he added. The Soviets did agree that the United Nations should take another look at the effectiveness of the sanctions it imposed on Iraq, with an eye to ``new resolutions'' if necessary to enforce the old ones. That narrowed the gap a little bit. But administration officials said many differences remain. One Soviet official, speaking on the condition of anonymity, suggested that ``Bush and Baker did not come here with a need to decide anything urgently'' and might be getting a bum rap. ``It seemed that they were interested in longer-range talks, in taking the longer view,'' the official said. Even so, it was clear that administration officials had expected more to happen. The two lecterns set up by the White House in the U.S. ambassador's residence for a news conference that never happened - one set high for the tall Bush, the other set lower for the more stocky Gorbachev - were graphic testimony to that. Did Bush send out the wrong signals in trying to win support for a more militant stance toward Iraq at a peace conference? ``I can see the wisdom of that line of thought,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. But he suggested the need to build a consensus and ``having everybody on board'' was more important than a question of location and timing. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Tom Raum covers the White House for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: East's Perils Acknowledged, But Aid Still Uncertain
With PM-Summit Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Summit delegates offered their concern, but little concrete help to cope with the seething nationalism and economic troubles that threaten Eastern Europe's young democracies and the crumbling Soviet empire. Speaker after speaker mentioned the dangers to peace and democracy as the leaders of 34 nations met at the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, one year after Eastern Europe's breathtaking revolutions. ``A new welfare war may rise in place of the Iron Curtain,'' warned Hungarian Prime Minister Joszef Antall. Poland's Tadeusz Mazowiecki raised the specter of an ``A-class Europe and a B-class Europe.'' German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who is preparing to ship food to help the Soviet Union through its harsh winter, used his first summit speech as head of his reunified country to urge the wealthy West to bail out the poorer East. Discussion of one grave danger - the migration of millions from the poor East to the rich West - dominated a closed-door session Tuesday, according to German spokesman Hans Klein. Up to 5 million Soviet citizens are believed ready to emigrate once a new passport law is passed. As many as 25 million people want to leave the former East bloc, United Nations officials estimate. Soviet neighbors Czechoslovakia, Poland and Hungary are particularly worried that the flood of migrants passing through would tax their already stretched economies beyond the breaking point. Thousands of talented young people already have fled the poor Balkan nations of Romania and Bulgaria. Yet, while everyone agrees the West must act to shore up democracy in Eastern Europe, the most delegates accomplished on the migration question was to consider establishing a pan-European group to monitor it. European leaders floated various proposals to help Eastern Europe combat collapsing economies, high oil prices and dwindling Soviet supplies, the threat of mass unemployment and the renewed vigor of populist nationalism. The Netherlands, for instance, seeks a European Energy Charter to help East Europe deal with reduced supplies of oil, coal used for heating and a major shortfall in electricity predicted by 2000. Norway pledged to establish a new fund to help reduce harmful emissions that cause global warming, and delivered a reminder that capitalism cannot cure all the East's ills. ``Market forces alone cannot protect our health or achieve social justice,'' said Prime Minister Gro Harlem Brundtland. ``Economic growth cannot be bought at the expense of social justice.'' Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, whose giant country is threatened with multiple ethnic and social conflicts, delivered the strongest warning on nationalist tension, warning of a ``destructive snowball effect'' if demands to revise borders and remake nations are elevated to state policy. Bulgaria's Zhelyu Zhelev, warning against ``the exaltation of national sentiment,'' urged creation of a new section in the Helsinki process - now divided into security, economic cooperation and human rights - to deal with ethnic and minority issues. Some of these proposals would cost little, others would cost billions. But no one mentioned providing money. This is at least partly because the East's needs arise as the West also is becoming strapped for cash. The United States must bear the costs of involvement in the Persian Gulf, escalating oil prices, a coming economic recession and a vast, stubborn budget deficit. Even wealthy Germany, the world's largest exporter, is expected to become a heavy net borrower on international markets to help the former East Germany achieve something approaching Western living standards. When President Bush visited Prague last weekend, all he could offer in new aid was a $60 million development fund he said he would request from Congress. One Prague resident said that was less than the value of Air Force One. But East European officials seemed appreciative that the region's plight is at least high on the West's agenda. ``The problem is there for all to see,'' said Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel's spokesman, Michael Zantovsky. ``We feel supported by the speeches, and we think that more concrete steps will follow.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Farm Exports Expected to Face Challenges Next Year
DOC.TEXT: The value of U.S. agricultural exports rose to a nine-year high in the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30, but Agriculture Department analysts say it'll be tougher sledding in 1991. In fiscal 1990, the department's Economic Research Service said Tuesday, export values rose to $40.2 billion from $39.7 billion in 1989. That was the most since the record of $43.8 billion in 1981. Official forecasts of 1991 exports, farm income and other indicators will be issued next week at the department's annual outlook conference. But bumper crops in some other countries have already lowered prospects for U.S. grain exports in the coming year, the report said. For example, the export volume of corn in September - the final month of the 1990 fiscal year - plunged to 2.7 million metric tons, the lowest monthly volume since February 1987. Although analysts were not specific on the effects of an export slowdown, the report noted other factors that will have a bearing on farm income in 1991 and beyond. ``The U.S. economy continues to grow very slowly, and the outlook is for more slow growth, or even a brief contraction,'' the report said. ``Given an orderly unwinding of current problems, though, growth should pick up in 1992.'' Over the longer haul, it said, forecasts suggest that inflation, interest rates and the value of the dollar will drift down. ``Lower interest rates would put downward pressure on farmers' production costs and a lower exchange rate would aid farm exports,'' the report said. But good crops in much of the world ``have lowered prospects for U.S. exports of wheat, coarse grains and rice,'' it added. ``Global wheat output is expected to rise 11 percent in 1990-91, setting a record,'' the report said. ``A smaller gain in coarse grain production is likely, and world trade will slip. A record world rice crop is expected, and trade will increase only slightly.'' The monthly report by the department's Economic Research Service also said the net cash income of farmers this year is still expected to be at a record level, probably in the range of $59 billion to $63 billion. That is unchanged from previous forecasts by the agency. Net cash income is the difference between gross cash income and cash expenses. Another report Tuesday said the cereal grain needs for 55 low-income countries in 1990-91 ``are substantial, despite the favorable outlook for supplies'' globally. ``East Africa and the relatively populous region of South Asia will require the most assistance, followed by Latin America and Southern Africa,'' the report said. The analysis added that ``the situation reflects poor harvests in Ethiopia and Sudan, good crops in most of Asia and declining commercial cereal imports in most regions due to foreign exchange shortages.'' --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter has no plan to leave his job, despite speculation that he would soon step down, says his chief spokeswoman. Talk has circulated on Capitol Hill and elsewhere that Yeutter was headed for greener pastures following completion of the 1990 farm bill and the conclusion next month of international trade talks. One of the latest to surface is that Yeutter might be in line for an ambassadorship, perhaps to Germany, if that should become available. Kelly Shipp, who has been Yeutter's press secretary since 1987 when he was President Reagan's U.S. trade representative, said reports of his leaving the Cabinet soon - perhaps within 90 days - are ``not true.'' Specifically, Shipp said Tuesday it is ``not true, absolutely, patently false'' that Yeutter is seeking or being touted for an ambassador's job, Yeutter just returned from a week of meetings in Europe where the Uruguay Round of talks under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade is struggling with agricultural strategy. The U.S. view, advocated vigorously by Yeutter for years, is that trade-distorting policies, including export subsidies and some internal price supports, are bad for everybody. Some countries share the U.S. position, but others - notably the European Community - are balking. As a result, there is a possibility the trade talks could wind up at an impasse on some of the major agricultural issues. ``People have always speculated that the secretary was going to leave after the Uruguay Round,'' Shipp said. ``But he never said that, he doesn't feel that way. He hasn't even focused on life after (USDA), whenever that's going to be.'' When President-elect Bush chose him as agriculture secretary in December 1988, it was reported that Yeutter had really wanted to get back into the private sector after 3{ years as trade representative. There was also talk at the time that Yeutter and Bush had agreed the USDA commitment would last only through the formulation of the 1990 farm bill - which is awaiting Bush's signature - and the conclusion of the GATT negotiations. But Shipp said Yeutter made no such deal with Bush. ``He and the president never talked about his departure,'' she said. Yeutter, who will be 60 on Dec. 10, has an interest in a 2,500-acre family farming operation in Nebraska. He holds doctorates in law and economics and has held many public and private posts, including Agriculture Department service in the early 1970s and the presidency of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange from 1978 to 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Black Workers Win Back Pay, Advancement Opportunities
DOC.TEXT: Black workers at the Treasury Department agency that produces dollars, stamps and government securities will be given more opportunity for advancement under a court settlement that also provides for $1.4 million in back pay. The settlement was announced Tuesday by lawyers who brought the action and was confirmed by the Bureau of Engraving and Printing. The bureau said it initiated the settlement and was pleased with its terms. The agreement in U.S. District Court covers 248 present and former employees of the bureau. It ends an 8-year-old lawsuit in which black workers contended they were denied access to higher-paying ``craft'' jobs such as bookbinders, printers or pressmen. The bureau employs 750 craft workers and 1,750 non-craft workers, said bureau spokesman Ira Polikoff. The lawsuit said the bureau perpetuated an old-boy network under which white workers were brought in from private industry by friends and relatives, and were given preferential treatment for craft jobs. Whites held 85 percent of the craft jobs while blacks held nearly 100 percent of the non-craft jobs, the plaintiffs argued. Blacks were held back by an apprenticeship system and written tests that had nothing to do with the skills required for the better jobs, the plaintiffs claimed. They added that blacks often had to train the whites on equipment that was unique to the bureau. The settlement suspends the written-test requirement for selecting apprentices to the craft jobs and shortens the apprenticeship period. The agreement also sets aside 72 bookbinder and pressman apprenticeships to be filled from within the bureau. Top officials of the Bureau of Engraving and Printing ``just didn't seem to care'' about the discrimination built into the hiring and apprenticeship system, said attorney David P. Donovan. Joseph M. Sellers of the Washington Lawyers Committee for Civil Rights Under Law, called the situation at the bureau ``one of the most egregious'' examples of discrimination in the federal government. Polikoff said the bureau initiated the settlement, which includes reforms suggested by Peter Daly after he took over as bureau director in 1988. ``He saw that the system was outdated and that it needed to be modernized,'' Polikoff said. He disagreed with Sellers' characterization of the degree of discrimination, and said that in 1983 the bookbinders apprentices consisted of 17 blacks and one woman. The settlement also provides for wage increases for 39 employees costing $300,000 in the first year of the settlement and pension increases for 44 retired employees at a cost of more than $170,000 a year, according to a statement from the Washington law firm of Wilmer, Cutler & Pickering, whose attorneys brought the lawsuit.

DOC.HEAD: Hubble Records Major Storm on Saturn: Caused by a `Burp?'
DOC.TEXT: Through the eye of the Hubble Telescope, scientists have recorded a gigantic storm blowing across Saturn at more than 1,000 mph, sending ammonia clouds billowing 150 miles into space. Pictures taken by the telescope's planetary camera show that the storm, which began in September as an earth-sized white spot, now girdles the planet in a band 6,000 miles across. ``It might just be the largest atmospheric structure right now in the solar system outside of the sun,'' Andrew Ingersoll, a planetary scientist from the California Institute of Technology, said Tuesday. ``The last time Saturn did anything of this magnitude was in 1933.'' After amateur astronomers discovered the white spot in September, the Hubble was trained on Saturn, the second largest planet in the solar system. The flaw in the telescope's mirrors does not detract from the instrument's ability to see such relatively close objects. By Nov. 9 and 11 when the first pictures were taken, the storm clouds ringed the planet with clearly visible swirls and loops. The Hubble photographed Saturn again last weekend, bringing the number of pictures to 400. They will be made into a film, said Charles Pellerin, director of astrophysics at NASA headquarters, ``and pretty soon we'll be able to watch what some people have called the storm of the century evolve in great detail.'' Astronomers don't know what is causing the great white belt of clouds and whether it is diffusing as it spreads or whether material from the planet is feeding it. ``These planets like Jupiter and Saturn are fluid objects, all the way to the center,'' said Ingersoll. ``There are no volcanoes erupting, because there are no volcanoes. There is no solid crust. These planets are sort of bubbling cauldrons of liquid and gas.'' The atmosphere of Saturn is composed of hydrogen and helium and the clouds contain ammonia ice crystals and possibly a mixture of sulfur and carbon compounds. Ingersoll discounted the possibility that a comet or other celestial object hit Saturn or that the disturbance was formed by smaller storms joining. ``It has to be some sort of internal intermittent thing on Saturn, like Saturn burped,'' Ingersoll said. ``Why it should wait so long to burp, I don't know.'' Saturn, the second largest planet after Jupiter, is the windiest place in the solar system with the storm being whipped by a west wind of 1,000 mph. Ingersoll said heat is coming out of the deep interior of Saturn and presumably pressures can build up. The planet's weather is not driven just by sunlight as it is on Earth. ``I don't really understand it,'' he said. ``In some mysterious way, which I don't have a clue about, Saturn burps in the summertime ... this changing season could be part of it.''

DOC.HEAD: Big Water Shortage Seen Possible in 1990s
DOC.TEXT: The decade of the '90s could confront America with a water shortage as serious as the current oil-price inflation, a top government water expert warns. ``As we move toward the 21st century, short supplies of clean water could rival expensive oil as one of the nation's most serious concerns unless we start now to implement strategies to better manage our water supplies,'' Dr. Michael D. Hudlow said Tuesday. ``I believe we're headed into a water management crisis in the 1990s,'' said Hudlow, director of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's Office of Hydrology. The severe drought that struck much of the nation in 1988 was just the first round in what could become a continuing problem, he explained. California already faces a serious water shortage. ``We're going to have real extreme drought conditions going into next spring ... unless Mother Nature cooperates and gives us a bumper crop of snowfall in the mountains of the West,'' Hudlow said. In general, the water outlook in much of the West is precarious, depending heavily on the winter snows, he said at a news conference called to discuss water conditions and resources. ``Extreme drought still grips much of the West, from California to Montana, and in parts of the Southeast. In mid-October, drought conditions in much of Georgia and the Carolinas ended with a significant flooding episode,'' Hudlow reported. Water shortages are developing as part of the normal variability of climate, he said, with the relatively wet years of the 1970s and early 1980s giving way to a drier period. And that does not include the threat of the so-called greenhouse effect, which some scientists say could raise temperatures worldwide and change rainfall patterns. If that does happen it could just make things worse, said Hudlow. While forecasting floods and drought now depends on climate records and short-term weather forecasts, Hudlow said a new water supply forecasting system is being developed by his agency. Termed WARFS, for Water Resources Forecasting Service, the system is being tested at the Colorado River Basin Forecast Office in Salt Lake City. Using long-range climate and weather models, the system can study the conditions in a local river basin and calculate probabilities of floods, drought or a return to normal conditions seasonally and farther into the future. If the testing goes well the system could be put into national service by 1992, assuming money is available, Hudlow said. The new system could provide local water managers and civil defense officials the probabilities of danger or drought on which they could make decisions, he explained. For example, reservoir managers might be reluctant to reduce water levels out of concern that they would later have too little water for generating power, irrigating crops and other uses. But if they had a reliable forecast that there was a good chance of severe flooding, a decision could be made to lower reservoir levels so flood water could be trapped and damage prevented. ``We didn't do it right in '88. We've got to get in a position to do it right now,'' Hudlow said, referring to the lack of accurate forecasts of water conditions in that drought year.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Resigns as Honorary Chairman of PAC Headed by Gingrich
DOC.TEXT: Former President Ford resigned as honorary chairman of a Republican political action committee a week after Democrats complained to him about a controversial word list the group developed for GOP campaigning. But Penny Circle, a spokeswoman for the former president, said Tuesday that his Oct. 8 resignation as honorary chairman of GOPAC was not related to the complaint he received Oct. 1 from Rep. Beryl Anthony, D-Ark., chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee. ``It was just coincidental,'' she said. Anthony's complaint was based on a 131-word list drafted by GOPAC that urged Republican candidates to use words such as ``greed,'' ``sick,'' ``permissive'' and ``liberal'' when describing Democratic opponents and words such as ``children,'' ``common sense,'' ``reform'' and ``family'' when referring to themselves. The list also suggested that Democrats should be described as ``traitors,'' but GOPAC later removed that word from the training brochure it mailed to some 6,000 Republican candidates and officeholders nationwide. Anthony wrote Ford in September asking him to ``demonstrate your support for decency in our nation's political life'' by repudiating GOPAC, whose general chairman is House Republcan Whip Newt Gingrich of Georgia. Ford replied, in a letter Anthony released Tuesday, that he had resigned the post because of a desire ``to reduce significantly my political activity.'' He did not mention the GOPAC word list but said he had delayed his response because he did not want it to become an issue in the 1990 elections. ``In view of this decision, I do not feel I should comment further,'' the former president wrote. In his complaint to Ford, Anthony characterized the list as ``demagoguery without limits, without content and without honesty.'' ``As an individual who has devoted his life to public service, I am sure you will find these activities as disgusting as I do,'' Anthony wrote. He sent Ford a copy of the list ``in the event that you have not seen it.'' Howard ``Bo'' Callaway, a former Georgia congressman who is chairman of GOPAC, said Ford, 77, stopped signing letters for the group about two years ago when he began cutting back his political activities. ``He's clearly from everything I understand just getting out of all political things,'' Callaway said. ``He has never expressed any dissatisfaction of any kind to me and I think we're close enough he would have.''

DOC.HEAD: TV Movies Score Big in Nielsens
With PM-Nielsens-List
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: ``It'' gripped viewers and ``The Big One'' shook them as the two dramas grabbed high ratings on television last week. Part two of NBC's ``The Big One,'' about a killer earthquake in Southern California, finished third in A.C. Nielsen Co. rankings released Tuesday. Part one of Stephen King's ``It,'' about a child-murdering entity, was fifth. ABC's ``Barbara Walters Special'' finished sixth. It featured Delta Burke's teary rekindling of her feud with the producers of her sitcom, ``Designing Women.'' For the sixth time of the 9-week-old fall season, NBC's ``Cheers'' was the most-watched show on television. ``60 Minutes'' on CBS was No. 2. In overall ratings, NBC was first with a 13.4 average. ABC had a 13.3 and CBS an 11.9. Each ratings point represents 931,000 television homes. For the 45th consecutive week, ABC and Peter Jennings won the network news with an 11.2 average. CBS and Dan Rather and NBC and Tom Brokaw tied at 9.7. Here are the top 10 shows, their network and rating: ``Cheers,'' NBC, 23; ``60 Minutes,'' CBS, 22.2; ``Monday Night Movie: The Big One, Part 2,'' NBC, 19.5; ``A Different World,'' NBC, 18.8; ``Sunday Night Movie: Stephen King's It, Part 1,'' ABC, 18.5; ``The Barbara Walters Special,'' ABC, 18.4; ``Empty Nest,'' NBC, 18.2; ``Roseanne,'' ABC, 18; ``America's Funniest People,'' ABC, 17.9, ``The Cosby Show,'' NBC, 17.7.

DOC.HEAD: Dairy Industry, FDA Defend Safety of Milk Supply
DOC.TEXT: Milk producers and the Food and Drug Administration say the nation's milk supply is safe despite a congressional report that contends federal testing methods are inadequate. ``Milk is one of the most tested food Americans consume,'' said Jim Barr, chief executive officer of the National Milk Producers Federation. ``The industry is constantly working with farmers, milk processors and state and federal governments to refine the testing procedures that guarantee the purity of the milk supply from cow to consumer.'' His comments came Tuesday after Rep. Ted Weiss, D-N.Y., released a report from the General Accounting Office that criticized the FDA for not being able to detect certain animal drug residues in milk. ``GAO found that we cannot rely on FDA's assurances of safety because FDA has absolutely no idea of the incidence of harmful drug residues in milk,'' said Weiss. Dr. Gerald Guest, director of the FDA's center for veterinary medicine, said the report's ``recommendations are things we will work on and need to work on.'' He said the FDA began improving its milk-testing methods after Weiss' Government Operations subcommittee held hearings on the subject last February. The milk ``is safe, but there are areas we should work to make it safer,'' said Guest. The GAO, the investigative arm of Congress, said its findings ``suggest a need for more thorough examination by FDA to identify the types and amounts of animal drug residues that may be contaminating milk.'' Even if the FDA had conducted a more thorough survey, ``the results would still be of limited value because FDA lacks test methods to detect and confirm most of the drugs believed to be used in dairy cows, and some of FDA's test methods cannot detect drug residues at the concern level set for human consumption,'' the report said. The GAO recommended that the FDA: -Ask the states and the dairy industry to routinely provide them with the results of screening tests for drug residues and information about their testing methods. -Help states evaluate commercially available screening tests and encourage that those found effective for sulfa, tetracycline and other drugs be included in the surveys now primarily used just for penicillins. -Speed up efforts to develop new testing methods. -Work closely with the states to confirm on a random basis the types and amounts of drug residues found in state screening samples. -If widespread misuse of drugs is found, the FDA should reassess its policies on drugs it allows for dairy cows and take appropriate regulatory action.

DOC.HEAD: Daily News Sues Strikers, Others Over Alleged Financial Losses
DOC.TEXT: The Daily News took a new tack in the nearly month-long strike against the tabloid by suing 11 people for allegedly burning a delivery truck, stealing bundled papers or attacking replacement drivers. Evidence in two of the three lawsuits filed in state court Tuesday includes videotapes made by management, newspaper spokesman John T. Sloan said. Each lawuit seeks $100,000 in punitive damages and unspecified compensatory damages. They claim defendants hurt the paper's ability to do business. One lawsuit claims that a member of the drivers union set fire to a truck outside the paper's Brooklyn printing plant on Oct. 25, the night the strike began. Another claims two Wall Street Journal drivers stole bundles of the News that had been left off at a drop-off point by non-union drivers on Oct. 30. The third lawsuit accuses eight people of attacking non-union drivers and independent distributors on Oct. 31 at a paper drop-off point. Nine unions representing more than 2,000 employees at the nation's third-largest newspaper went on strike over what they said were unfair labor practices. The walkout followed month of unsuccessful contract talks. In a separate court action, strikers won a victory when U.S. District Court Judge Jack B. Weinstein issued a temporary restraining order Tuesday night permitting striking pressmen to expand pickets outside the Brooklyn plant. The pressmen complained management and police infringed on their rights by confining pickets to side streets on either end of the block-long plant.

DOC.HEAD: Automaker, Union Inaugurate Program on Repetitive Motion Trauma
DOC.TEXT:
General Motors Corp. is the last of the Big Three U.S. automakers to establish a program for helping workers ward off potentially crippling repetitive motion injuries. One hundred thirty-eight plants and an estimated 302,000 workers will take part in an effort similar to those being undertaken by Chrysler Corp. and Ford Motor Co. last year and earlier this year, Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole said Tuesday. The GM pact is part of a settlement of government charges that the nation's largest automaker violated safety and health rules at plants in Trenton, N.J., and Oklahoma City, Okla. GM will pay $360,000 in fines for the alleged violations. ``The transformation of the workplace required by this agreement won't be possible overnight,'' said Stephen P. Yokich, a UAW vice president. ``But if we are to make progress, there must be an immediate recognition by the management at each individual plant of the full extent of the problem.'' A spokeswoman said GM would have no immediate comment. Repetitive motion traumas, also referred to as cumulative trauma disorders, are disorders of the musculoskeletal and nervous systems caused by repetitive motions or exertion over extended periods. Painful and sometimes crippling, they range from back injuries to a nerve disorder of the hand and wrist to various tendon ailments. They comprise about 48 percent of the workplace injuries for which the department's Occupational Safety and Health Administration keeps records. Preventive measures include redesigning work stations t better accommodate the body by, for example, adjusting workbench heights. Also, devices can be used to prevent excessive lifting or similar exertions. Tools and training can be redesigned.
---
DOC.HEAD: Judge Refuses Bail For Son Of Interior Secretary
DOC.TEXT:
A judge has refused bail to the son of Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan, saying Robert Jeffrey Lujan, who was arrested on a rape charge, was ``an unreasonable danger'' to the community. Circuit Court Judge Donald M. Haddock in suburban Alexandria, Va., on Tuesday rejected an appeal from Lujan's attorney who argued that the young man was not a threat to flee and had no history of violent behavior. Lujan's attorney, Robert Powell, said he would take the case to the Virginia Court of Appeals. Lujan, 28, was arrested Wednesday and held without bail on charges of raping a woman resident of the same apartment building where Lujan lives with his parents. The 48-year-old woman testified she awoke to find Lujan - naked and armed with a shotgun - sitting on her bed. Powell has said Lujan has admitted spending several hours in the woman's apartment, but added the woman invited him to the apartment and that the sexual relations were consentual. Manuel Lujan said after the arrest that his son, who had a federal felony drug conviction in 1983, has a severe drinking problem.
---
DOC.HEAD: New AIDS Vaccine Candidate Approved For Early Clinical Trials
DOC.TEXT: A new AIDS vaccine candidate that has been shown to work in one chimpanzee has won approval for early human clinical tests. The candidate vaccine approved for further testing by the Food and Drug Administration was developed through the cooperation of the National Institute for Allergy and Infectious Diseases, the National Cancer Institute and Immuno-U.S., Inc., a Rochester, Mich. branch of an Austrian company. At a news conference Tuesday, company officials said the clinical trials will test the safety of the vaccine and determine whether the 60 test subjects develop antibodies against human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), the virus that causes AIDS. This first step of human testing, called Phase I trials, will not use AIDS patients. If the vaccine proves to be safe and shows promise, then Phase II trials will more thoroughly test for protection against AIDS. A final phase of testing would be required before the FDA releases the vaccine for general use. The candidate vaccine is a genetically-engineered synthetic glycoprotein that was derived from the envelope, or skin, of the HIV1 virus. This part of the virus envelope is called gp160. The theory is that the body's immune system will react to gp160 and develop antibodies. These antibodies then would trigger an immune response in the body should there be contact with the HIV virus. Dr. Martha Eibl, director of AIDS vaccine research at Immuno AG, the parent company of Immuno-U.S., said that two forms of the vaccine were tested on four chimpanzees. The chimps were injected with the candidate vaccine and then injected with the AIDS virus, using a dose that is 100 times the amount needed to cause an infection in the laboratory. All four of the chimps developed some immune response, and one of the animals remained free of AIDS. ``It has protected a chimp from productive infection for nearly three years,'' Eibl said of the candidate vaccine. ``That is the longest protection up to now.''

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Identify Man Who Burned Himself as Vietnamese
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs first two grafs to fix typos
DOC.TEXT: A man who burned himself to death on the steps of the Capitol has been identified as a Vietnamese newspaper publisher who recently moved from California to Washington. Authorities were unable to identify Nguyen Kim Bang, 56, after the Monday incident because he was burned beyond recognition. He doused himself with a flammable liquid and set himself afire on the steps of the Capitol's West Front. A law enforcement official who spoke on condition of anonymity identified the man Tuesday and said he moved here two months ago to help start a newspaper in northern Virginia. Acquaintances said he had been distressed about the treatment of his fellow countrymen in Germany and about his own strained ties with a newspaper in California, the Vietnam Daily News of San Jose. The law enforcement official and acquaintances said Bang evidently had spent time in a ``re-education'' camp after North Vietnamese communists overran the South and later became one of the boat people who fled Vietnam by sea.

DOC.HEAD: Rare Florida Landing Ends Last Secret Shuttle Mission
LaserPhoto CSB1
DOC.TEXT: Atlantis ended its secret mission where it began, making the first shuttle landing in Florida since 1985. Many NASA workers who launch the spaceships got their first chance to see one come back. Rain-dampened desert runways and high wind kept Atlantis from landing in the California desert as planned. NASA opted for clear skies, calm winds and the concrete runway at Kennedy Space Center for touchdown Tuesday afternoon. ``We didn't expect to be here when we left,'' mission commander Richard Covey, an Air Force colonel, said after the spacecraft touched down. During their secret Pentagon mission, Atlantis' five astronauts put in orbit a satellite to spy on Iraq. Atlantis' astronauts had planned to return on Monday, but high winds at Edwards Force Base, Calif., forced them to stay in space another day. Rain at the Mojave Desert base Monday night left the natural surface runways too wet on Tuesday, and the wind was too high for a landing on Edwards' concrete runway. So NASA decided to use Kennedy, where Atlantis touched down on the 2.8-mile paved runway, its arrival heralded by its signature twin sonic booms. Kennedy workers, given just a few hours' notice, scrambled to prepare for the landing. About 250 people cheered the near-perfect touchdown. They included two busloads of launch control center workers who had counted down to Atlantis' fiery liftoff in an unusual nighttime launch five days earlier. ``You have to remember that half the workforce (at Kennedy) has never seen a shuttle landing,'' said launch director Bob Sieck. ``It's a real treat for them and of course we're thankful for it.'' It was the sixth shuttle landing at Kennedy. The last was in 1985, when Discovery blew a tire and sustained brake damage on touchdown. Atlantis appeared to be in good shape, with only a few dings in the heat-resistant tiles, said William Lenoir, head of NASA's spaceflight program. The shuttle had enough supplies to stay in orbit until Thursday if necessary. The mission, delayed since July by hydrogen leaks, was the seventh and last secret shuttle flight for the Pentagon, which still plans to fly unclassified cargoes on two more shuttles but will use unmanned rockets for secret payloads. The Pentagon ordered a news blackout on the mission, but sources said the crew deployed a satellite that will conduct photo surveys or eavesdrop on communications in the Persian Gulf. ``One of these days we'll be able to tell you about Dick and Frank and Carl and Bob and Sam's excellent adventure,'' Covey told a crowd of about 150 people on the crew's return to Houston hours after the landing. ``For now, it'll have to remain under ropes and under tight cover.'' The other crew members were pilot Frank Culbertson Jr., a Navy commander, and Army Maj. Charles ``Sam'' Gemar, Air Force Lt. Col. Carl Meade and Marine Col. Robert Springer, all mission specialists. Among those greeting the astronauts in Houston were their wives, who had been at Edwards for landing. NASA plans to use Kennedy for more landings but prefers Edwards because it has a variety of lakebed runways and a concrete strip to choose from, weather more stable than Florida's, and wide-open spaces with more room for error. The space agency saved $1 million and about a week's time by using Kennedy since Atlantis doesn't have to be taken back to Florida atop a jetliner. Columbia, also grounded this summer by hydrogen leaks, is scheduled to fly next, in early December, on an astronomy mission.

DOC.HEAD: Harvard Law Students Sue School to Broaden Minority Faculty Hiring
DOC.TEXT: A group of Harvard Law School students turned their legal training into a weapon against their own school with a lawsuit aimed at getting more minorities hired as professors. ``Today we use the only instrument of power Harvard Law School seems to understand,'' said second-year student John Bonifaz. ``Today we take Harvard to court.'' The lawsuit filed Tuesday and signed by 11 students accused the Ivy League school of failing to hire any minority women, American Indians, Asian-Americans, disabled people, openly homosexual men and women, or Hispanics to the permanent faculty. It also claims Harvard discriminates against white women and blacks in its faculty hiring. ``The complaint does not have merit, and in due course we will submit a formal response to the Superior Court,'' law Dean Robert C. Clark said in a statement. The student group that sued, the Harvard Law Coalition for Civil Rights, said five of 66 tenured and tenure-track faculty members at the law school are women, or 7.58 percent. Nationwide, at law schools approved by the American Bar Association, 23.7 percent of faculty members are women. Of the school's four tenure-track faculty members, two are black, the lawsuit said. Three of 62 tenured positions, or 4.84 percent, are held by blacks. Clark did not challenge the students' figures but countered that about one-third of the school's part-time lecturers are women or minorities. The lawsuit seeks to force Harvard to give weight to diversity in its hiring and establish an affirmative action plan and other corrective measures. In 1971 Derrick Bell became the first black appointed to a full-time faculty position at the law school, founded in 1817. Bell in April took an unpaid leave of absence to protest Harvard's hiring policies. He joined the students at a sidewalk news conference after the lawsuit was filed.

DOC.HEAD: 28 Leftist Leaders Arrested, Charged With Seeking Armed Revolution
DOC.TEXT: Security officers have arrested 28 leftist leaders on charges of plotting armed revolution and instigating violent labor and campus protests, police and new reports said today. Police said that since the crackdown began last month, 13 radical student and labor leaders have been arrested on charges of organizing the Workers Struggle League, with 170 members at 60 factories in five cities. Police said the group has sought an armed revolution led by students and workers to topple the government of President Roh Tae-woo and establish a communist state. The group has operated a phony trading company in Seoul, the Jaeil (first) Planning Co., and ordered workers and students to set up revolutionary bases in factories, police said. Police said the group has described South Korea as a U.S. colony and campaigned for the ouster of what they called the nation's pro-U.S. dictatorship. About 43,000 U.S. troops are stationed in the country under a mutual defense pact. In a related but separate crackdown, Yonhap, the South Korean news agency, quoted the Agency for National Security Planning as saying it arrested 15 dissidents and students last month. Those arrested by the security agency were accused of organizing the Vangard Line, an underground group allegedly following North Korea's revolutionary propaganda, Yonhap said. The agency's crackdown began Oct. 24, when security officers arrested Song Gap-suk, head of Chondaehyup, a nationwide radical student alliance. Song and other radical students were alleged to have sought secret contacts with Communist North Korea through the Libyan embassy in Seoul, Yonhap said. Song's group has organized violent anti-U.S. and anti-government protests. Security officers are tracking down other student leaders, Yonhap said. All are to be charged with violations of the National Security Law, which carries a maximum penalty of life in prison. More than 100 radical students and dissidents have been arrested this year on similar charges. In a major crackdown last month, the security agency crushed a 1,600-member revolutionary ring and arrested 40 leaders. South Korea's leftist movement has mushroomed in the past 10 years, with radical leaders calling for armed revolution and using factories and campuses for their bases. The radicals have staged violent street protests, but their violent tactics and ideological extremism have failed to build widespread public support. U.S. facilities have been firebombed frequently.

DOC.HEAD: New Government's Cabinet Sworn In
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar today presented a 32-member Cabinet dominated by loyalists who helped propel him into office after political and religious turmoil sank the previous government. The ministers who took their oaths of office include just two with a long history in the top ranks of national government. Seven others served as junior ministers during Prime Minister V.P. Singh's government, which lasted just 11 months, but sided with Chandra Shekhar when he split Singh's Janata Dal Party two weeks ago. Singh lost a vote of confidence on Nov. 6, and Chandra Shekhar replaced him four days later. No portfolios were announced during the swearing-in ceremony, but Press Trust of India said Chandra Shekhar retained the top ministerial posts in defense, home affairs and information and broadcasting for himself. Press Trust and another news agency, United News of India, later reported a breakdown for the other ministries. Deputy Prime Minister Devi Lal was given agriculture and tourism. Devi Lal was minister of agriculture under the previous government until being forced out in a power struggle with Singh. Vidyacharan Shukla, who held a half-dozen Cabinet posts between 1966 and 1980, is the new foreign minister. The swearing-in ceremony at the presidential palace was marred when police beat journalists, snatched cameras and kicked them out of the palace. Police prevented about 100 journalists from entering the ceremonial hall, claiming they had arrived too late. At least two reporters' arms were cut by glass when the window in a door was smashed. Police grabbed at least two cameras from photographers and beat several journalists with bamboo staves. ``This is a brutal act by the police,'' Subodh Kant Sahay, minister of state for home affairs in the new government, said later. Sahay held the same post in the previous government. Sahay will also be minister of state for information and broadcasting. Minister of state is a junior rank below minister. The Indian Press Association issued a statement condemning the attack. Chandra Shekhar, whose splinter group, the Janata Dal (Socialist) Party, commands barely 10 percent of the seats in Parliament, became prime minister with the support of the opposition leader, former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi. Gandhi's Congress Party holds 195 seats in the 522-member lower house of Parliament, giving him the power to bring down the new government at any time. The Singh government collapsed when a right-wing Hindu party withdrew its support a month ago following the arrest of its leader. Lal Krishnan Advani, head of the Bharatiya Janata Party, was detained while leading a cross-country caravan to rally support for a campaign to build a Hindu temple on a site already occupied by a Moslem mosque. At least 386 people were killed in Hindu-Moslem riots touched off by the temple-building project.

DOC.HEAD: Blind Man Completing 2,167-Mile Appalachian Trail Hike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Hiker expected to finish trek at 10 a.m. EST.
DOC.TEXT: Bill Irwin today neared the end of his eight-month, 2,167-mile quest to become the first blind person to hike the entire Appalachian Trail. Accompanied on his odyssey by his guide dog, Orient, he planned to walk the final 2.4 miles to Baxter State Park in the Maine wilderness this morning. Irwin, a 50-year-old recovered alcoholic who lost his sight to an eye disease when he was 28, decided to attempt the feat as an affirmation of his faith in God.
