Sponsors helped pay his expenses. ``I'm no great example of anything,'' the Burlington, N.C., resident said in a September interview. ``Any blind person that is capable could do the same thing if they wanted to go through the same difficulty.'' A party was planned in Irwin's honor at a lodge tonight, said Carolyn Starling, a friend who served as his spokeswoman during his journey from Georgia. Eighteen fellow members of Irwin's church traveled to Maine by bus last weekend from Burlington, N.C., to celebrate Irwin's achievement, she said. In recent days, Irwin has hiked in snow and sleet, but today's forecast held what Ms. Starling called ``prayed-to-order weather.'' ``It's such a fitting end,'' she said. Since setting out from Georgia in March, Irwin has fallen down dozens of times. He has broken a rib, worn out equipment and coped with foul weather. He said in September that the scariest part of the trip was ``starting out on Springer Mountain all alone in the middle of the worst flood in the history of Georgia ... not even knowing how I was going to get down the trail.'' Though he couldn't see the magnificent vistas or trailside sunsets during his trek, Irwin said he found solace in the silence of the woods and beauty in the odors and other sensations of nature. At the urging of Baxter State Park officials, he interrupted his hike in late October to climb mile-high Mount Katahdin - normally the last northern leg of the trail - before winter weather closed that section of the trail.

DOC.HEAD: GM Recalls 520,000 Cars for Brake Light, Cruise-Control Malfunctions
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. is recalling about 520,000 1989-90 cars because of a faulty switch that can keep the brake lights from going on and the cruise control from turning off. The No. 1 automaker said Tuesday its is recalling certain 1989-90 Pontiac Grand Prix, Oldsmobile Cutlass Supremes, Buick Regals and 1990 Chevrolet Lumina cars. GM dealers will inspect the cars and replace the switch for free, spokesman David Sloan said Tuesday. ``It's a safety recall so you want to get it fixed as soon as possible,'' he said. Since 1989, GM has learned of 10 accidents, including four minor injuries, in which the defect allegedly was present, Sloan said. None of the accidents involved fatalities. The cars may have a faulty switch that can result in the brake lights not going on when the brakes are applied, or staying on all the time. If cruise control is being used, the cruise control, which normally shuts off when the brakes are applied, may resume when the brakes are released, GM said. When that occurs, the cruise control can be turned off manually or by reapplying the brakes, GM said.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Keeps Stiff Upper Lip at Palace Feast
With PM-Summit Rdp Bjt
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 3rd graf, ``If she loses xxx to CORRECT 11 1/2 years to 15 years
DOC.TEXT: Margaret Thatcher may lose her job next week, but Britain's Iron Lady kept a stiff upper lip at a glittering feast for summit leaders. The British prime minister chatted politely with her Belgian counterpart, Wilfried Martens, just two hours after being pushed into a second-round vote for the leadership of her Conservative Party. If she loses next week, Mrs. Thatcher will be out of a 15-year job as party leader and will step down as prime minister. But Mrs. Thatcher put on a brave face and a black-and-red brocade gown after hearing the news and attended a ballet and five-course dinner at Versailles Palace. Seated at a dinner table as long as a fashion runway in the shimmering Hall of Mirrors, Mrs. Thatcher smiled for photographers but refused to comment on her future. Seated directly across the table, ironically, was French Premier Michel Rocard, who survived a narrow no-confidence vote Monday in the National Assembly. What was Mrs. Thatcher's mood? She wasn't letting on. A British diplomat who was asked the question simply threw back his head and roared in laughter. --- Ever the polite host, French President Francois Mitterrand held up the ballet performance by star dancers of the Paris Opera while Mrs. Thatcher made her entrance 25 minutes late. The troupe performed a medley of pieces by Tchaikovsky, Auguste de Bournonville and Marius Pepita. Later, between bites of a dinner roll, President Bush offered the simple critique: ``That ballet was good.'' --- Mitterrand beamed from his seat at the center of the table next to First Lady Barbara Bush. Few leaders can throw a party in a place like Versailles. Built by King Louis XIV during the 17th century, the chateau and its manicured gardens and fountains define grandeur, Gallic style. Dining in the Hall of Mirrors aglow with chandeliers requires a menu equal to the venue. The army of chefs feeding 120 heads of state or government and their spouses and ministers settled on the following: Shellfish soup, lobster from Brittany, capon dressed with foie gras, cheese and iced nougat sprinkled with Grand Marnier liqueur. They washed it down with two vintage wines, a 1978 Chateau-Margaux and 1985 Puligny-Montrachet. Coffee was in high demand among the summit leaders, who heard 21 speeches during day-long conferences Tuesday. --- Marie Antoinette supposedly mocked starving peasants with the line, ``Let them eat cake.'' She lost her head. Today's French leaders have learned their lesson in a land where the stomach is the real king. The thousands of police officers, journalists, paramedics and ordinary palace workers dined on bouillabaisse, creamy veal stew and rich chocolate mousse in a palace wing converted into a 100-table dining room. ``I hear in America they just get sandwiches,'' a gendarme said, shaking his head. ``Poor guys.''

DOC.HEAD: Milli Vanilli: Thick Foreign Accents Raised Suspicions
LaserPhoto LA1
DOC.TEXT: Exposed as lip-syncing frauds, the Milli Vanilli duo say that rather than come clean about the sham, they once took a dialect coach on tour with them to help them shed their foreign accents. ``Every time we gave an interview, the reporters would hear my French accent or Rob's German accent and they'd say, `No way. How could these guys have sung the songs?''' Fabrice Morvan said in today's Los Angeles Times. ``We didn't want to do any more interviews,'' said his partner, Rob Pilatus. ``The more we talked, the worse things got.'' Dialect Accent Specialists in Los Angeles was hired in August 1989 and paid by Arista Records to accompany Pilatus and Morvan and help them sound more like the singing voices they mouthed on their hot-selling album, they told the Times. On Monday, the National Academy of Recording Arts & Sciences stripped Milli Vanilli of its Grammy after its producer confirmed rumors that Pilatus and Morvan were just front men on the album that won them best new artist honors in February. The pair met reporters Tuesday and heaped blame on their German producer, Frank Farian. They claimed he took advantage of them when they were down and out in Munich. ``We were seduced, we were abused and we felt very guilty,'' Pilatus said. The deception began to unravel at a 1989 concert when their audio system playing the album ``Girl You Know It's True'' started to skip like a broken record, the Times reported today. The recording at the Bristol, Conn., show kept rerunning the lyrics: ``Girl you know it's, Girl you know it's ...'' ``I knew right then and there it was the beginning of the end for Milli Vanilli,'' Pilatus told the newspaper. ``When my voice got stuck in the computer and it just kept repeating and repeating, I panicked. I just ran off the stage.'' Pilatus and Morvan, both 25, said at Tuesday's news conference that they had been pressing Farian to let them sing on the next album. ``We said to Frank Farian, `You don't let us sing on the album. Don't do this anymore,'' Pilatus said. ``We don't want to live like this. ``We don't want to be embarrassed every night by Arsenio Hall. We didn't want to go to clubs and (have) every girl say, `Hey, you don't sing on the records.' We wanted to stop.'' Their album sold 7 million copies and made the two unknowns international stars. Pilatus said it actually featured vocalists Johnny Davis, Brad Howell and Charles Shaw. Pilatus said he and Morvan were offered $4,000 each to become Milli Vanilli when they were living in a Munich housing project and were so poor they had to steal food. ``You get something, but for that you make a pact with the devil,'' Pilatus said. ``We really love our fans. ... We just hope that they understand that we were young, that we just wanted to live the life the American way.'' Clive Davis, president of Arista Records, knew they were faking, the pair and manager Carsten Heyn claimed, despite repeated Arista denials. Pilatus, born in New York and raised in Germany, and Morvan, a native of Guadaloupe in the French West Indies, intend continue to their musical career - minus the Milli Vanilli name. The new monicker? ``Rob and Fab, the German and the French,'' Pilatus said.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Bush May Have Pushed Too Hard on Gulf Resolution
An AP News Analysis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material top 9 grafs to reflect morning developments. Picks up 8th graf pvs...``When the...'' ^By TOM RAUM
DOC.TEXT: President Bush counseled ``just be patient'' when pressed on why the Soviet Union hadn't joined his call for a resolution authorizing military force against Kuwait. But in the end, Bush seemed to be the impatient one. By seeking support for a resolution dealing with war at a conference dedicated to peace, Bush may have given the impression of pushing too hard. That threatened to alienate some of those who stood with the United States in earlier United Nations actions against international outlaw Iraq. Even so, the president declared today that ``we're on the same wavelength as the Soviet Union'' on Persian Gulf policy, despite departing Paris without a new UN resolution backed by the Soviets in his pocket. Bush was heading to the Middle East - where he will meet with Saudi and exiled Kuwaiti officials today, U.S. forces on Thanksgiving and Egyptian officials on Friday - without the the clear consensus he had hoped to forge while here at a 34-nation European summit. The president's hand on the Persian Gulf also may have been weakened by the political defeat delivered to British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on Tuesday by her own Conservative Party. Mrs. Thatcher, who was forced into a second party leadership vote next week, has been Bush's staunchest ally in insisting that the military option be left open in the gulf. At a news conference today before leaving Paris, Bush hinted that he and Gorbachev had reached understandings on how to proceed against Saddam Hussein that he could not publicly divulge. He suggested this unity also may have been obscured by ``the technicalities of diplomacy'' and that the ``coalition in the sands and on the seas of the gulf'' was holding together. Like lobbyists on Capitol Hill in search of votes, Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker III worked the halls and the elegant salons in which the 34-nation Conference on Cooperation and Security in Europe had gathered to celebrate the end of East-West hostilities. But the U.S. efforts failed to wring clearcut agreement from summit leaders on what to do next to dislodge Iraq's Saddam Hussein from Kuwait. When the summit leaders went into a closed-door session Tuesday for concluding discusions, the crisis in the Persian Gulf didn't even come up, participants said. After Bush's private dinner with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Monday night failed to produce a breakthrough, Baker continued to press the president's case during two meetings Tuesday with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. Speaking with reporters after the second meeting, Shevardnadze stressed past U.S.-Soviet cooperation on the gulf. He noted it was remarkable, considering the long history of rivalries. ``That unity and high level of solidarity that has been accomplished in the course of preparation and adoption of past Security Council resolutions is something that we cherish very much,'' he said. ``So please don't make me get ahead of time,'' he added. The Soviets did agree that the United Nations should take another look at the effectiveness of the sanctions it imposed on Iraq, with an eye to ``new resolutions'' if necessary to enforce the old ones. That narrowed the gap a little bit. But administration officials said many differences remain. One Soviet official, speaking on the condition of anonymity, suggested that ``Bush and Baker did not come here with a need to decide anything urgently'' and might be getting a bum rap. ``It seemed that they were interested in longer-range talks, in taking the longer view,'' the official said. Even so, it was clear that administration officials had expected more to happen. The two lecterns set up by the White House in the U.S. ambassador's residence for a news conference that never happened - one set high for the tall Bush, the other set lower for the more stocky Gorbachev - were graphic testimony to that. Did Bush send out the wrong signals in trying to win support for a more militant stance toward Iraq at a peace conference? ``I can see the wisdom of that line of thought,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. But he suggested the need to build a consensus and ``having everybody on board'' was more important than a question of location and timing. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Tom Raum covers the White House for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Dip, Dollar Dives
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange continued to decline in thin trading today, while the dollar closed sharply lower against the yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which had shed 312.68 points on Tuesday, lost another 388.49 points, or 1.67 percent, closing at 22,816.99. A total of 260 million shares were traded on the first section, up from 210 million shares Tuesday. Many securities firms and other institutional investors were refraining from buying as they adjusted their positions for the month's end, said Osamu Yamazaki, general manager of the equity department at New Japan Securities Co. Also discouraging buyers, he said, were a sharp decline on Wall Street overnight, continuing high interest rates in Japan and the lingering Middle East crisis. The dollar closed at 127.68 yen, down 1.25 yen from Tuesday's close of 128.93 yen. It opened at 128.68 yen and ranged between 127.45 yen and 128.70 yen. The dollar now has lost 2.05 yen in the last three trading days. Some $15.28 billion changed hands in today's spot trading, up from $6.14 billion on Tuesday. Akihiko Kagawa, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo, said the dollar came under selling pressure through cross trading between the German mark and the yen. Kagawa said yen buying followed a narrowing in differences between Japanese and German interest rates. Higher interest rates tend to make a country's currency more attractive to investors. Kagawa said German rates began declining Tuesday. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 85.56 from Tuesday's close of 85.34. Their yield fell to 7.585 percent from 7.635 percent.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. President to Visit Greece For First Time Since 1959
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today he will visit Greece early next year, when he also has planned a stop in Turkey. Bush's visit was announced by White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater as the president met with Greek Prime Minster Constantine Mitsotakis. The last U.S. president to visit Greece was Dwight Eisenhower in 1959. Fitzwater said a date for the visit would be set soon.

DOC.HEAD: Navajos Choose Zah as New President
DOC.TEXT: Navajo voters chose former Chairman Peterson Zah to again lead the divided tribe as the first elected successor to the jailed Peter MacDonald. ``The first order of business will be to put the tribe back together,'' Zah told hundreds of supporters after defeating interim President Leonard Haskie 46 percent to 32 percent Tuesday. Zah, chairman from 1983 to 1987, will be president, a position replacing chairman under a newly created three-branch system of government for the nation's biggest Indian tribe. Zah, 52, of Low Mountain, had 23,311 votes to Haskie's 16,354. George P. Lee of Shiprock, N.M., an excommunicated official of the Mormon church who had been MacDonald's running mate, had 11,407, or 22 percent, in write-in votes. Haskie, a 46-year-old engineer, said the vote totals show Zah doesn't have a stronghold on tribal support. The tribe's Board of Election Supervisors disqualified MacDonald from running against Zah after his Oct. 17 conviction in tribal court on bribery, ethics and conspiracy charges. The Navajo Nation Council then let Haskie face Zah. MacDonald, 61, was sentenced to nearly six years in a tribal jail and five years of labor for taking cash, loans, plane rides and the use of a car from businessmen trying to curry favor with him. His son, Peter ``Rocky'' MacDonald Jr., 36, was convicted of similar charges and sentenced to 1{ years in jail and a year of labor. The elder MacDonald was suspended as chairman last year, during his fourth term. He still faces trial on conspiracy charges stemming from the tribe's purchase of a ranch for $33.4 million from a company that paid $26.2 million for the property five minutes earlier, and on 93 fraud counts stemming from the tribe's 1986 elections. The council in April reorganized tribal government. The president's powers are limited to heading the executive branch. The new post of speaker was created to head the council, the tribe's legislative branch. The tribe also has a judiciary. About 51 percent of the nearly 100,000 registered Navajo voters cast ballots Tuesday. There are 219,000 Navajos in Arizona, New Mexico and Utah. Voters made their choices by connecting symbols of broken arrows to photos of the candidates or by writing in the candidates' names. Zah, an educator, campaigned on a platform of supporting family and education. Haskie opposed the legalization of liquor on the reservation and supported tribal ownership of mineral leases.

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuit Challenges Two-Term Council Limit
DOC.TEXT: Two city councilmen filed a federal civil rights lawsuit seeking to block a two-term limit approved by voters on Nov. 6. Charles Hazley and Robert Hernandez, who would be barred from re-election under the new law, claimed in the lawsuit Tuesday that the limit violates the Voting Rights Act of 1973 by restricting minorities' choice of candidates. Term limits are fast becoming a trend among voters fed up with incumbents. California, Colorado and Oklahoma in recent months passed limits on how long politicians may serve, and similar measures are being considered elsewhere. Hazley and Hernandez argued that city voters, the majority of whom are white, restricted the choices of voters in predominantly minority districts when they passed the term-limit measure. The measure would prevent nine of the 13 council members from seeking re-election. All five minorities on the council are affected, as are four whites. The four other council members are white. Henry E. Lyons, chairman of the Committee to Limit Terms, said minorities are not deprived of their voting rights under the term limit any more than whites. The lawsuit seeks a court order allowing the councilmen to file for re-election. The filing period opens Tuesday for the 1991 elections.

DOC.HEAD: Candidate For Poland's Presidency Called a `Modern Indiana Jones'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Tyminski faring even better in more recent poll. Picks up 3rd pvs, `Canadian colleagues ...' ^By JEFFREY ULBRICH
DOC.TEXT: The mysterious Polish emigre who exploded out of nowhere to challenge for the presidency of his native land is described by a close associate as a leader, a charmer and a modern-day Indiana Jones. Stanislaw Tyminski, 42, has moved ahead of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki in the most recent public opinion polls, supported by 20 percent of respondents against 17 percent for Mazowiecki as Sunday's election nears. Solidarity leader Lech Walesa leads with 27 percent in the survey conducted by Poland's government polling service over the weekend. Canadian colleagues of Tyminski say it all began as something of a lark. Tyminski, head of several companies in North and South America, turned a routine business trip to Warsaw in September into a run for the presidency, according to business partner Frank Ollie. ``Look, he is a very mysterious guy,'' Ollie said, describing Tyminski's route from Poland to Sweden to Canada to Peru to self-made millionaire in the West to dark-horse candidate for the top job in Warsaw. Tyminski traveled to Poland in September to attend to the business of Transtek, a company he set up in his sister's name, and to promote a book on his political and economic ideas written last summer, entitled ``Sacred Dogs.'' ``It was all fun in those days,'' Ollie said of Tyminski's early presidential aspirations. It's not entirely fun now. Tyminski is being investigated for slander for some of his comments, Polish newspapers are attacking him and questions abound about the man who came home to run for president after making his fortune. ``A Liar or a Fool,'' the pro-Mazowiecki Gazeta Wyborcza newspaper said in a headline Tuesday. ``A week before the elections, we know as much about Tyminski as he has told about himself. And from what he says, and how he says it, an image of an unbalanced individual emerges.'' His colleagues across the Atlantic paint a much different picture of the man who estimates his worth at $5 million. ``He is very charismatic,'' said Ollie, general manager of Tyminski's Canadian-based computer company, Transduction. ``He loves to talk. His stories are amazing. He would be a great dinner guest. ... He is an excellent leader. Obviously he has a way about him.'' An adventurer? ``He is. I don't think there is any doubt about it. He's a bit like a modern Indiana Jones. He just does crazy things,'' Ollie said, referring to the rugged charcter in the adventure movies. According to Bob Spanski, Tyminski's ``North American campaign manager,'' the candidate was born in a Warsaw suburb in January 1948. He left Poland at the age of 21, first going to Sweden, then arriving pretty much penniless in Canada in 1970. He became a Canadian citizen in 1975. Tyminski, who owns a 40-acre strawberry farm outside Toronto, founded Transduction in the nearby suburb of Mississauga 15 years ago. The private company produces industrial computers. Spanski says its annual sales exceed $10 million. Tyminski also heads or is associated with several other computer-related companies. ``He was in the right place at the right time, but he also took some bold steps on the right products and made a lot of money out of it,'' Ollie said. In the early 1980s, Tyminski went to Peru, ending up in Iquitos on the upper Amazon. According to Ollie, Tyminski first built a barge to distribute gasoline up and down the Amazon, but the army took a liking to it and grabbed it. ``Rumor has it he lost $800,000 on it.'' Then Tyminski decided the people of Iquitos needed cable television. Now his main Peruvian interests include TVS Iquitos, a radio-telephone business and a restaurant. ``Basically, the effect he had there was probably the exact effect he had in Poland,'' Ollie said. ``He came in as a wealthy gringo. He wanted to help the people.'' He also married one. Tyminski and his Peruvian wife, Grace, have three children. He also has a son by an earlier marriage.

DOC.HEAD: Blacks Blast Cops; Call Low-Key Investigation Racist
DOC.TEXT: Black leaders accused police of a racist double standard for their low-key investigation of the gang-rape and murder of a young black woman. Eight teen-agers were arrested Monday in the slaying of Kimberly Rae Harbour, 26, nearly three weeks after her mutilated body was found on a playing field near the housing project where she lived with her 7-year-old daughter. Investigators said the woman was repeatedly raped, beaten with a bottle and a tree limb and stabbed more than 100 times on Oct. 31. ``The people of our community, particularly the women, were put at risk by the police when they failed to inform the community,'' said Louis Elisa, president of the Boston chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Police Commissioner Francis M. Roache said officers withheld details of the grisly slaying to avoid jeopardizing the investigation, but comparisons were immediately drawn to the Charles Stuart case. Stuart, a white man, told police a black man had shot to death his pregnant wife. Police questioned blacksuntil evidence began to point to Stuart, who apparently jumped to his death in January when he learned he was a suspect. ``In the Stuart case, Mayor (Raymond) Flynn was at the hospital immediately making statements to the press and calling out every available detective because there was some great threat to public safety,'' Ellis-Hagler said. ``On this one we don't hear a whimper'' until weeks afterward, he said. ``No one saw (Harbour's killing) as any great threat to public safety,'' said the Rev. Graylan Ellis-Hagler, pastor of the Church of the United Community. ``I can't help but think the difference is that Stuart was white, and this victim was black.'' David Rodman, spokesman for the district attorney's office, said authorities were being placed in a no-win situation. ``In the Stuart case, the community was upset with the police and the prosecution for publicizing the case,'' Rodman said. ``Now they are criticizing us. You're really damned if you do and damned if you don't.''

DOC.HEAD: CNN Hands Over Noriega Prison Tapes to Judge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to DELETE extraneous possessive.
DOC.TEXT: CNN's tapes of Manuel Noriega's jailhouse phone calls to his legal team are in the hands of a federal magistrate who will help determine whether the former dictator's right to a fair trial has been jeopardized. The network handed over a briefcase full of tapes on Tuesday after the U.S. Supreme Court refused over the weekend to lift U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler's temporary order barring CNN from airing the recordings. U.S. Magistrate William Turnoff will make and study transcripts and report to Hoeveler, who as the judge who will preside over Noriega's trial on drug trafficking charges will weigh a defense request to dismiss the case. Hoeveler assigned Turnoff to listen to the tapes to avoid being ``tainted'' by having learned details of Noriega's defense strategy. No time limit for reviewing the tapes was set, but Noriega's lead attorney, Frank Rubino, said the judge guaranteed it would done ``with dispatch.'' Rubino also asked Hoeveler to set a contempt hearing against CNN for airing a conversation in alleged violation of the judge's order. The judge did not immediately set a hearing, saying he must await a decision by the chief judge of his judicial district on a CNN request to remove him from the tapes case. CNN attorney Steven Korn wouldn't say how many tapes were turned over. He would not discuss their contents or origins but said he was confident that the judge will rescind his so-called prior restraint on broadcast of the tapes. He said CNN believes it never violated the judge's order because the telecast conversations did not deal with matters protected by attorney-client confidentiality - in part because Rubino tacitly agreed to broadcasting them when he identified them on the air. Noriega has asked that the case against him be dismissed because of the taping, the freezing of his assets, and other alleged government misconduct. The fallen dictator is jailed outside of Miami on charges of taking bribes to protect the cocaine trade. His trial isn't expected to begin before the spring.

DOC.HEAD: State Of Emergency Lifted In Soviet Republic Of Kirghizia
DOC.TEXT: A state of emergency declared after ethnic violence flared in the Central Asian republic of Kirghizia in June has been lifted, Tass reported today. The official Soviet news agency said the state of emergency ``accomplished its task'' and conditions in the republic had stabilized. The clampdown was imposed on June 7, along with a curfew in the capital of Frunze and the town of Osh, about 200 miles to the south, where fighting between ethnic Kirghiz and Uzbeks claimed more than 210 lives. The two ethnic groups, both largely Sunni Moslems who speak Turkic dialects, are engaged in a dispute over the allocation of land plots for building private houses.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers: Parental Dieting, Praise Vital for Fat Kids
DOC.TEXT: Tubby kids stand a better chance of slimming down and keeping the weight off if their overweight parents try to reduce too, stay away from junk food and praise the children along the way, researchers said today. ``If you have children who you don't want to eat potato chips, you can't sit in front of them eating Ho-Hos,'' said psychologist Leonard H. Epstein, head of the University of Pittsburgh's Childhood Obesity Clinic and leader of the research team. Findings published in today's Journal of the American Medical Association suggest child obesity need not persist into adulthood. Previous research concluded that fat children will become fat adults and that weight lost in dieting programs is typically regained quickly. In the study, children who participated in a weight-loss program as 6- to 12-year-olds and whose parents took part in similar programs were significantly less obese 10 years later than those whose parents received less training. Parental support, conveyed through praise and by maintaining proper eating and exercise habits, made the difference, Epstein said. ``If you have a family where both parent and child share the problem, you have to include both in the treatment in order to foster the best change in the children,'' he said. Despite the children's improvement, all parents in the study were more obese after 10 years. In the project, 75 obese children and their parents were randomly assigned to three groups. They were instructed to limit consumption to no more than 1,500 calories a day and follow an aerobic exercise program. All were asked to attend eight weekly treatment meetings followed by six monthly meetings, then meetings at the 21-month, five-year and 10-year marks. In one group, both parents and children received praise for losing weight and were trained to praise other family members for changing eating and exercise habits. In the second group, only the children received praise and were trained to praise family members for weight-control behavior. Parents and children in the third group received praise only for attending the meetings. They received information about social reinforcement without specific training in how to use the method. All subjects lost weight initially. At the 10-year mark, the children in the first group were, on average, 7.5 percent less overweight than at the beginning of the study. Those in the second and third groups were 4.5 percent and 14.3 percent fatter, respectively. Although encouraging, the study needs to be repeated to confirm its findings, Drs. Albert J. Stunkard of the University of Pennsylvania medical school and Robert I. Berkowitz of the Philadelphia Child Guidance Clinic wrote in a journal editorial. Nevertheless, they said, the findings ``are the first evidence that treatment of obesity in childhood can produce effects that persist into young adulthood.''

DOC.HEAD: The Clocks Were Running Little Behind
DOC.TEXT: Even a clockmaker can't be expected to be on time all the time. But 100 years late? Wait. Better make that 101 years. It was 1889 when workers erected the Jefferson County Courthouse in this Rocky Mountain town, and blueprints called for three clocks in the brick tower. The clocks were ordered from Germany. They still haven't arrived. It wasn't until last year that county officials decided they'd waited long enough. This time, the county contracted with a Helena electronics distributor, who arranged for the manufacture of the timepieces in Minnesota. Olivia Hagadone, chairwoman of the county's Museum Board, said the clocks were supposed to be installed to mark the state's centennial last year. But they were late - again. The clocks finally arrived last week, and the three 4-foot clocks were installed in the building's steeple. Hagadone said supporters of the project raised about $5,000 to buy and install the clocks.

DOC.HEAD: How Did Turkeys Enjoy the Food? Gobble, Gobble
DOC.TEXT: How did the turkeys that came to dinner enjoy the food? They gobbled it up, of course. Paula Silver and Lorri Bauston cooked cornbread muffins, cranberries, apple pie and stuffed squash Tuesday for six turkeys at Ms. Silver's home. The two animal-rights activists held the meal to promote humane treatment of poultry. ``The birds gobbled it up,'' Ms. Silver said. ``It was a beautiful little spread.'' Mrs. Bauston and her husband, Gene, operate an animal sanctuary in upstate New York and are traveling the country with 15 turkeys to publicize their cause. They are lobbying to have poultry protected under the federal Humane Slaughter Act, which requires that farm animals be stunned before they are killed for food. Ms. Silver, who adopted two of the Baustons' turkeys, lives in a log house on 20 acres she shares with a wild mustang, four dogs, a cat and several hens.

DOC.HEAD: Summit Partners Sign Charter of Paris; Declare Cold War Ended
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev led world leaders today in final rites for the Cold War as a 34-nation summit ended with a triumphant declaration that the ``era of confrontation and division in Europe is over.'' The celebration was tempered by concern over the Persian Gulf, and the leaders departed Paris still apparently groping for consensus on how to force Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait. The final act of the first post-Cold War European summit was marked by the signing of the Charter of Paris, a written commitment to democracy, human rights and economic freedom. ``We are closing a chapter in history. The cold war is over and we now move on toward working ... toward a peaceful and stable Europe,'' said Bush. It took only 15 minutes to sign the document, bound in red leather, which signaled an end to an era of tensions in the nuclear age. French President Francois Mitterrand was the first to sign. He was followed by Helmut Kohl, chancellor of a newly unified Germany, and the leaders of Poland, Hungary and other nations that until a few months ago were hardline communist followers of the Soviet Union. The summit opened on Monday with the formal signing of a landmark treaty that slashes non-nuclear forces in Europe and a companion non-aggression pact. But if the formal sessions were devoted to European security issues in the post Cold War era, President Bush devoted much of his backstage diplomacy to the Persian Gulf, where Iraq's occupation of Kuwait is more than three months old. Bush, headed for the Middle East and a Thanksgiving Day visit with U.S. troops there, departed without a public commitment from Gorbachev to support a United Nations resolution authorizing the use of force to dislodge Iraq's army from Kuwait. Even so, he said, ``I've said all along ... that we are on the same wave length as the Soviet Union.'' He added he was ``very encouraged about this holding together of a coalition in the sands and on the seas of the Gulf.'' The Soviets are calling for a meeting of the United Nations Security Council, a position Gorbachev underscored after meeting with Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney. ``There is a need for a meeting of the U.N. Security Council without delay to discuss the situation and take a decision there,'' Gorbachev said, describing the situaiton as ``very dangerous.'' The summit document exulted in the end to Cold War tensions that divided Europe for 45 years. Every European nation but Albania signed, as did Canada, the United States and the Soviet Union. ``Europe is liberating itself from the legacy of the past,'' the charter said. ``Ours is a time for fulfilling the hopes and expectations our peoples have cherished for decades: steadfast commitment to democracy based on human rights and fundamental freedoms, prosperity through economic liberty and social justice, and equal security for all countries.'' The charter sets up a small bureaucracy in Prague for the 34-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, as well as a center for the prevention of conflict in Vienna and an office in Warsaw to help monitor elections. ``Democratic government is based on the will of the people, expressed regularly through free and fair elections,'' the charter said. ``Democracy is the best safeguard of freedom of expression, tolerance of all groups of society, and equality opportunity for each person.'' The summit document also recommends that the heads of member states and governments meet at least once every two years, their foreign ministers annually and senior officials even more often. Bush, who met with Gorbachev over dinner on Monday night, said he was leaving Paris convinced that ``we're in good synchronization'' with other nations on strategy for ending the gulf crisis. Nevetheless, the Persian Gulf was not discussed at Tuesday's afternoon closed-door session, said French spokesman Hubert Vedrine. He said the subject did not come up, adding: ``There will be no common declaration by the 34 on the gulf.'' There was not, and the leaders departed without devoting a line of their summit charter to the issue. Asked by reporters if he had set a deadline for Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, Bush replied, ``Just watch the way all this develops. Everybody is convinced that they must get out of Kuwait with no concessions, and that's what's emerging here.''
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: PARIS: emerging here.''
DOC.NOTE: EDS: The following material is intended to stand for the cycle.
DOC.TEXT: The fruits of peace in Europe were evident in the summit discussions. Several Eastern European leaders suggested that the Warsaw Pact was headed for dissolution and appealed to the West for support to avoid an economic Iron Curtain separating Europe's haves and have-nots. Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel said he could imagine the Warsaw Pact remaining, but only as ``a temporary consultative organization'' on disarmament issues. Still, there was no shortage of problemsd to address: Kohl, leading his nation to its first major international forum since unification, endorsed the appeals of Eastern European leaders for Western financial support. ``There must now be no borders which perpetuate the prosperity divide,'' he said. ``The ideological gulfs that have been overcome must not be torn open again.'' The social highlight of the summit came Tuesday night, when the leaders gathered at the chateau of Versailles outside Paris for a ballet performance and a banquet featuring lobster and capons. Among those on hand was Britain's Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who learned shortly before the dinner that she faced a second round of balloting in an unprecedented challenge to her 11-year reign as Conservative Party leader. The summit opened Monday after leaders of 16 North Atlantic Treaty Organization members and the remaining six Warsaw Pact nations put their signatures on two treaties - one making sweeping cuts in non-nuclear arms throughout Europe and the other pledging non-aggression toward one another. The so-called Conventional Forces in Europe treaty reduces thousands of tanks, armored vehicles and other non-nuclear weapons from the arsenals of the Warsaw Pact and NATO across Europe. U.S. and Soviet officials said Tuesday that Bush and Gorbachev tentatively plan to meet in Moscow in January - hoping that negotiators can first work out problems with a nuclear arms treaty. Havel was one of several leaders who, in summit speeches, expressed regret that the Soviet Union's breakaway Baltic republics - Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania - had been excluded from the summit. The three Baltic foreign ministers protested Tuesday at the Soviet move and urged participants to help them gain a ``full and complete'' role in the conference. Also unhappy was the delegation from Albania, limited to observer status because of its isolationist policies and lack of political reform. The delegation said in a statement that the reasons for its exclusion were ``incomprehensible.''

DOC.HEAD: Florida Legislature Passes Ethics Bill
DOC.TEXT: Not one member of the Legislature voted against an ethics measure than bars more than 32,000 state and local officials from taking gifts over $100 from lobbyists. ``I don't think there's another legislature in the nation that's gone as far as we've gone,'' said House Speaker T.K. Wetherell, a Democrat. The bill, an effort to restore public confidence eroded by a criminal investigation into government ethics, passed the House 119-0 and the Senate 39-0 on Tuesday. Gov. Bob Martinez is expected to sign it into law. The bill would prohibit gifts over $100 from lobbyists and political action committees to more than 32,000 public officials, including legislators. Among the exceptions: Lobbyists can pay for food and drink of any price if it's consumed at a single sitting. The measure would impose a fine of up to $5,000 and a two-year lobbying ban on lobbyists who violate it. Officials could be removed from office. Senate Republicans had tried to amend the bill to prohibit gifts no matter the value. ``Under this bill, (a lobbyist) couldn't give you a $400 set of golf clubs,'' said Sen. Richard Langley. ``But he could give it to you one club at a time.'' But Democrat Tom Brown, the measure's chief Senate sponsor, said $100 was a reasonable amount that could be changed by the Legislature in the future. ``This is one we needed to get behind us,'' Brown said. The bill was inspired by an investigation into legislators' acceptance of trips to hunting lodges, ski resorts and foreign countries from lobbyists, and lawmakers' failure to report the gifts as the law now requires. A prosecutor has subpoenaed records from dozens of lobbyists as part of the probe. Government entities - such as state commissions, school boards and city councils - could give officials gifts, but universities and colleges could not. That would end such perks as football weekends for legislators. Also out would be the annual legislative family day at Disney World. Bill Jones of the good-government group Common Cause said the bill is a good first step but that the need for campaign finance reform is much greater.

DOC.HEAD: New Poll Puts Dark Horse In Second Place
DOC.TEXT: A previously unknown millionaire emigre who has suddenly become a contender in Poland's presidential race jumped ahead of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki in the polls today, trailing only Lech Walesa. The latest survey by the government polling service showed 42-year-old businessman Sanislaw Tyminski was backed by 20 percent of respondents. Walesa, the Solidarity chairman, was favored by 27 percent, Mazowiecki 17 percent, and the remaining three candidates shared a total of 12 percent. Twenty-four percent were undecided or did not plan to vote. If no candidate wins more than 50 percent in Sunday's election, the top two vote-getters will compete in a Dec. 9 runoff. However, the poll was conducted over the weekend - before Tyminski charged that Mazowiecki had betrayed the nation by creating economic chaos and found himself the subject of a government slander investigation. Tyminski's allegation was based in part on figures he misinterpreted and prompted journalists to take the first hard look at his international business dealings, his Canadian and Peruvian nationality and his absence from Poland for the last 21 years. The pro-Mazowiecki newspaper lamented Tyminski's meteoric rise in a front-page commentary today: ``Poland used to be the conscience of Europe and now we have a chance to become the laughing stock of the world.'' Under the headline ``A Liar or a Fool,'' the newspaper on Tuesday said Tyminski appeared ``unbalanced.'' Tyminski describes himself as a self-made millionaire who left Poland penniless at age 21 and made fortunes in Canada and the Amazon port of Iquitos, Peru. According to his campaign, he runs Transduction Ltd., a Toronto computer automation company, and leads Canada's tiny, conservative Libertarian Party. Although unknown in Poland or in emigre circles, Tyminski was given free television and radio time by newly democratic Poland's evenhanded election law, and a press making every effort to be fair covered him just as it treated Walesa, Mazowiecki or the other three candidates. However, because he initially was given no chance of winning, he was generally treated as a curiosity and not subjected to hard criticism until his surge in the polls. He appealed to Poles disenchanted by the painful market-oriented reform promulgated by Mazowiecki and endorsed by Walesa, who saw his support drop from 35 percent in a poll released Friday. ``The anti-inflationary plan threatens to bring civil war,'' Tyminski told audiences struggling with high prices, unemployment and uncertainty. ``The country has been engulfed by recession; we have neither a government nor a Parliament.'' A columnist in the Zycie Warszawy newspaper said one sociologist described Tyminski's appeal as an easy way for Poles to resolve their problem of choosing between Walesa and Mazowiecki. ``If I have a conflict hanging over me, I will gladly go out for a vodka,'' the commentator said. ``It is this vodka that (Tyminski) the only independent candidate represents.'' However, he wrote, when Tyminski made charges amounting to treason against Mazowiecki, a veteran Solidarity activist and the first non-Communist prime minister in the East bloc, ``the vodka got spilled.'' Gazeta Wyborcza, referring to the investigation of Tyminski for slander, said that a person can be imprisoned for from six months to eight years if convicted of ``publicly offending and humiliating the Polish nation.'' The poll released today was conducted Saturday and Sunday and surveyed 1,490 people in person, the government polling service said. The margin of error was 2 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Lower, Gold Steadies
DOC.TEXT: The dollar moved lower against key currencies in European trading this morning. Gold steadied after a steep drop overnight in Hong Kong. The dollar closed in Tokyo at 127.68 yen, down 1.25 yen from Tuesday's close. The dollar has dropped 2.05 yen in the past three trading days in Tokyo. Later, in London, it was quoted at 127.43 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Tuesday: -1.4734 German marks, down from 1.4760 -1.2442 Swiss francs, down from 1.2470 -4.9740 French francs, down from 4.9780 -1.6600 Dutch guilders, down from 1.6650 -1,108.00 Italian lire, down from 1,110.50 -1.1583 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1598 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9691, compared with $1.9695 late Tuesday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $377.35 per ounce at midmorning, little changed from $377.75 bid per ounce late Tuesday. In Zurich, the bid price was $377.40, down from $377.50 late Tuesday. In Hong Kong, gold dropped $8.17 an ounce today, to close at $372.13. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.12 a troy ounce, from Tuesday's $4.10.

DOC.HEAD: Mail-Bomb Suspect Agrees to Cooperate With Prosecution
DOC.TEXT: The estranged wife of a man accused of sending mail bombs that killed a lawyer and a judge has pleaded guilty in an unrelated case and is cooperating with prosecutors trying to convict her husband, a newspaper says. Federal agents are questioning Susan Moody, 28, about the mail bomb case, the Atlanta Journal-Constitution reported today. Her husband, Walter Leroy Moody Jr., is charged with sending the bombs that killed a federal judge in Alabama and a Savannah civil rights lawyer. The bombings last year terrorized the South, and especially black leaders. Mrs. Moody pleaded guilty in a witness-tampering case on Nov. 10 in an unusual Saturday session before U.S. District Judge Anthony Alaimo, the newspaper quoted unidentified sources as saying. The judge sealed the records of the proceeding and barred participants from even acknowledging a hearing took place. The newspaper filed court papers objecting to the closing of proceedings that are typically open. A hearing was scheduled for Friday. Sandra Popson, Mrs. Moody's Macon, declined comment, as did Howard Shapiro, a prosecutor in the case. The Moodys were indicted in July on charges of threatening two women who had been paid to provide a fake alibi for Moody during his efforts to overturn a 1972 bomb-possession conviction. The women were considering changing their story. Moody has been jailed without bail. Mrs. Moody, who has filed for divorce, is free.

DOC.HEAD: More Snow Falls in the West
DOC.TEXT: Snow today helped ensure a white Thanksgiving for more of the West after storms left more than 2 feet in Utah's canyons and up to 18 inches in Yellowstone National Park. The early-season snow had two predictable effects: It made traveling difficult but ski area operators happy. ``The storm was far from being a turkey,'' joked William Alder, a National Weather Service meteorologist. ``This is just perfect for the resorts.'' Utah's Big and Little Cottonwood canyons got more than 2 feet of snow. Solitude ski resort decided to open two lifts today and open more terrain Thursday. Snowbird also will open on Thanksgiving. The fast-moving storm caused traffic problems, but no serious accidents were reported. High winds - gusts to 80 mph were recorded near Wolf Creek, Colo., and to 62 mph between Cheyenne and Laramie, Wyo. - blew the snow and hampered visibility. Snow fell this morning in Boise, Idaho, and heavy snow was possible in the mountains of Washington and Oregon. The mountains of eastern Idaho generally got 1 to 3 inches, and to 18 inches fell in Yellowstone. Light accumulations were expected in the mountains of Northern California. Where it wasn't snowing, light rain was scattered throughout much of the West, as well as parts of the Midwest, Texas, Oklahoma and Kansas. The East and Southeast generally were fair with seasonable temperatures today. The high temperature for the nation Tuesday was 90 degrees at McAllen, Texas.
