DOC.HEAD: Plane Crashes in Thailand, At Least 10 Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with television saying crash occurred on approach to island. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A plane with 36 people aboard crashed on a southern tourist island just short of the airport today, and 10 bodies have been found, Thai television reported. The Bangkok Airways turboprop plane crashed as it was approaching to land at the island's airport, Channel 7 reported. It had four crew members and 32 passengers aboard, the television reported without giving further details. Flights to the island, Koh Samui, usually have many foreign tourists aboard. The island is on the Gulf of Thailand about 300 miles south of Bangkok. An aviation official in Bangkok said the Dash 8 turboprop lost contact with the control tower today about 3{ miles from the airport. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, also gave no further details. The Dash 8 can carry up to about three dozen passengers.

DOC.HEAD: Arab Vendor Convicted Of Selling Phony Kosher Hot Dogs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note language in 11th graf
DOC.TEXT: A dispute over how to grill a hot dog has a Palestinian food retailer pitted against a rabbi who is Baltimore's lone inspector of kosher meats. The merchant, George Barghout, still was touting his dogs as kosher on Tuesday despite a conviction last week for violating a city ordinance that bars merchants from claiming their products are kosher when they're not. Rabbi Mayer Kurcfeld has spent 15 months dogging Barghout, insisting that the kosher wieners he sells at his Yogurt Plus eatery are rendered non-kosher because he grills them next to non-kosher dogs. ``If the consumer believes he is getting kosher food, that is what he should get,'' the rabbi said. Jewish dietary laws forbid the commingling of kosher and non-kosher foods. Barghout says the cooking does not deprive the hot dogs of their kosher qualities. ``The flame doesn't contaminate the meat; it purifies it,'' he said. ``It doesn't make any difference what he thinks,'' Kurcfeld replied. Barghout came to the United States 31 years ago and says he is devoted to the cause of a Palestinian homeland. He owns five Baltimore food stores. Kurcfeld is an Orthodox Jew born in Israel. He takes his job with Baltimore's Bureau of Kosher Meat and Food Control so seriously that he refuses to reveal the days he travels to Philadelphia for a second job as a kosher slaughterer. ``If people knew when I was out of town, who knows what they might do?'' he asks. ``Am I in a Zionist state or am I in America?'' said Barghout. ``This is a Zionist place, I tell you, a goddamn Zionist place.'' The conviction cst Barghout $500 in fines plus court costs.

DOC.HEAD: Manuscript Fetches $1.57 Million
DOC.TEXT: A manuscript of Mozart's ``Fantasia and Sonata in C Minor'' sold today at auction for $1.57 million, tying a record for a music manuscript, Sotheby's said. The manuscript, which contained previously unknown embellishments by the composer, was part of a group of manuscripts offered by the Eastern Baptist Theological Seminary of Philadelphia. The bid by Otto Haas, a London dealership, tied the record for such a manuscript set a year ago, when Sotheby's got the same price for a piano concerto by Robert Schumann. Haas paid an additional buyer's premium of 10 percent. The manuscripts were discovered in a safe at the school in July. They had been donated in 1950 by Marguerite Treat Doane, whose father had been a prominent collector. Sotheby's said the manuscript apparently had been among a collection sold by Mozart's wife, Constanze, in 1799, eight years after the composer's death. William Howard Doane of Cincinnati, Ohio, an industrialist and hymn writer, acquired the manuscript in 1889. The fantasia and sonata are customarily played together.

DOC.HEAD: Bitter and Bittersweet: Memories Flood Back at Orphan Train Reunion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf, `He said...', to CORRECT to spent sted sent.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY16
DOC.TEXT: Time hasn't faded 77-year-old Harold Williams' memory of leaving New York City along with other orphans on a train taking them to new homes in the Midwest. ``I remember standing on the platform and then going into the train and sitting down with my teddy bear in my lap,'' he said Tuesday. ``I recall looking out the window and seeing all the people and the buildings.'' Many orphaned or abandoned children benefited from the Orphan Train Movement, which lasted from 1854 to 1929. Others merely had their suffering relocated. Their tales, good and bad, were told at an Orphan Train reunion attended by about two dozen people who took part in the unusual social experiment that sent more than 100,000 children to foster homes far from the big city. ``In 1929, me and my twin brother were put on the last orphan train out to Kansas,'' said Alan Bankston, 64, of Dayton, Ohio. ``We wound up with adoptive parents,'' he said. ``They gave us everything we needed, except love. And love is what we needed the most.'' Bankston wept during part of his talk. He said although he and his wife had six children, they took in two foster children ``because I knew how important it was to have someone love you.'' The Orphan Train came at a time when New York City was inundated by European immigrants who crowded tenements on the Lower East Side. Poverty and disease were rampant. Many children were orphaned or left to fend for themselves on the streets. Arthur Smith, 72, of Trenton, N.J., was only 49 days old when a well-dressed woman left him in a wicker basket in Gimbel's department store. When he was 4, he boarded a train for a new life on an Iowa farm. Smith said he was lucky to be taken in by a loving family, but he admitted the mystery of the woman who left him behind haunted him. ``Then I sort of put it aside,'' he said. ``I decided it was a door I wasn't meant to open. I don't feel bad about my mother. I assume she was in circumstances beyond her control.'' Williams, of Magalia, Calif., said he is still angry at his mother. ``I was a cute little baby, only 16 days old,'' he said. ``How could she dump me?'' He said he spent most of his childhood with ``an old lady who was a tyrant and her five daughters.'' ``I was scared to death of her,'' Williams said. ``If I became sick, I got beaten. She had this theory that if you got sick, you'd done something bad.'' Williams left that home at 17, after years of being ``abused mentally, physically and sexually.'' He became a homeless alcoholic but pulled his life together with the help of a job at a dairy plant. He later became plant manager and got married. Seventy-one-year-old Winifred Williams, no relation, of Temple Hills, Md., looked at her husband, Lawrence, while she spoke to the group. ``To be an orphan means to survive,'' she said. ``You don't have a parent or a mother to love you. You tell yourself you will survive until you find someone who will love you. I felt that way when I met my husband. He made up for all the love I didn't have as a child.'' Alice Ayler, 71, of Oklahoma City, survived a nightmarish childhood in a series of foster homes where she was abused. She became a psychologist and has been married for 51 years. The reunion, she said, completed the journey begun so many years ago. ``We're all a big old family,'' she said, looking around the crowd. ``Not by blood, by something bigger.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Panel Slams Republics' Refusal To Lift Prices On Luxury Goods
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Black market dollar prices in 3rd graf cq
DOC.TEXT: The national government berated the Russian and Kazakhstan republics today for refusing to obey a decree to lift price controls on jewelry, American cigarettes and other luxury goods. The State Prices Committee said the move to free market prices for non-essential luxury items was inevitable, and that their prices should rise. The Communist Party newspaper Pravda quoted the committee as saying the defiant republics' refusal to obey the order was illegal. Prices of many luxury items have been fixed by the state, but many are regularly sold for much more than the official price by corrupt salesclerks and even the factory workers who produce the goods and the truck drivers who deliver them. Women's shoes now cost $439 on average on the black market, a pack of 20 cigarettes costs $9 and a color television set $3,638 - all three to six times higher than state prices, a newspaper report said today. The Council of Ministers, or Soviet Cabinet, announced last week it was lifting price controls on select items to encourage production of consumer goods. The order affected sales of furs, carpets, high-tech electronics, cut glassware, china, car parts, caviar and imported whiskey and gin. Within hours of the surprise announcement, the Russian republic refused to enact it and temporarily forbade the sale of the affected goods on Russian territory. The Central Asian republic of Kazakhstan also nullified the decree within its borders, and Azerbaijan said today it would temporarily ignore it while studying its impact. Floating prices are an important element of the government's plan to move to a market economy from central planning, in which the government sets all prices regardless of the cost of production. The Supreme Soviet, or national parliament, adopted a plan for gradually freeing prices last month, but has run into resistance from some republics, notably Russia, which has adopted its own plan. The Rabochaya Tribuna (Workers Tribune) newspaper today quoted the Russian Federation Statistics Committee as saying the black market prices of some consumer goods in the republic exceeded state prices by 100 to 200 percent or more. It said the average black market price for beef or pork was $16.20 and for a small jar of caviar, $37.80, both four times the state prce. In Moscow, a can of caviar fetches $63 dollars on the black market, or seven times the state price, the newspaper said. ``The price of $45 dollars for a kilogram (2.2 pounds) of chocolate candies exceeds the state price seven times over,'' it said. ``A bottle of wine is sold for $18, while the average official price is $6.30.'' The State Prices Committee rejected criticism that the freeing of prices would play into the hands of black marketeers. Pravda said as long as prices remain artificially low, ``jewelry, caviar and other goods in short supply are being bought up on a large scale for personal gain, not only by Soviet citizens but also - and this is particularly alarming - by foreigners.''

DOC.HEAD: Passionate Biblical Passages Cause Storm in Parliament
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents in 9th graf
DOC.TEXT: A liberal lawmaker challenging a proposal to regulate suggestive advertising evoked a provocative Biblical passage while ultra-Orthodox Parliament members shouted and covered their ears in protest. Arieh Eliyav of the left-leaning Labor Party said he read the passionate sections from the Songs of Songs in the Old Testament to show that indecency is not easily defined. But after seven hours of debate Tuesday, legislators voted 42-38 to give the first of three approvals needed to adopt a law banning use of nude or scantily clad women in advertising. The law is among religious legislation the ultra-Orthodox Agudat Israel Party demanded last week when it joined Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's ruling coalition. The proposed laws have incensed many secular Israelis who accuse the ultra-Orthodox minority of religious coercion. About 70 percent of Israeli Jews do not observe strict religious practices. At the beginning of the session, the debate was more academic than erotic, with lawmakers discussing whether clothed or nake women were more arousing. Then came Eliyav quoting from the Song of Songs, also known as the Song of Solomon: ``Your two breasts are like two fawns, twins of a gazelle that feeds among the lilies ... How delightful is your love, my sister, my bride, how much more pleasing is your love than wine, and the fragrance of your perfume than any spice,'' he quoted. Rabbi Avraham Ravitz of the ultra-Orthodox Torah Flag Party leaped to his feet. ``He (Eliyav) is bringing damnation upon the people of Israel,'' he shouted. ``This could only happen in the Israeli Parliament, using the Bible for political purposes. It's a shame.'' Agudat Israel legislator Rabbi Moshe Feldman covered his ears. Eliyav continued unperturbed: ``Your belly is a heap of wheat encircled with lilies ...'' After Eliyav stopped reading, three legislators urged him to leave. ``I won't let the Rabbi Ravitz teach me about loving the Bible ... Throughout the years, hundreds of millions of people throughout the world loved these words, word for word ... and we gave them to the world,'' he told the daily Yediot Ahronot newspaper.

DOC.HEAD: Detroit Tops 1 Million Mark in Census
DOC.TEXT: The city made it over the 1 million census hump, although it took a recount to do it, and officials say retaining their big city status gives them something to crow about. ``I guess I can say `I told you so,''' Mayor Coleman Young said Tuesday. He led a massive ``Detroit, Were You Counted?'' campaign to round up at least 30,000 uncounted residents after the first count showed 970,000 people. Final figures still aren't in, but Census Bureau Director Barbara Bryant told Young the city topped 1 million. The recent tally included such people as military personnel stationed elsewhere during the first count, Bryant said. Falling below 1 million would mean a loss of state and federal dollars. Officials estimated it would cost Detroit about 16 percent of its annual operating revenue of $1.9 billion. ``Hooray, hooray, hooray,'' Rep. John Conyers said from his office in Washington. ``The powers that be finally got the message that the oppressed, the homeless and the impoverished don't always have phones and houses from which to be recorded.''

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Bush
Bush Says Embassy In Kuwait Dug New Well, Can Last Until December
DOC.TEXT: Diplomats under siege at the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait have found a new source of water and may be able to hold out until some time in December, President Bush said today. Bush said the water source was being purified for drinking, but he did not elaborate. Until now, the diplomats drank purified swimming pool water and bottled liquids. Iraq cut off water and electricity to all embassies in Kuwait in late August, ordering them to shut down. All diplomats have left except for eight Americans, two Britons and some Arab representatives. The diplomats have been living off canned food supplies and fresh dates, and were not expected to hold out beyond November. ``In terms of how long the people can last, I don't know the answer to that,'' Bush told reporters at the U.S. ambassador's residence following an international summit. ``It has been pushed back to something in December,'' he added, before departing for a visit to Saudi Arabia and Egypt. The 10th anti-Iraq resolution adopted earlier this month by the U.N. Security Council calls for the Secretary General to find ways to resupply the beleaguered embassies. But he has yet to announce how he plans to do so. In late October, Secretary of State James Baker announced the diplomats had dug a shallow well in the compound. He said they were using the water to tend a vegetable garden and to thumb their nose at the Iraqi troops ringing the compound by washing the embassy cars. The U.S. compound shelters Ambassador W. Nathaniel Howe, a staff of seven and 19 American citizens who have taken refuge there. ``There is an attempt by Saddam Hussein to starve them out,'' Bush said.

DOC.HEAD: Second Cave-In at D.C. Construction Site Disrupts Businesses, Traffic
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New thruout with cave-in stabilized, utility crews still working to restore service; no pickup; Michel is CQ in 3rd graf
DOC.TEXT: A construction site cave-in four blocks from the White House was stabilized early today as utility crews worked to restore telephone and electrical services. A 100-foot-long section of sidewalk and part of a downtown street slid into the 4-story-deep hole Tuesday as workers tried to shore up the construction site from the initial collapse Monday night. No injuries were reported. Workers at United Press International were allowed back in their headquarters today, but telephone company spokesman Michel Daley said full service would not be restored until later in the day. The news agency abandoned its headquarters adjacent to the scene of the collapse Monday night, but the news service continued to operate with help from a rival agency, Reuters, and from National Public Radio. Even though the site was stabilized, more dirt will be dumped, according to Vincent Ford, District of Columbia chief building inspector. Ford said he did not expect any further ground movement. Daley said Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Co. crews were working to repair a cable that was severed in the collapse. About 70 percent of the circuits were expected to be restored by early afternoon, Daley said. ``We're literally running cables through windows to get services restored on a temporary basis,'' Daley said. If the cave-in spreads any further, it could cut electric lines supplying power to surrounding office buildings, said Bill Gausman, construction manager for the Potomac Electric Power Co. The utility urged customers to curtail power usage. The area around the half-block-square construction project is being blocked off to traffic while crews dump dirt into the site. Workers ``are going to be at it for days,'' said Charles Culver, director of construction and engineering for the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, which is investigating the accident. Schal Mid-Atlantic Inc. had planned an office building at the location. UPI will operate from temporary quarters until at least Thanksgiving, according to spokesman Milt Capps. ``We urgently need our telephone service restored if we are going to deliver quality service over the holiday period,'' Capps said. He described morale as ``grim'' but added there was also a ``foxhole camaraderie'' among employees. UPI staff members who are members of the Wire Service Guild voted last Friday to accept a 90-day, 35 percent pay cut the company said was needed to stave off financial insolvency and make it mre attractive to potential buyers. Management employees took the same cut earlier. Capps said Reuters was helping UPI distribute photographs to its clients and that National Public Radio was helping maintain its broadcast and audio network services. UPI was operating out of several locations, including the Senate press gallery at the Capitol. ``We're prepared to continue operations over here indefinitely,'' UPI's executive editor, Al Rossiter Jr., said from a company facility in a Virginia suburb. UPI was unable to serve many Washington-area clients, mainly federal agencies. The news service delivers stories to those customers over telephone lines that were cut in the cave-in, said Washington bureau chief Berl Schwartz.

DOC.HEAD: Freed Iranian POWs Arrive Home From Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th pvs, `Some 79...' to RESTORE dropped word. Pickup 5th pvs, `The agency...'
DOC.TEXT: More than 200 freed Iranian prisoners of war arrived home from Iraq today in the first prisoner exchange by the two countries in two months, the official media reported. The Islamic Repubic News Agency said the freed men kissed the ground on arrival, crying for joy and chanting ``Allahu Akbar!'' or God is great. Tehran radio said the 238 former POWs arrived at the capital's Mehrabad Airport and were warmly greeted by military and political figures. Some 79 Iraqis taken prisoner during the eight-year Iran-Iraq war were also sent home by air in the first prisoner exchange in two months, the official Islamic News agency said. The agency said the Iraqis had been convicted of crimes but were later pardoned by Iran. It did not specify the nature of the crimes. Another 200 Iraqis were scheduled to be repatriated Thursday. The exchanges started in mid-August after Iraqi President Saddam Hussein abruptly agreed to all Iran's conditions for a formal peace treaty, including the exchange of prisoners. He was apparently seeking peace on his eastern border while trying to consolidate his hold over Kuwait. Iran has strongly condemned the Aug. 2 invasion of the emirate. Iraq suspended the prisoner exchanges without explanation on Sept. 20, after 37,000 men had been exchanged. The International Committee of the Red Cross said 25,000 men still remain interned, without giving a breakdown. But a visit by Iranian Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati to Baghdad last week, the highest official from Iran to visit Iraq since the 1979 Islamic revolution, got the exchanges going again. Iraq said earlier that all the prisoners to be released today were convicted of crimes such as murder and assault after they were interned in camps during the 1980-1988 war. IRNA, in its report, said: ``A freed POW, while weeping bitterly, said a great grief breaking their hearts was the passing away of Imam Khomeini.'' Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the personification of Iran's 1979 Islamic revolution, died in June 1989, almost a year after a cease-fire in the Gulf War.

DOC.HEAD: County Officials Stymied By 5-Way Election Tie
DOC.TEXT: It's still neck and neck - and neck and neck and neck - in what was a four-way tie for one seat on the newly created Franklin County Charter Commission. Now there's a fifth person in the tie for the District 3 seat. Each got one write-in vote on the Nov. 6 ballot, which listed no candidate for the post. The ballot boxes, which had been sealed since the election, were opened Tuesday by county officials hoping to resolve the tie. Instead they turned up the fifth write-in. ``We've never had this happen before,'' said Gladys Hanley, chairwoman of the county Board of Registrars. ``We don't know what to do.'' The board plans to ask state election officials what to do. To further complicate things, one of the candidates already has been elected to the Charter Commission as an at-large delegate and another is tied with two other candidates for another at-large seat.

DOC.HEAD: Payment Offer Lured Lebanese Heroin Figures to U.S.: Prosecutor
DOC.NOTE: EDS: CORRECTS 5th graf bgng, `Among the,' to identify Kamal Charif as a former employee of Lebanese parliament, not former state senator
DOC.TEXT: Federal drug agents lured reputed Lebanese heroin producers and traffickers to the United States with the promise of payment for previous drug shipments in order to arrest the ring's leaders, a prosecutor says. ``We were able to arrange for all of the key players to be present in the United States during a two-week period,'' said Henry E. Hudson, U.S. attorney for the Eastern District of Virginia. ``They came here to collect money for previous transactions,'' he said Tuesday, adding, ``We're talking several hundred thousand dollars.'' The results were the arrests of 22 people in five states and the District of Columbia, including nine people who normally reside in Lebanon but were enticed to the Washington area, officials said. Among the Lebanese residents arrested were Kamal Charif, identified by officials as a former employee of the Lebanese parliament, and his son, Wadgy Charif. Wadgy Charif told undercover Drug Enforcement Administration agent Hollis Williams and a DEA informant on Aug. 2, 1989 that his father ``owned and operated one of the largest heroin processing facilities in the Bekaa Valley, and could supply ... Williams with large quantities of heroin,'' Williams said in an affidavit. Kamal Charif came to the United States not only to pick up money but also ``to negotiate with our agents to supply 50 kilograms (110 pounds) a month to supply what he thought was a heroin network,'' Hudson said in an interview. The 16-month undercover case, dubbed ``Operation Helix,'' began with the August 1989 meeting at the Four Seasons restaurant in Alexandria, Va., and involved purchases or arrangements to purchase numerous multi-kilogram quantities of heroin at about $40,000 apiece, Williams' affidavit said. It also led to the seizure of 25 kilograms of extremely pure heroin, Hudson said. ``It's possible that the arrests could have been delayed so we could have seized more heroin, but we might have lost a couple of the key players,'' the prosecutor said. ``This organization is probably one of the largest importers of heroin on the East Coast of the United States, responsible for supplying significant quantities into the Washington metropolitan area as well as into New York and Detroit,'' Hudson said. The organization was ``responsible for the importation of hundreds of kilograms of relatively pure southwest Asian heroin into the United States, Europe and Canada,'' a Justice Department statement said. Of the 22 people arrested, 18 were charged with conspiracy to distribute heroin, a charge that carries a possible sentence of life without parole, as well as immigration violations. The other four are charged only with immigration violations. Fifteen of the 22 were seized in Washington, D.C., or northern Virginia; three in Detroit; two in New Jersey and one each in Toledo, Ohio; and Miami. The investigation is expected to lead to nine more arrests, including one in Germany, said an official familiar with the case. The heroin came from the Syrian-controlled Bekaa Valley. The newfound cooperation between the United States and Syria due to their alliance against Iraq has not extended to drug control efforts, according to the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``The Syrians aren't helping us,'' the official said. ``If anything, they are hindering us.'' The State Department's International Narcotics Control Strategy Report, issued last March, said, ``We believe that Syria tolerates and profits from the drug production and trafficking in the areas over which it exercises control.'' This view was supported by one of the people arrested, Michel Rebeiz, who told DEA agent Williams that ``the Syrian police were now running the airport and asking $10,000 per kilogram to allow heroin through the checkpoints,'' according to Williams' affidavit. The State Department report said Lebanese production of opium - the raw ingredient for heroin - increased significantly last year to as much as 45 metric tons. During that year, the U.S. officials believe Lebanon produced as much as 6.5 metric tons of heroin, with 4.5 metric tons coming from locally grown opium and the rest from opiates imported from Afghanistan, Iran and Pakistan. The heroin involved in ``Operation Helix'' was shipped through Cyprus, Western Europe and then to the United States, said DEA spokesman Cornelius Dougherty.

DOC.HEAD: Pima County Votes to Give Employees Time Off to Honor King
DOC.TEXT: TUCSON, Ariz. AP) - One Arizona county's employees will get a paid day off in January in honor of Martin Luther King Jr. despite voters' rejection of a state holiday honoring the civil rights leader. The Pima County Board of Supervisors on Tuesday unanimously voted to give county employees eight hours of paid administrative leave to be taken on either the third Monday of January or the Friday before it. Supervisor Raul Grijalva said he hopes the Maricopa County Board of Supervisors in Phoenix will follow his board's example so ``that will push the Legislature to either do something themselves, or put it back on the ballot for voters to decide.'' Voters in the state's general election on Nov. 6 rejected two propositions that would have created a paid state holiday honoring King. A majority of Pima County voters supported creating a King holiday. The county includes the city of Tucson, which has a King Day.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Assad Said Due In Geneva
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with meeting Friday, background; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Syrian leader Hafez Assad are expected Friday in Geneva for an apparent meeting, airport sources said today. The sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said they had no further details on the visit by the two presidents to the Swiss city. Bush would be on his way back from a Thanksgiving visit to U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia - the first by an American president to front-line forces since Richard Nixon in 1969. Syrian troops are part of the 350,000-strong multinational force massed against Iraq in the Persian Gulf since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. The U.S. and Syrian diplomatic missions to the United Nations in Geneva had no immediate comment. Washington's relations with Damascus, strained for many years over Syria's support for international terrorism and its hard-line positions against Israel, have warmed since the Syrians joined the anti-Iraq coalition.

DOC.HEAD: Latest Developments in the Gulf Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief look at the latest developments in the Persian Gulf: --- Mikhail S. Gorbachev says the U.N. Security Council should meet to address a ``very dangerous'' situation in the Persian Gulf ``and take a decision there.'' Speaking after a meeting with Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, Gorbachev said: ``We can't just leave things this way without giving them closer analysis.'' The Soviet leader did not elaborate on what any U.N. Security Council meeting might discuss, or what any solution might involve. --- Iraq, meanwhile, promised to free 157 more Europeans it is holding, Western officials said. Hostages to be released over the next days included Britons, Italians, Germans, Irish, Dutch, Danes, Belgians, Portuguese and Greeks. Many Western officials have said Saddam Hussein's policy of releasing hostages gradually is designed to break the world alliance against Iraq. --- Speaking in Paris, where he attended a European Security summit, President Bush said he and Gorbachev see ``eye to eye'' on the gulf crisis and any differences between them were ``very minor.'' Bush left Paris for the Middle East, where he was to meet with Arab officials and spend thanksgiving with U.S. troops in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia. --- It looks like virtually all 230,000 Americans deployed in the gulf will be eating fresh turkey with all the trimmings on Thanksgiving Day. But just in case, the U.S. military says it has 600,000 prepackaged turkey dinners stashed in a warehouse. --- Airport sources in Geneva said Bush and Syrian leader Hafez Assad were expected Friday in Geneva for a meeting. The sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said they had no further details on the visit by the two presidents to the Swiss city. Syrian troops are part of the 350,000-strong multinational force massed against Iraq in the gulf.

DOC.HEAD: `Shogun, The Musical' Opens on Broadway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS other critics at end.
DOC.TEXT: ``Shogun, The Musical'' certainly has the spectacle. What it needs is a coherent story, a few good songs and a couple of characters you could care about. All are missing from this big, beached whale of a show that floated belly up into Broadway's Marquis Theater on Tuesday night. The premiere was postponed several days after the leading man, Philip Casnoff, was bonked by a piece of falling scenery during a preview performance Nov. 13. It's amazing Casnoff wasn't hurt before. The show opens with a shipwreck - a rather nifty maritime catastrophe done with an honest-to-goodness ship, laser beams and some black-clad sea sprites pulling billowing sheets of cloth. The musical also has an earthquake and several big battle scenes, including one striking chorus line of warriors on horseback. They are not enough. Although ``Shogun'' has the technical expertise of recent big British musical blockbusters, it doesn't have the emotional sweep of ``Les Miserables'' or the sense of romance and fun found in ``The Phantom of the Opera.'' Director Michael Smuin has mastered the wizardry of modern stage technology but he can't do much with a baffling narrative and pedestrian music and lyrics. The musical is based on James Clavell's mammoth novel of 17th-century Japan. The book is so detailed and complicated - the paperback version runs more than 1,200 pages - that any adaptation is bound to be more outline than story. Even so, the producers have included a two-page plot synopsis and a glossary of Japanese phrases that still don't make the tale completely accessible. ``Shogun'' concerns an Englishman, John Blackthorne, shipwrecked on the Japanese coast. He gets involved with several warlords, a conniving Portuguese Jesuit and, most significantly, the lovely Lady Mariko, who happens to be married to a nobleman. You know there will be trouble. ``Shogun'' takes itself very seriously. The characters don't talk. They proclaim. When they are not proclaiming, they are explaining the plot. Adapter John Driver uses several of the main characters to summarize what is going on. It's like listening to Cliffs Notes read out loud. When they are not explaining, the performers are singing composer Paul Chihara's wallpaper-thin music, melodies that linger no longer than the time it takes to sing them. The music and lyrics, which are by Driver, often seem unnecessary, stopping the plot rather than advancing it and, more important, in the love songs, failing to forge the bond between Blackthorne and Mariko. Instead, these love songs are so generic - particularly an often repeated number called ``Born to Be Together'' - that they probably could be dropped into any musical and work OK. The cast doesn't let the weak material stop them. Casnoff is personable, a handsome leading man who sings with authority and even seems to have a sense of humor. June Angela as the doomed Mariko is striking, a lovely singer who throws herself into the show with even more conviction. The rotund Francis Ruivivar, as the good warlord, is stuck with a character who alternates between buffoon and nobleman. He also has one of the show's more pointless songs, ``Rum Below,'' in which Blackthorne teaches the would-be shogun to dance a jig. But the show's campiest moment occurs early in the second act when the geishas sing about Oriental sexual toys. Truly embarrassing. The costumes by Patricia Zipprodt are extraordinary, an endless display of patterned silks and brocades as well as a parade of armor for scores of warriors. No one seems to wear the same outfit twice. Loren Sherman's settings are equally lavish, particularly the richly decorated, dark-hued Osaka Castle, lair of the evil Lord Ishido. The lighting by Natasha Katz beautifully shows off the settings and the costumes. But these design achievements can't really mask the thinness of what we're seeing and hearing on stage. ``Shogun, The Musical'' can occasionally dazzle the eye but it never touches the heart and mind. What other critics said: Frank Rich in The New York Times said Casnoff's accident with the scenery may have been ``the biggest break of his career'' because his performance after his recovery ``had the swaggering self-assurance of a star in complete command of a vast production.'' Clive Barnes in the New York Post said the show ``is as unremittingly serious as triviality can ever hope to be. ... The book is unwieldy and the lyrics banal,'' he said. Linda Winer in Newsday said: ``'Shogun' is drivel, but it's not inept drivel. Without Cameron Mackintosh and his pre-sold international marketing machine behind it, however, the show will need all the karma it can get.''

DOC.HEAD: Baghdad To Release 157 More Europeans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with six grafs to UPDATE with Muhammad Ali leaving for Baghdad, ADDS background on Le Pen; Pickup 6th pvs, `He said...'
DOC.TEXT: The government has agreed to free at least 157 more Europeans stranded in Iraq and occupied Kuwait, Western officials said today. The announcement came a day after Iraq's Parliament voted to free all Germans. The Bush administration, seeking global support for a U.N. resolution to wage war on Iraq, has called the Baghdad government's piecemeal releases of hostages an attempt to divide the coalition arrayed against Saddam Hussein. There is general agreement among coalition members that the U.N.-ordered embargo on trade with Iraq is far from achieving its desired goal of forcing Saddam out of Kuwait, which his forces seized on Aug. 2. Heavyweight boxing great Muhammad Ali left Amman for Baghdad today for talks with Saddam on the gulf crisis. Ali was accompanied by two associates and two members of the Coalition to Stop U.S. Intervention in the Middle East. French right-wing politician Jean Marie Le Pen, in Baghdad since Sunday, will take 83 European hostages to Strasbourg, seat of the European Parliament, a member of his delegation said. Le Pen is a member of the European Parliament, which is scheduled to discuss the gulf crisis on Thursday. The delegation member, speaking on condition of anonymity, said those leaving Thursday would be 35 Britons, 15 Italians, 15 Germans, six Irish, five Dutch, three Danes, 2 Belgians, a Portuguese and a Greek. He said two others who held French passports but were not full French citizens would fly out. He would not elaborate. The head of a Swiss parliamentary delegation said today that 36 hostages would leave Thursday afternoon on a Swissair charter flight to Zurich. Edgar Oehler, a Christian Democrat member of Parliament, told a news conference that those allowed to leave include 16 Swiss, four Irish and two Britons. Also today, the head of personnel for foreign workers at Ibn al-Bitar Hospital said 38 mostly Irish staff members would be allowed to leave. The group includes 2 Britons and a Dane, said Gerry Fitzgerald. It was unclear when the workers' contracts had already expired. The Iraqi government has previously blocked some workers from leaving even if their contracts were fulfilled. It was not immediately known when that group would be allowed to leave. Iraq's parliament voted Tuesday night to release all the German hostages in response to recent statements by German Chancellor Helmut Kohl stressing the need for a peaceful solution to the Persian Gulf crisis. Iraq's parliament speaker, Saadi Mahdi Saleh, said there were 124 Germans still in Iraq and Kuwait. No specific arrangements were made for their departure. Germany says there are about 180 of its citizens still in Iraq. The Germans were among the 600 people including Americans, Britons and Japanese held at strategic sites to deter an attack by the multinational forces gathered in the gulf to try to force Iraq out of Kuwait. About 2,000 Westerners are believed hiding in Kuwait. Earlier this week Iraq said all foreigners would be set free between Dec. 25 and March 25, but Information Minister Latif Nassiyif Jassim indicated Monday that some might be allowed to leave earlier. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, in Paris with President Bush for a European security cummit, said Baghdad's moves to free hostages gradually was another effort to chisel away international solidarity against Iraq. ``Our answer is simply, `Sorry, it won't work,''' said Fitzwater on Tuesday. The Iraqi promise to free all foreigners came after the Bush administration announced last week that 200,000 more U.S. troops would be sent to the region to place the 350,000-strong multinational force on an offensive footing.

DOC.HEAD: Precede NEW DELHI
Procession for Victims of Market Massacre Turns Violent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with violence during funeral procession. Pickup 6th pvs, `At least ...
DOC.TEXT: Hindus mourning victims of a massacre by Sikh separatists attacked a bus station today and assaulted Sikhs, witnesses and police said. A four-hour curfew was imposed in some sections of Amritsar following the violence, which injured at least two Sikhs. Some of the Hindus were armed with swords and sticks, United News of India reported. At least 11 Hindus and two Sikhs were killed in a crowded market on Tuesday evening when masked Sikh gunmen opened fire. Four militants, suspected to be among the assailants, were killed by police a few hours later. Amritsar police chief Sanjeev Gupta said the mourners burned two government buses when the funeral procession passed a bus station on the way to a cremation ground. Sikh employees at the bus station retaliated by throwing stones, said Gupta. The curfew was lifted after the victims of the attack were cremated under police guard. Tuesday's attack in Amritsar, 250 miles northwest of New Delhi, was the latest in a series of killings by separatists in strife-torn Punjab state. Gupta was quoted by the news agency as saying the weapons recovered from the slain radicals Tuesday matched spent bullets found at the scene of the market shooting. Witnesses had said they saw at least five masked gunmen during the attack. It was not immediately clear if only four were involved or if one had escaped. At least 120 people have died since Nov. 13. Victims have included passengers pulled out of a bus and shot, people on morning walks and members of security forces. Sikhs comprise just 2 percent of India's 880 million people but are in a majority in Punjab, a rich farming state which borders Pakistan. Sikh militants have been campaigning for independence since 1982, claiming their community is discriminated against by the Hindus, who make up 82 percent of the country's population. At least 2,860 people have been killed in Punjab this year in violence blamed on the militants.

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin Says Latest Gorbachev Proposals Not Logical
LaserPhoto MOSB1
DOC.TEXT: Boris N. Yeltsin today criticized Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plans to strengthen the executive branch of government as illogical and hastily prepared. Yeltsin, president of largest Soviet republic, said Russia could not be forced into signing Gorbachev's proposed Union Treaty, which would redefine the relationship between the 15 republics and the national government. The treaty would be signed only if Russia's ``real sovereignty'' would be assured and if issues are resolved over the ownership of the vast republic's bounty of gold, diamonds, oil, gas and other natural resources, said Yeltsin, Gorbachev's frequent critic and main political rival. Gorbachev on Saturday proposed dumping his embattled prime minister, Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, and revamping the executive branch to put it entirely under presidential control. The Supreme Soviet legislature gave the proposals initial approval, but is expected to consider them further Friday. The Soviet leader made the proposals after the Supreme Soviet urged him to resolve a building political crisis that was paralyzing efforts at reforming the nation's economy. Most of the 15 Soviet republics, including Russia, have declared some form of sovereignty, pushing for local control over their own economies, political structures and culture. This has resulted in political confrontations with the central government over which directives should be carried out or ignored. Yeltsin, speaking to reporters at the opening of a historical exhibition at the Russian republic's headquarters, said Gorbachev's proposed strengthening of the national presidency seemed to be ``prepared in a hurry, probably as a result of the debates in the Supreme Soviet, or prompted by the staff of the Supreme Soviet or presidential aides.'' ``But they are not exactly logical, not quite consistent, for one thing, and for another such things should be discussed and adopted taking into account the will of the republics,'' he said, without elaboration. Yeltsin, who on Monday urged a referendum on the entire presidential system and the government's performance, said today that a decision on such a vote hasn't been made and he would not predict one. Asked if Gorbachev's reputation or credibility are helped by the proposal to strengthen his presidential powers, Yeltsin replied: ``It was my impression from the stormy meetings in the Ukraine, where I spent only one day, that no, it doesn't.'' Yeltsin was in the Ukraine earlier this week to sign a treaty on relations between that republic and the Russian republic.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Department Says Oil Company Profits Increased Slightly
DOC.TEXT: Profits for major oil companies increased by less than 2 percent in the months immediately after the Persian Gulf crisis, and most benefits from higher prices went to oil-producing countries, the Energy Department reported today. A report by the Energy Information Administration said higher crude oil prices ``led to substantial increases in income from oil and gas production,'' but the beneficiaries often were foreign governments. Income for oil-producing countries, as well as for domestic producers, soared in the third quarter by 684 percent, compared to the same three-month period in 1989, the report said. But for the most part, the benefit did not pass on to many of the oil companies, the study reported. ``For the major petroleum companies, increased profits from oil and gas production were nearly offset by reduced earnings from refining, marketing and chemical businesses,'' said the report. The net income for major U.S. oil companies was l.7 percent overall, the report said. Companies that had to buy crude oil and petroleum products at the higher prices reported profit declines, the report said. Some refineries reported sharp increases in profits, however. The report said that the net income for independent refiners increased 130 percent in the 3rd quarter compared to the same period a year earlier. Profits from integrated refinery operations at the major oil companies were mixed. Five companies reported profit increases up to 46 percent, while six reported decreases of up to 83 percent, the report said. ``Due to retail price restraint, U.S. companies who had to purchase oil to process at higher prices, saw their income decline,'' said the report. The report provided no information on specific companies. Its analysis covered the month of July through September. Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, leading to an embargo of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil and a shortfall of world oil supplies by 4.3 million barrels, prompting prices to soar. Spot crude oil prices, which were about $21 a barrel before the invasion peaked at $41 a barrel in October before declining to about $34 a barrel in early November.

Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers in the United States and abroad. --- Nov. 16 Roswell (N.M.) Daily Record on the president's need to build support before taking offensive action in the Persian Gulf: President Bush's decision to significantly expand American force levels in the Persian Gulf and cancel troop rotation orders sends a resolute signal he is ready to go to war to liberate Kuwait. Yet it is far from certain that, in the event of bloodshed on a massive scale, Mr. Bush would be able to count on the sustained backing of the American people and the rest of the world. Mr. Bush must clearly spell out America's aims and articulate why the defeat of Saddam Hussein on the battlefield is vital to U.S. interests. Otherwise, Americans may not be willing to make the heavy sacrifices that a war almost certainly would impose. Much more is at stake in the Persian Gulf than low cost gasoline. The strategic reality is that unless Saddam's aggression is checked once and for all, the economic security of the entire industrialized world will be in jeopardy. ... --- Nov. 16 The Ledger, Lakeland, Fla., on the congressional role in the Gulf crisis: President Bush, as commander in chief of the military, has every right and obligation to prepare the troops for war. He acted wisely by rapidly deploying U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf to contain Iraqi aggression. Containment of Saddam Hussein is certainly in the best interest of the United States. The president should not, however, slowly draw the United States into war with Iraq without first building a consensus among the American people. Congress, in fact, should no let Bush do it. Congress has neglected its duties by putting off hearings on the military buildup in the Middle East, the economic and human costs of war, the strategic benefits and risks, and whether or not war is necessary. --- Nov. 19 Los Angeles Times on hostage family visits to Iraq: The somewhat ghoulish invitation of President Saddam Hussein to ``come visit Iraq,'' as it were, presents the loved ones of hostages being held there with a difficult dilemma. It's not surprising that some of them are reacting emotionally. It's also not surprising that some plan to go. ... Clearly, the Iraqis hope to milk these visits for all the propaganda value they are worth. Hussein seems to think the world will see Iraq as a kinder, gentler place - and as a country with which it is possible to do business. It probably doesn't occur to Hussein that these visits, as well as his latest offer to free all ``guests'' by March, only remind everyone of Iraq's cruel hostage-taking policy. ... It could be that the sight of loved ones in Baghdad for the holidays will actually aid U.S. policy by starching up the anti-Hussein coalition and reminding people of the grisly nature of his dictatorship. ... But even if the visits have an effect close to what Saddam Hussein probably wants, it is still right that they be permitted to occur. In Western political philosophy, individuals do count; the role and desires of just one person have importance. ... --- Nov. 16 The Columbus (Ohio) Dispatch on election results: Committed political junkies, those who like to pick over the bones of an election until they are absolutely clean, must have noticed by now that the voting last week propelled a bumper crop of women into office. And political strategists said the stage has been set for a greater share of female victories in 1992. In the coming years, there will be an increasingly large number of women working as lawyers, doctors, engineers and in other professional capacities. No reason, then, that there shouldn't be more women politicians, too. ... This year the Center for the American Woman and Politics reported 2,063 female candidates in the field. These candidates are expected to increase the share of state legislative offices held by women to about 18 percent. Ask the average person what kind of job he or she thinks politicians are doing and the answer might well be unprintable. With more women in the field, maybe that will change. ---
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: will change.
DOC.TEXT: Nov. 15 The Flint (Mich.) Journal on homelessness: Soon the last vestiges of Indian summer will vanish. ... And thus inside our homes, shut off from the snow and cold, we will breathe in the fine aroma of well-cooked meals. ... There's nothing quite like home sweet home. But, sadly, for a growing number of Americans, young and old, no such place exists. They have no home, no fireplace, no closet, no oven - not even a bed to call their own. For them, home is a box or a tent or a car or an abandoned home - or for short periods, shelters. ... With the U.S. economy sliding ever deeper in recession, millions more are teetering on the edge of homelessness. Some of these people are as ordinary as our friends or neighbors. All they need is a good paying job and a couple of breaks to return them to their feet. Others are people whose lives have been torn for any of a wide variety of reasons, including problems they inflicted upon themselves. Still, they are people - brothers and sisters in this special relationship we call humanity. As a society, we must do a much better job of creating public, private and charitable strategies to address this complicated problem. ... But as a civilized people, as a caring people, we cannot wait for these strategies to be implemented and succeed. We must do what we can now as individuals to help those in need all around us. And so we urge you to help area shelters and food banks. Donate what you can and volunteer your time. ... --- Nov. 16 The Kenosha (Wis.) News on the airline industry's woes: One of the first economic sectors to suffer the effects of the dawning recession is the airline industry. Thanks to Saddam Hussein, the price of jet fuel has risen 70 percent since early August. More than 10,000 airline employees have been laid off; ridership is down and likely to fall further; yearly losses are estimated at a record $1 billion. Some well-known carriers teeter on the brink of bankruptcy. So in its new budget, Congress did to this essential industry what Congress does best: It raised the industry's taxes and user fees almost $14 billion. Congress blithely assumed that these costs could be passed on to consumers, but the industry says competitive pressures, combined with the general weakness of air-travel business, make this impossible. Industry leaders have gone to Transportation Secretary Sam Skinner seeking relief, perhaps by relaxing rules on foreign investment or delaying ticket taxes. They're entitled to it - and not in the name of some ``industrial policy,'' in which the government manipulates the market to help favored industries. At this critical moment, the airline industry, and the millions of consumers who depend on it, don't need government protection; they need protection from government. --- Nov. 16 The Westerly (R.I.) Sun on Willie Nelson: Willie Nelson is broke. The ``revenooers'' from Washington have swooped down on Willie to the tune of $16.7 million they say he owes Uncle Sam in back taxes. Now Willie is really a nice guy. He was the country music star who back awhile staged those concerts that raised funds to help struggling farmers stave off foreclosure and bankruptcies. ... But fortunately, he has friends. And one of them, Annetta White, ... has a solution to Willie's problem: We should all send a dollar to ``Willie Aid'' and with those dollars, Willie, she says, could pay off those troublesome tax men. Now if we all do as Annetta suggests, it's a safe bet Willie would find his present stay in Hawaii a bit more relaxing, And when you millions of Americans send those dollar bills, don't forget Jimmy Swaggart and Jim Bakker. ---
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: Jim Bakker.
DOC.TEXT: Nov. 15 The Times of India on Japan: Important winds of change are blowing over Japan today. With the accession to the throne of the new emperor, Akihito, the resurgence of Japanese militarism, which historically has been associated with royalist rule, has again become an issue. ... Mr. Kaifu favours the participation of a Japanese military contingent in the Gulf alongside Western partners. He has been pressured to adopt this view by the U.S. But it is clear that Tokyo itself has fewer reservations than ever before about flexing its long-dormant military muscle. ... Just as Emperor Akihito's accession to what is seen as divine status is a generational change at the apex, it may be only a short while before a new Japanese generation, with only faint memories of World War II or the earlier inter-war period, feels that the resurgence of Japanese militarism is but the ``natural'' complement of its exceptional economic might. --- Nov. 14 The Herald of Harare, Zimbabwe, on the Gulf crisis: War is now inevitable in the Persian Gulf, if only because the foreign forces have to seek justification for having been deployed there in the first place. President George Bush, whose country already has the largest single foreign force in the Gulf, has just ordered a further build-up. ... Two weeks ago the Americans and the Saudis streamlined the chain of command of their forces should war break out with Iraq. Many saw this as one more step in the direction of armed confrontation. The American administration is under severe pressure at home to do something now before the all too familiar campaign to ``bring our boys back home'' gains momentum. Mr. Bush, smarting from a midterm election disaster, now has the time to devote his energy to the Gulf crisis. But he and President Saddam Hussein, more than anybody else, have burned their bridges in a diplomatic game whose end result has all the potential for a devastating conflict. --- Nov. 16 El Pais of Madrid on the first anniversary of the murder of Jesuit priests in El Salvador: ... The military chiefs who planned and ordered the action don't even appear as suspects. The judge handling the case has been and remains incapable of sitting all those responsible in the dock. The blame lies with, among others, the government of the extreme rightist President Alfredo Cristiani which, far from fulfilling its promise to solve the crime, has dragged its feet and even put stumbling blocks in the way of the judicial investigation. The scandal is of such magnitude that the government of the United States has reduced its military aid to El Salvador by 50 percent. Other governments, like the government of Spain - less able to impose material sanctions - have put considerable moral pressure on the Central American nation. Without much success, either. In the end, it is not so much a question of finding and punishing those guilty of a repulsive crime as it is of a country demonstrating that it is capable of functioning like a civilized society that follows the rule of law. ... --- Nov. 19 Financial Times of London on the Soviet Union: The Soviet crisis deepens by the day. ... Hunger, possibly famine, is facing the Soviet Union as the snows of winter cover fields of rotting crops. ... Oil production is falling sharply and the problem of delivering oil and gas is compounded by disintegrating pipelines and a chaotic transport system. ... What we are witnessing is the accelerating collapse of political and economic structures. This is happening in a country where the destruction of civil society over 70 years has fatally weakened the country's capacity to react creatively to the new freedoms suddenly granted it. ... All that is clear at this stage is that the transition from communism is going to be much longer, much harder and much more expensive than imagined over a year ago. To achieve it peacefully could cost the West as much effort and treasure as the cold war whose demise we celebrate in Paris this week. This is the probable scale of the challenge ahead.
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Rdp
Afghan President Meets With Afghan Resistance in Geneva
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet-backed Afghan president said today he met in Geneva with leaders of the U.S.-financed Afghan resistance and the talks opened the way for restoring peace to his country after 12 years of civil war. President Najibullah told reporters at U.N. headquarters in Geneva that he had been satisfied with the talks on a possible political solution to the Afghan conflict. ``A cornerstone has been laid for opening talks and dialogue and for advancing the process as well as the implementation of the peace process,'' Najibullah said. ``No doubt it will bear fruit.'' Najibullah later left for the Swiss capital in Bern where he was to meet with Swiss legislators. One deputy, Gilles Petitpierre, said plans for an Afghanistan peace conference hosted by Switzerland was a likely topic. At a news conference, Najibullah did not say when the talks took place. He also declined to identify the Afghan resistance leaders with whom he met, saying only they were ``prominent personalities of the opposition side.'' Some observers speculated that Najibullah met in Geneva with Pir Sayed Ahmed Gailani, leader of the National Islamic Front - the most moderate of the seven Afghan rebel groups allied against the Communist Afghan government. Najibullah said conditions for a political solution were favorable. He said his government had embarked on a democratic course - providing for party pluralism, a free press and government reforms. He said diminished tensions between the United States and the Soviet Union also could contribute to the peace process. The Soviet Union sent troops to Afghanistan in 1979 to shore up that country's gpvermment. Ten years later, the last of the Red Army soldiers withdrew under a 1988 Geneva accord - also signed by the United States. Moscow continues to send aid to Kabul. Washington supports the the Pakistan-based guerrillas, who have kept on fighting Najibullah but not managed to topple him.

DOC.HEAD: Tass Reports Two Killed in Clash
DOC.TEXT: Two Azerbaijanis have been killed in a disputed southern territory, triggering clashes between Soviet Interior Ministry troops and Armenian nationalists that injured several people, Tass said today. One Soviet soldier also was abducted during the clashes Tuesday night in Nagorno-Karabakh. It began in the late afternoon and continued for several hours, the official Soviet news agency said. Tass said unknown gunmen killed the Azerbaijanis near the village of Zabukh, in Nagorno-Karabakh, but it gave no other details. Twenty Soviet troops were dispatched to the scene, and immediately came under fire fromy what Tass called ``an 80-man group of Armenian terrorists.'' Authorities dispatched 20 more troops as reinforcements, and a firefight continued until nightfall, Tass said. ``The attackers suffered casualties. One serviceman was abducted,'' Tass reported without elaboration. Armenians and Azerbaijanis have been clashing for nearly three years over control of the predominantly Armenian region lying within Azerbaijan. Armenia has demanded control, but Azerbaijan has refused, prompting strikes, boycotts and violence that has killed a number of people. Interior Ministry troops have been dispatched to maintain order.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
NEW YORK: friends and supporters.
DOC.TEXT: Wood said Milken's misuse of his leadership position constituted ``serious crimes warranting serious punishment and the discomfort of being removed from society.'' She said Milken was a man of ``talent and industry'' but that a long prison term was required to send a message to other possible securities-law violators. The judge said she considered evidence of additional crimes, including obstruction of justice by Milken in handing down the sentence. He was ordered to surrender to U.S. marshals March 4, 1991. No federal prison was designated.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Heading to Saudi Arabia for Visit With U.S. Troops
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs grafs 4-5 to show formal announcement of Assad meeting
DOC.TEXT: President Bush headed to the Persian Gulf today, saying he will tell U.S. troops they are ``not there on a mission impossible'' and declaring the Soviets support his tough stand against Iraq's Saddam Hussein. Departing a European security summit for a Thanksgiving Day visit with U.S. forces in the Middle East, Bush said any differences with the Soviet Union on the Persian Gulf are ``extraordinarily minor.' He said he and Gorbachev see ``eye to eye'' on the subject despite the Soviet leader's reluctance to issue a public declaration of support for a United Nations resolution authorizing the use of force to evict Iraq's occupying forces. Bush was en route to Saudi Arabia when the White House announced he would return to Europe on Friday to meet with Syrian President Hafez Assad. The meeting in Geneva will center on the Persian Gulf. Relations with Syria, a hardline Arab state considered by the State Department to be a sponsor of international terrorism, have warmed since it joined the U.S.-led coalition against Iraq last August. Bush spoke in Paris just before the Soviet leader issued a call for an immediate meeting of the United Nations Security Council to address a ``very dangerous'' situation in the Persian Gulf ``and take a decision there.'' ``We can't just leave things this way without giving them closer analysis,'' the Soviet leader added. Asked if the U.N. might act this month, Bush said, ``Stay tuned. There's certainly a chance.'' Bush's first stop in the Middle East was in Jiddah for a meeting with the exiled emir of Kuwait. Next was a near-midnight dinner with Saudi King Fahd, known for his preference for late-night meetings. On Thursday, Bush will fly to Dhahran on the Persian Gulf to begin a day-long, hopscotch series of meetings - and Turkey - with troops from the Air Force, Army, Navy and Marines. About 250,000 American troops have been sent to the gulf, and Bush has ordered an additional 200,000 to the Middle East. The president had been scheduled to return to Washington immediately after talks in Cairo on Friday with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak. As for his visit to Saudi Arabia, he said he planned to tell the troops, ``We're going to prevail. We're not there on a mission impossible.'' Bush attended a three-day European security summit in Paris, and spent much of his time working on Persian Gulf diplomacy. He said efforts to win a United Nations resolution authorizing the use of force to evict Iraq from Kuwait were ``on track.'' In addition to Bush's personal diplomacy, Secretary of State James A. Baker III met for several hours with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze to discuss the Persian Gulf conlfict. The president, who has sought a tougher international stand against Iraq's Saddam Hussein, told reporters that ``I leave Paris feeling that we are still together as countries who want to see this situation reversed and want to see this man unilaterally get out of Kuwait.'' The president talked to reporters twice within two hours, once during a meeting with Greek Prime Minister Constantine Mitsotakis and again at the U.S. Embassy in Paris, where he spoke to officials. Both times, he sought to minimize any differences with the Soviets over a United Nations resolution authorizing force in the Persian Gulf. ``I'm encouraged, very encouraged about this holding together of a coalition in the sands and on the seas of the gulf,'' he said. Bush said he believes the United States is ``in goodsynchronization'' with other nations on how to cope with the Persian Gulf crisis. Asked whether he had set a deadline for Saddam to get out of Kuwait, he replied, ``Just watch the way all this develops. Everybody is convinced they must get out of Kuwait with no concessions, and that's what's emerging here.'' Asked if he was concerned about the risks of going into a potential combat zone, he replied, ``It really doesn't enter my mind at all. It is not a risky mission in my view. I'd tell you if I felt any tremors. I don't'' Bush spent three days in Paris for the 34-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, dealing with the future of Europe in the post-Cold War era. The Soviets did not rule out Bush's proposal for a U.N. resolution, but instead counseled patience. Gorbachev, interviewed on French television, said, ``All political leaders strive to avoid a military solution, but we cannot tolerate Saddam Hussein and his regime bringing the world community to its knees.'' He said the U.N. Security Council ``will make an analysis of the situation and will reach a well-considered solution.'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater refused to confirm a report that one resolution being discussed would call for automatic military action if Saddam did not withdraw within a few months. ``There are any number of approaches that are being considered. We will not comment on any one of them,'' he said. Resolutions already approved by the Security Council impose an economic boycott on Iraq and occupied Kuwait, call for Iraq's unconditional withdrawal and insist upon restoration of Kuwait's previous government. Even before one trip was over, Bush was planning a second. The White House said he would visit Greece and Turkey early next year. Meanwhile, U.S. and Soviet officials unveiled plans for a superpower summit in Moscow early next year to sign a treaty on reducing long-range nuclear weapons. Fitzwater said there was no firm date for the summit, although he said both countries were aiming for January. He said having a nuclear arms treaty to sign was a prerequisite for the summit, but holding the session in January ``is what we have been talking about and shooting for.''

DOC.HEAD: Security Forces Kill 12 Moslem Militants
DOC.TEXT: Border guards today killed 12 Moslem militants after the separatists sneaked into India from Pakistan carrying arms and ammunition, officials said. Five militants were captured after the encounter, the officials said. They said 11 Soviet-designed AK-47 assault rifles, 3,200 bullets, 29 grenades and three rocket launchers were seized. The officials, who cannot be identified under briefing rules, said the group of 17 Kashmiri militants was intercepted by troops of the paramilitary Border Security Force in Kupwara, 45 miles west of Srinagar. When asked to stop, the militants fired, forcing the troops to return fire, the officials said. Officials regularly report similar encounters between border guards and Moslem militants, who the government says receive arms and military training in Pakistan to carry on their campaign for the secession of Jammu-Kashmir state from India. Pakistan denies it is training Kashmiri militants but says it morally supports the insurgency, calling it a movement for self-determination. The extremists, who earlier wanted Jammu-Kashmir to unite with Pakistan, now demand indepdence for the Moslem-majority state. Sixtyfour percent of the state's 6 million people are Moslem. Nationwide, Moslems comprise 12 percent of India's 880 million people. Hindus comprise 82 percent. At least 1,573 people have been killed in Kashmir since January. Most of the victims have been militants who fell to security forces. The separatist movement had been simmering since 1947 when British-ruled India won independence and was partitioned into Pakistan and India. Jammu-Kashmir, then an independent state ruled by a Hindu king, had the option of merging with either Pakistan or India. The ruler chose India. Pakistan, an Islamic country, says it should have got Kashmir because of its predominantly Moslem population.

DOC.HEAD: Six Killed in South African Unrest, Township Hit by Strike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th pvs, `A wave...' with 2 grafs to ADD most violence between supporters and opponents of local black officials. Pickup 6th pvs, `In other...'
DOC.TEXT: Assailants firing automatic rifles today killed a South African policeman and seriously wounded his partner in a black township outside Cape Town. Authorities reported five killings in separate incidents, including a black man shot by police near Johannesburg. Police offered a $4,000 reward for help in capturing the killers of the policeman, Constable Frans Van Der Merwe, who was shot in Khayelitsha township outside Cape Town. Cartridges from assault weapons were found at the scene, police officials said. They said Van Der Merwe and his partner were patrolling the area when they came under fire before dawn. The partner, who was not identified, was in stable condition in a Cape Town hospital. A wave of black-on-black violence has swept Khayelitsha. Some residents have attacked supporters of local black officials, accusing the officials of collaborating with the white-led South African government. Eight blacks were killed in the township last month. Garbage piled up today in the strife-torn township, where some 800 trash collectors fearing for their safety were on strike for a fourth straight day to demand protection from authorities. In other violence around Cape Town, a black man was found dead near railway tracks late Tuesday, apparently after jumping from a train to escape assailants, a police report said. Police fatally shot a black man in Orkney, west of Johannesburg, after firing on a group of blacks hurling gasoline bombs, according to the police report, which chronicles unrest over the past 24 hours. Among the other fatalities were a black man found shot and hacked to death Tuesday in the Zonkezizwe township outside Johannesburg. Another black man was slain by unidentified assailants in Kamashu, near Durban on the east coast, according to the unrest report. A black woman died when she was hit during a brick-throwing melee outside a police officer's residence in a township in Orange Free State south of Johannesburg, police said. The report did not specify when the incidents took place. Zonkezizwe was the scene of a weekend massacre in which 19 black men were hacked and stabbed to death. Police said they have not determined a motive for the slayings, but residents said the township had been the scene of fighting between members of the Xhosa and Zulu tribes. Zulus comprise the bulk of support for the Inkatha Freedom Party and have been battling for years with Xhosas and other blacks supporting the African National Congress led by Nelson Mandela. Both groups oppose apartheid but differ on tactics for fighting it.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrilla Attacks End in Salvador
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with guerrilla attacks ending today, detail. Pickup 4th pvs, `The Farabundo...'
DOC.TEXT: A spate of guerrilla attacks against the army abruptly halted today, but President Alfredo Cristiani said the fighting could derail peace talks. Fighting broke out in half of El Salvador's 14 provinces on Tuesday, beginning early in the day and leaving at least 27 people dead and 141 wounded, officials said. But the country appeared to be returning to normal this morning, despite sporadic exchanges of gunfire on the outskirts of the northern provincial capital of Chalatenango, 30 miles north of the capital. In the eastern provincial capital of Usulutan, where some of Tuesday's heaviest fighting took place, buses were returning to the streets and women were setting up market stalls today with no gunfire in earshot. Electricity still had not returned to Usulutan, 60 miles east of San Salvador, nor to most of eastern El Salvador. The Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, the rebel organization also known as FMLN, denied it had launched an offensive. It said the attacks aimed to prod Cristiani's government back to the negotiating table. Government and rebel representatives have held five rounds of talks since May. Negotiations were to resume Nov. 4 in Mexico but bogged down over bitterly differing positions on the future role of the armed forces. ``It is time to say enough to the FMLN. ... This cannot be called military action, since most of those affected are civilians,'' Cristiani said in a radio-TV speech late Tuesday. ``It's a new terrorist offensive.'' ``The only thing these actions do is endanger the negotiating process, since violence engenders violence and will not provide the flexible and rational conditions needed to end the bloodshed,'' he added. More than 73,000 people have been killed, nearly half of them civilians, since the civil war began in October 1979. Many have been slain by death squads linked to the military who suspected them of leftist sympathies. The rebels say they are willing to demobilize and join the political process only if the current armed forces are disbanded, a demand the government refuses to entertain. Congress has slashed El Salvador's $85 million annual military aid in half for 1991 to prod the negotiations along. It stipulated that aid would be restored if the rebels launched an offensive, and cut off altogether if the Cristiani government balked at further talks. A rebel communique shortly after the attacks were launched said the FMLN could launch an all-out offensive if the government does not return to the negotiating table soon. FMLN's action followed the first anniversary of the army's massacre of six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her teenage daughter on Nov. 16, 1989, during a rebel offensive in the capital. The guerrillas, international human rights groups and U.S. congressional investigators say the armed forces murder and torture political opponents and are corrupt. Defense Minister Col. Rene Emilio Ponce warned in a radio-TV message Tuesday night the rebels were likely to intensify their attacks. He said a total of 25 people were killed and 126 wounded in the fighting. Ponce said 12 government soldiers were killed and 76 wounded, and 10 guerrillas were killed and an undetermined number injured. He said civilian casualties amounted to three dead and 50 wounded. A telephone survey of hospitals, first aid centers, military officers in the field and town officials provided the casualty figures earlier Tuesday showing that at least 27 were killed and 141 wounded. One military airplane and three small civilian planes were destroyed by rebel gunfire at the main air base on the outskirts of the capital, Ponce said. Guerrilla sabotage damaged electrical installations and power lines affecting about two-thirds of this Central American nation of more than 5.5 million people, the government electrical company said.

DOC.HEAD: Amateur Fisherman Catches Valuable Sculptures in a Fjord
DOC.TEXT: An unemployed man who went fishing to kill time reeled in two bronze statues which had been stolen from a recent art exhibition, the national news agency NTB reported Wednesday. Algot Hansen, who fishes as a hobby, could hardly believe his eyes when he saw a statue by Norway's prominent artist Per Ung on the hook. ``I was even more surprised when I got another statue a bit further out in the fjord,'' Hansen was quoted as saying. The statues were worth $17,000, according to Ung, 57, who said they were stolen two weeks ago from an exhibition in Oslo. ``I never thought I would see them again,'' Ung said.

DOC.HEAD: Meningitis Kills 202 in Tanzania
DOC.TEXT: An outbreak of meningitis has killed 202 people within the past five months in Tanzania, a senior health official said. The victims were among 2,132 people who had contracted the disease since May, Health Minister Philemon Sarungu said Tuesday. Sarungu said the outbreak appeared under control but urged health officials to send adequate stocks of medicine to hospitals treating meningitis patients. The United Nations Children's Fund has donated $50,000 in medicine for the campaign against the disease in the East African nation, he said. Meningitis is a viral disease that attacks the brain and the spinal cord. It can be fatal if not treated early.

DOC.HEAD: Former CIA Official Says Indictments Close in Pan Am Bombing
DOC.TEXT: A former CIA official says the United States is ``very close'' to getting indictments against the terrorists who bombed Pan Am flight 103, and it also has evidence that Iran was responsible for the disaster. U.S. officials investigating the December 1988 bombing over Scotland had initially suspected that members of the Syrian-based Palestine Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command were responsible. But Vincent M. Cannistraro, who retired two months ago as chief of operations and analysis at the CIA's Counter Terrorism Center, said the PFLP-GC guerrillas abandoned the project at the last minute after a police raid on their safehouses near Frankfurt. Cannistraro said the job was taken over by Libyan agents who planted the highly sophisticated Semtex explosives in the forward hold of the plane and timed them to go off soon after takeoff from Frankfurt. Cannistraro said the Pan Am bombing was ordered by the government of Iran in retaliation for the accidental downing of an Iranian passenger jet over the Persian Gulf in July 1988 by the USS Vincennes. The scheme was known by Iran's top leadership, including the country's current president, Hashemi Rafsanjani. Most of the 270 people killed by the blast were Americans, and the United States has been seeking sufficient evidence for indictments that would stand up in a court of law. Cannistraro, taking the unusual step of speaking to reporters soon after leaving the agency, said investigators had made great progress in determining how the bomb was placed on board and by whom. He did not elaborate. But, he added, the indictments won't make much difference because the perpetrators probably are ``beyond the reach of U.S. law.''
