Last month, Irwin interrupted his hike to climb mile-high Mount Katahdin, site of the trail's northern terminus, before wintry conditions closed that section of the path. He spent Tuesday completing difficult sections of the trail he had previously missed.

DOC.HEAD: Bush To Discuss Gulf Crisis, Hostages with Syrian President
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 15-16, Tutwiler comments on Syrian link to terrorism.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will meet Friday with Syrian President Hafez Assad, a man whose government has been denounced by the administration as a supporter of terrorism and oppressor of human rights. The two-hour meeting focusing on the Persian Gulf crisis will be held in Geneva as Bush heads home from a Thanksgiving day visit with U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia and talks in Cairo with President Hosni Mubarak. In Saudi Arabia Wednesday, Bush defended his meeting with the leader of a state the U.S. government has branded as terrorist. ``Syrians want to see Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait just as much as we do,'' Bush said. ``I have no problem sitting down with him for this common objective.'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater stressed, ``I don't think it (the meeting) implies any change in our overall relationship.'' Still, there are clear advantages for Bush in becoming the first U.S. president Assad will meet since Jimmy Carter in 1977 - not the least of which is solidifying Syrian support for the coalition against Iraq. The meeting's main purpose is to discuss the coalition, to which Syria has committed 15,000 troops, said Fitzwater. The two leaders will also discuss the plight of 13 Western hostages, among them six Americans, held by pro-Iranian extremists in Lebanon, he said. Syria is the main power broker in Lebanon, with 40,000 troops who control large parts of the country. Taking advantage of its new alliance with Syria, the United States asked Assad to use his good offices with Iran to press for the hostages' release and for Iranian compliance with the international trade embargo against Iraq. Assad went to Tehran in late September, after Secretary of State James Baker met him in Damascus, but reportedly came away empty handed on both counts. Assad also has much to gain from easing his hardline anti-U.S. policy and joining the anti-Iraq coalition. An immediate dividend is the rage of his bitter foe, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. By gaining points with the United States, Syria hopes it will eventually be removed from the State Department's list of seven countries that support terrorism and become eligible for aid or other economic benefits. Officials have denied that Bush brokered a deal for Saudi Arabia to give Syria $1 billion since the Syrians joined the coalition. Nonetheless, a Syrian diplomat here confirmed the Saudis have substantially increased their aid to Damascus in recent months, easing the cutoff in Soviet support that sustained Assad for much of the 1980s. Syria also hopes that by improving its relationship with Washington, it might eventually prevail on the United States to pressure its close ally Israel into relinquishing the Golan Heights, a strategically vital area conquered in the 1967 Arab-Israeli war. U.S. officials bristle at the suggestion that the administration is turning a blind eye to Syria's record. ``Our policy cannot and never will be amoral,'' Baker said in response to criticism of his visit to Damascus. ``We have an enormous problem with Syria'' because of its alleged sponsorship of international terrorism, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said Wednesday. ``We cannot improve our relations until the terrorism problem is cleared up. It is still a very emotional, sensitive subject in our country. ``At the same time,'' she added, ``it is a fact of life they have troops on the groud in Saudi Arabia. It's just really important to other Arabs that they (Syria) not be left out.'' Baker brought Syria documents which cite evidence that a Palestinian guerrilla group headquartered in Damascus was responsible for the 1988 bombing of Pan Am 103 in which 270 people, mostly Americans, were killed. Syria responded, as it has often in the past, that the evidence was insufficient to warrant the group's expulsion. Syria has also angered U.S. anti-narcotics officials. The State Department's International Narcotics Control Strategy Report issued last March, said, ``We believe that Syria tolerates and profits from the drug production and trafficking in the areas over which it exercises control.'' Syria controls Lebanon's Bekaa Valley, where production of opium - the raw ingredient for heroin - increased significantly last year. ``The Syrians aren't helping us,'' one official said. ``If anything, they are hindering us.'' ``Syria remains effectively under the rule of an authoritarian regime,'' according to the State Department's annual report on human rights around the world. ``Human rights abuses, including torture, denial of the freedoms of speech, press, association, ... continue to characterize the regime's record in 1989.'' Middle East Watch, a human rights group, said in a recent report that Syria had executed 10,000 of its own citizens over the past 20 years. The United States is also worried about Syria's chemical weapons arsenal, considered by experts as dangerous as Iraq's - if not more so. Acting within a 16-nation alliance known as the Australia Group, the United States has tried to stop European companies from helping Syria build its chemical weapons capability. But Syria is known to have begun production in the mid 1980s, and to have equipped accurate SS-21 missiles with chemical warheads that can hit neighboring Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Calm Returns to Most of El Salvador
With AM-US-El Salvador
LaserPhoto SAL1
DOC.TEXT: This battered provincial capital and most of the rest of the country returned to peace Wednesday after a brief guerrilla offensive, but few expected the calm to last. ``It is very possible that these sick minds of the most radical elements of the FMLN will continue or augment these actions,'' President Alfredo Cristiani told the nation Tuesday night, 20 hours after the rebels launched their most extensive and concerted military campaign of 1990. Usulutan, 65 miles southeast of San Salvador, was the scene of some of Tuesday's heaviest combat. Rebels of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, or FMLN, struck army posts here and in 14 other towns and cities. The fighting left more than 80 dead and nearly 270 people wounded, according to the U.S. State Department, which cited Salvadoran military sources. As they have in many previous battles of El Salvador's 11-year civil war, the citizens of this city of 80,000 listened to the racket of gunfire through shuttered windows Tuesday, then returned to their affairs at first light Wednesday. With the rebels cleared out of town, the market was bustling with women selling melons, plantains and beans to shoppers. Buses and other traffic circulated normally. But 25 miles to the west, on the flat coastal highway to San Salvador, traffic was backed up more than an hour because of combat between guerrillas and government soldiers. Reporters saw at least three soldiers wounded in the fighting. Battles also continued Wednesday in Sesori, about 30 miles north of Usulutan. In Santa Elena, five miles northeast of here, about 100 government troops rested or manned guard posts after driving rebels out of the town Tuesday afternoon. But the feeling among townspeople was that the rebels had been testing the waters and would be back. ``I'm going to stock up for a few days,'' said shopper Evangelina Castillo, a 45-year-old mother of four. Guerrillas who spoke with reporters on the northern periphery of San Salvador, where fighting was also heavy Tuesday, had said the rebel campaign was designed to last three or four days. Insurgents remained entrenched in Quetzaltepeque, 10 miles north of San Salvador. Guerrilla commander German Serrano said Wednesday in an interview broadcast on the clandestine rebel radio said the offensive was designed ``to pressure the army to agree to political accords that will permit us to achieve peace.'' The State Department strongly denounced the offensive and said it was weighing an increase of military aid. ``Once again, the FMLN is talking about peace settlement, while raining violence and death on El Salvador's citizens. The FMLN has repeatedly stalled the negotiating process over the past four months, and now claims to be seeking to accelerating it,'' said spokesman Richard Boucher in Washington. Under legislation approved last month, Congress cut military aid to El Salvador in half, to $42.5 million, because of the lack of progress in halting rights abuses. The legislation would allow the cut aid to be restored if the rebels launched a military offensive threatening the government. Boucher said that provision of the legislation was being reviewed in light of Tuesday's attacks. The bill also called for a complete aid cutoff if the government pulls out of peace talks. Five rounds of peace talks this year have produced little progress, bogging down on the rebel demand for demilitarization of society. The rebels are calling for the transformation of the army into a civilian-led police force. Cristiani has said his government is willing to reform the armed forces, but that their abolition is out of the question.

DOC.HEAD: Despite Gorbachev Call For Urgent Meeting, Security Council Quiet
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Although Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev appealed Wednesday for an urgent Security Council meeting on the gulf crisis, there is no sign of an agreed resolution or a meeting soon. Gorbachev's appeal came after President Bush failed to win the Soviet leader's support for a U.N. resolution to use force to drive Iraq from Kuwait. Gorbachev urged the 15-nation Security Council to address ``very dangerous'' developments in the gulf and ``take a decision there.'' He did not elaborate, but the comments seemed to indicate he was moving closer to Bush's position. Bush met with Gorbachev on Tuesday in Paris, where the two leaders were attending a European security summit. After the meeting, Bush said that despite his failure to win support for a U.N. resolution condoning force, he and Gorbachev ``saw eye to eye'' on Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, and that any differences between the two superpowers were ``extraordinarily minor.'' The United States had been trying to push through a resolution to use force against Iraq before the end of the month, when U.S. Ambassador Thomas Pickering gives up the council's rotating presidency. The position then passes to Yemen, which is the only Arab council member and is reluctant to move toward war with Iraq. Asked if the United Nations might act this month on a U.N. resolution to use force against Iraq, Bush said: ``Stay tuned. There's certainly a chance.'' Nevertheless, both the Soviet and American U.N. missions said Wednesday they had no instructions to call a meeting of the 15-nation Security Council. Finnish Ambassador Klaus Tornudd, who is close to both the U.S. and Soviet missions, said of the prospect for such a meeting: ``I don't think so, not this week.'' U.N. spokesman Francois Giuliani said the U.N. Secretariat has not been asked to make preparations for a council meeting. The U.S. mission said the only council action they have in sight is a possible meeting Friday on a PLO-backed resolution on Israel and the occupied territories, which would call for deployment of U.N. peacekeepers to monitor Israeli security forces. The Soviets and Americans are known to have prepared texts for potential resolutions on the gulf crisis, but they differ markedly, diplomats have said. Resolutions already approved by the Security Council impose an economic boycott on Iraq and occupied Kuwait, call for Iraq's unconditional withdrawal, insist upon restoration of Kuwait's deposed government and demand Iraq free all hostages.

DOC.HEAD: Ohio Supreme Court Rejects Former Congressman's Appeal
DOC.TEXT: Former U.S. Rep. Donald Lukens' conviction on a charge of having sex with a 16-year-old girl in 1988 was upheld Wednesday by the Ohio Supreme Court. Lukens resigned from Congress last month, two days after the House Ethics Committee voted to investigate new charges of sexual misconduct against him that involved alleged advances on a congressional employee. Lukens, a Republican from Middletown, was sentenced in June 1989 to 30 days in jail and fined $500 after a jury convicted him of a misdemeanor charge of contributing to the unruliness of a minor. He has been free on bond pending appeal. There was no immediate indication when Lukens might begin serving his sentence. Franklin County Domestic Relations Judge Ronald Solove said he would have to await paperwork in the case from the Supreme Court. ``Once that's done then we will probably set a date for enforcement of the sentence,'' Solove said. A call to Lukens' lawyer, Thomas Tyack of Columbus, was not immediately returned. Lukens' attorneys had argued that Solove erred by barring testimony about the girl's juvenile offense record. The Franklin County prosecutor's office had no comment on the appeal. A state appeals court upheld the conviction in June. Court records indicated the Supreme Court justices voted 5-1 to dismiss the appeal, with one judge listed as not participating. The court did not elaborate on its decision. Allegations surfaced in early 1989 that Lukens had sex with a girl while he was a member of Congress. A Columbus television station broadcast a videotape of a November 1988 meeting between Lukens and the girl's mother, Anna Coffman. Lukens did not know the meeting at a restaurant was being taped by a television crew. Lukens served two terms in Congress, from 1967 to 1970, and then made an unsuccessful attempt to gain the GOP gubernatorial nomination in Ohio. After 15 years in the Ohio Senate, voters returned him to Congress in 1986 and he was re-elected in 1988. He lost his bid for a third consecutive term in the 8th District GOP primary in May. He will be succeeded by state Rep. John Boehner, who won the seat in the Nov. 6 election.

DOC.HEAD: Government Supporters, Opponents Clash in Sofia
DOC.TEXT: Government supporters and opponents skirmished in the capital Wednesday, as Parliament prepared to vote on a controversial reform package that could decide the fate of embattled Premier Andrei Lukanov. Riot police intervened to prevent serious clashes, the state BTA news agency said. Leaders of the governing Socialist Party and the main opposition alliance, the Union of Democratic Forces, went on national television to call for tolerance and restraint before the key Parliament session Thursday. The legislature is to vote on Lukanov's budget package, which includes steep price hikes. Lukanov has said he will step down if it is not passed. The Socialist premier faces increasing calls for his resignation from citizens frustrated by the country's continuing economic decline and food shortages. On Wednesday, several hundred supporters of the opposition scuffled with pro-government demonstrators who marched through the capital, witnesses said. They said hundreds of helmeted police armed with shields and batons surrounded Parliament. Three demonstrators and three policemen were slightly injured in the scuffles, said a police spokesman on condition of anonymity. A first-aid doctor said he saw one young opposition supporter beaten by police after he allegedly attacked pro-government demonstrators. Several hundred demonstrators marched to Sofia's TV station, the site of pro-democracy demonstrations after Bulgaria's long-time Communist leader Todor Zhivkov was ousted last November. Police said there were no violent incidents. Supporters of both sides also rallied in other cities, many chanting slogans such as ``Give Lukanov a Chance'' or ``Down with the Socialists.'' There were no reports of violence. Zhivkov, who has been under house arrest since he was forced from power, is to be brought to trial on charges of misappropriating millions of dollars in state funds and for abuse of power, the prosecutor general announced Tuesday. No date has been set. After Zhivkov's ouster, the Communist Party subsequently renamed itself the Socialist Party and introduced reforms that led to free elections in June. The Socialists won a majority and hold 210 of the 400 Parliament seats. The opposition, which holds 144 seas, rejected repeated offers by Lukanov to form a coalition government that would have broad popular support and be better able to push through badly needed economic reforms. The government's inability to stock Bulgarian stores with staples has caused the Socialists' popularity to plummet with the economy's performance. In an effort to boost food supplies, Parliament voted Wednesday to restrict the export of meat and dairy products, except in exchange for scarce commodities, the BTA news agency said. The opposition alliance backed a call Tuesday by the labor confederation Podkrepa for a general strike next week if Lukanov's government does not resign. Several thousand university students, who have been on strike for two weeks, also staged an anti-government rally in Sofia Wednesday. The rector of Sofia University announced all classes would be canceled from Thursday through Dec. 1 in solidarity with the student strikers, BTA said.

DOC.HEAD: Kasparov, Karpov Prepare for Second Half of Title Match
DOC.TEXT: Chess masters Garry Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov said Wednesday they hope the peace and quiet of this central French river city will help their play when they face off this weekend for the world championship. Both complained of the noise and activity that surrounded them in New York, where they ended a 12-game contest in a draw, with six points apiece. The second half of their championship play begins Saturday. ``For chess publicity it was better in New York, but for the chess player it is better in Lyon,'' Kasparov, the 27-year-old defending world champion, told a joint news conference. Karpov, 39, said the longtime rivals had hoped to boost the popularity of chess among Americans by playing in New York from Oct. 8 to Nov. 7. He said chess ``is a lot more popular in Europe.'' Unlike New York, where honking horns and police sirens proved inescapable, the two Soviet masters are installed in spacious villas in Lyon. ``It's always different between a hotel and a grand villa,'' Kasparov said. Karpov agreed. ``In New York, I was on a very noisy street,'' he said, adding that he had to move into a hotel one night to get rest. ``Here I have a nice, quiet house.'' Each player won one game in New York. They tied 10. Kasparov likened the match - the fifth world championship he has played against Karpov - to the series they played in 1986 in London and Leningrad, which began with only three clear victories in London. At the time, Kasparov was defending the title he won a year earlier. ``We had only three positive results in London and then six results in Leningrad,'' Kasparov said. ``Hopefully, we will have it here again.'' Kasparov retained the title again in 1987 when the match ended at 12 points apiece. The two men dislike each other, but Kasparov declined to discuss personal animosity Wednesday. ``For me to explain it again, I would have to tell my biography from beginning to end,'' he said. The talkative, flamboyant Kasparov, who speaks fluent English, identifies Karpov with the official Soviet system. Karpov, who is frequently portrayed as a colorless introvert who plays with surgical precision, has often said he has ``two loves: communism and chess.'' The first player to win 12{ points is victor in this year's world championship, and will receive $1.7 million of a $3 million purse. A 12-12 tie would leave Kasparov with the title. Kasparov says he will help victims of the Chernobyl nuclear power station disaster and promote chess in schools with his share of the winnings. Karpov has been quoted as saying that his earnings will finance ``my private interests and the political interests of the world.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Announces Accord With Army on Makeup of High Command
DOC.TEXT: President Patricio Aylwin has succeeded in vetoing the promotions of two generals favored by Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the government announced Wednesday. The vetoed officers, Brig. Gens. Carlos Parera and Ramon Castro, will remain in the army, but will not be promoted to major general as Pinochet wished, said Defense Minister Patricio Rojas. Parera, commander of the Santiago garrison, will be made military attache at an unspecified embassy abroad, apparently South Africa, sources said. Castro will remain as military attache in the Chilean embassy in Washington. Rojas said in a communique that Aylwin approved all the new assignments to the high command that had been proposed by Pinochet. The outcome of the annual army command shuffle seemed to strengthen Aylwin, who took office in March after the first Chilean elections in 18 years. Wednesday's arrangement marked the first time since the military coup that brought Pinochet to power in 1973 in which the command makeup was not determined by Pinochet alone. Aylwin's relations with the army are considered among the most complex problems he will deal with during his four-year term. Under a special clause of the 1980 constitution, the 74-year-old Pinochet remained commander of the 65,000-man army. Aylwin cannot fire Pinochet.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Says Embassies Involved in Drug Smuggling
DOC.TEXT: Iran said Wednesday some embassies in Tehran are involved in drug trafficking and appealed to Europe and the United Nations to help combat the smuggling of narcotics. The official Islamic Republic News Agency, monitored in Cyprus, said the charge was leveled by Mokhtar Kalantari, commander of the Islamic Revolution's Committees and secretary of the Anti-drug Headquarters. Kalantari told a news conference in Tehran the Foreign Ministry was investigating the alleged involvement of certain embassies in drug smuggling, but did not specify what ones. Iran is a major transit route for illicit Asian drugs reaching Europe and the United States. Some drugs are also believed produced locally. He said with European help, Iran will completely block transit of drugs to Europe. ``Unfortunately, those countries appear to be indifferent toward the fate of their youths. No heroin would arrive in Europe if Western countries desired to contribute to our anti-narcotics campaign,'' IRNA quoted him as saying. He did not elaborate on what help he expected Europe to offer. However, Kalantari also complained that the U.N. Fund for Anti-Narcotics Campaign failed to help fight smuggling. He suggested the fund could offer assistance to his government. ``What we need is some technological assistance, such as drug-detecting instruments, and trained dogs,'' he said. Kalantari estimated the number of Iranian drug addicts at 1 million, but said 200,000 to 300,000 have given up the habit the past two years ``and not single person had become addicted to opium in the said period.'' U.N. reports have said the number of addicts in Iran is at least double that reported officially. Iran's parliament passed a law in 1988 mandating the death penalty for anyone caught possessing narcotics, no matter the quantity. According to official figures, 1,500 people have been executed for drug offenses since then and about 50,000 people jailed as abusers. Iranian opposition groups and international human rights organizations maintain that those executed included political prisoners. Kalantari said Iran's crackdown has broken up about 520 international drug trafficking rings since 1988, comprising 38,862 smugglers who included 1,158 Afghanis. He said members of one ring recently confessed to smuggling three tons of drugs to Europe. He gave no details. Kalantari said Afghanis were the main distributors of drugs, ``and there are clues that they account for 60 to 70 percent of smuggling rings.'' On Tuesday, Iranian security forces killed ``eight notorious traffickers and bandits'' - including two Afghanis - in a clash in Sirjan, in southern Hormuzgan province, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Boston Considers Curfew Following Gang Slaying
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Raymond Flynn said Wednesday he is considering a nighttime curfew for young people as city officials and civic leaders reel from arrests of teen-agers in the Halloween gang rape and murder of a young woman. The curfew idea drew immediate criticism from civil libertarians who called it an unconstitutional abridgement of freedom, but Flynn said parents have to be made accountable for their children. ``I'm going to talk to parents, young kids, community leaders and see whether or not there's something we can put in place that holds parents responsible for the behavior of their children, particularly in the wee hours of the morning,'' Flynn said. Authorities alleged that the rape and murder of 26-year-old Kimberly Rae Harbour was committed by a gang of teen-agers roaming the streets in search of women to rob. Eight black tee-agers were arrested this week. Flynn suggested a system similar to the curfew put in place this week in Atlanta, where youths under 18 hanging around on street corners or in public places are arrested and turned over to the custody of their parents. He said that if he decides to start a curfew, he would make it effective in the spring, when warming weather draws more people outside. The Massachusetts chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union, like its Georgia counterpart, promised to challenge a curfew in court. ``There is no way to equitably enforce curfew laws. It's simply impossible,'' said John Roberts, director of the Massachusetts CLU. ``It will be enforced in some neighborhoods and you know which ones. It will be enforced vigorously in Roxbury in a way that it will not in West Roxbury.'' Roxbury is a predominantly black neighborhood that has been beset by violent crime in the past several years. West Roxbury is a predominantly white neighborhood and one of the more affluent sections of Boston. Harbour's nude body was found on a grassy knoll in the Franklin Field park in Dorchester, a neighborhood next to Roxbury that also has been troubled by crime. Harbour had been bludgeoned, repeatedly raped, and stabbed more than 100 times. Boston city Councilor Bruce Bolling, who is black, said the curfew idea ``merits some discussion,'' but he questioned how it could be practically enforced. State Sen. Bill Owens criticized police for withholding details of the murder and investigation for three weeks. He added that ``We do not accept the blanket indictment that the entire black male population of our community behaves in this manner.'' Police compared the attack to one in New York's Central Park in which a female jogger was raped, brutally beaten and left for dead, allegedly by a group of black teen-agers who had gone ``wilding.'' The Harbour slaying initially drew little public notice after police announced it as a homicide. Details weren't released until this week after the arrests of the eight teen-agers, five of them juveniles. Prosecutors are seeking to have the five juveniles charged as adults. Conviction as an adult on a charge of first-degree murder would bring an automatic life sentence without parole. If they are found delinquent as juveniles, they could be released on their 18th birthday. The juveniles are scheduled to appear in court Dec. 5. Three adults aged 17, 18 and 19 have a pre-trial hearing on Dec. 29.

DOC.HEAD: Baltic Republics Want Joint Session of Their Parliaments
With AM-Soviet-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The leaders of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia on Wednesday denounced what they termed ``a policy of intimidation'' by the Kremlin against the Baltic republics, according to media reports. Their summit was convened in Jurmala, Latvia, to respond to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's proposals on strengthening the executive branch of government under his control. The leaders issued a statement asking the parliaments of the three republics to meet in an extraordinary joint session, citing what they said was a ``real threat to the independence of the three Baltic states.'' The statement did not elaborate. Presidents Vytautas Landsbergis of Lithuania, Anatoly Gorbunov of Latvia and Arnold Ruutel of Estonia invited representatives from international bodies to attend. In an interview with Interfax News Agency, Estonian presidential spokesman Tonu Kalume said the Baltics will not be swayed from their course of ``full sovereignty and independence,'' even if Gorbachev threatens to introduce direct presidential rule or economic sanctions. In a separate appeal to the Soviet parliament, Landsbergis, Gorbunov and Ruutel denounced what they said were ``direct threats to use force to suspend our democratically elected governmental institutions and our laws,'' according to the Baltic News Service. ``In the face of these threats, we note that the Baltic states will exercise their inalienable right to resist violence,'' it quoted the appeal as saying. ``The people, parliaments and the governmental bodies of the Baltic states will oppose new aggression and the repetition of tragic events comparable to those of 1940.'' The presidents reiterated their refusal to sign Gorbachev's proposed union treaty, which would redefine the relationship between the Soviet government and the republics. They expressed willingness, however, to take part in negotiations and conclude agreements with the Soviet Union and with other republics on political, economic and other forms of cooperation. Gorbachev said Wednesday support existed in the Baltics for staying in the Soviet Union. He told Soviet and French television journalists before leaving Paris, in an interview broadcast on Soviet TV: ``Look what happened during the celebration of the Soviet Revolution Day. More people took part in the celebration in Riga than in Moscow. And Latvians, Poles, Russians - all people who live there, Ukrainians, threw flowers at the participants in the parade. ``People went there deliberately to demonstrate in favor of this, the union, in favor of preservation, yes, also for renewal. So when we analyze these complex processes, we have to see the entire complexity of the thing, not just statements made by (Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera) Prunskiene, Landsbergis or anyone else.'' Gorbachev denounced as a ``provocation'' a demonstration that took place in Lithuania on Saturday in which protesters marched to a Soviet military base, shouted slogans against the Red Army and scuffled with soliders. ``An appeal to the government and the police didn't do any good,'' he said. ``The military had to defend themselves without using weapons.'' ``The fact is that the great majority of the people are in favor of the union, I am convinced.'' Gorbachev rejected the Baltic republics' declarations of independence this year. He blocked deliveries of Soviet oil, natural gas and other key supplies to Lithuania. Those sanctions ended after the government in Vilnius suspended its declaration in exchange for the start of negotiations with the Kremlin. Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia - independent between the two world wars - were seized by Josef Stalin in 1940.

DOC.HEAD: Winter Storms in the Northwest; Record Warmth in the Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Winter storms continued to plague the Pacific Northwest on Wednesday and rain was scattered over the central part of the nation. Rain fell over western Oregon and western Washington state, changing to snow at higher elevations in the mountains. Snow also extended over eastern Washington state, parts of Idaho, western Montana and western Wyoming. A new wet weather system was expected to reach the northern Pacific Coast on Thanksgiving day, bringing warmer temperatures and locally heavy rainfall will be locally heavy. A flood warning was posted for several rivers through Thursday. At midday, rain fell over parts of Michigan, southeastern Wisconsin and the northern half of Minnesota. Rain also fell from Missouri into northwestern Arkansas and eastern Oklahoma. Unseasonably warm temperatures extended from the upper Mississippi Valley into the central Plains. Record highs included 72 at Des Moines, Iowa; 63 at Duluth, Minn.; 68 at Eau Claire, Wis.; 57 at International Falls, Minn.; 70 at Kansas City, Mo.; 68 at La Crosse, Wis.; 51 at Marquette, Mich.; 67 at Minneapolis-St. Paul, Minn.; 69 at Rochester, Minn.; 62 at St. Cloud, Minn.; 63 at South Bend, Ind.; 73 at Topeka, Kan.; 69 at Waterloo, Iowa; 73, a tie, at Indianapolis; 70, a tie, at Lincoln, Neb.; 79, tie, at Montgomery, Ala.; and 68, tie, at Omaha, Neb. Wednesday morning's low for the Lower 48 states was 4 degrees at Ely, Nev. Temperatures at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 19 at Yellowstone National Park, Wyo., to 86 at McAllen, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Pakistan, India Leaders Admit Conflict Holds Back Progress
DOC.TEXT: The new prime ministers of India and Pakistan agreed Wednesday that hostilities between their nations had helped keep the region enslaved by poverty. But in their speeches at the opening of a seven-nation South Asian summit, the leaders avoided the contentious issues that led to three India-Pakistan wars in 43 years and brought them to the brink of a fourth conflict earlier this year. ``If we fight amongst each other, we will not be able to fight poverty, misery and squalor,'' said India's Chandra Shekhar, departing from his prepared text. ``It is regrettable that the new wave of conciliation and accommodation has not as yet pervaded the South Asian region,'' said Nawaz Sharif, head of Pakistan's two-week-old government. Sharif said the South Asian nations ``face underdevelopment in all its manifestations,'' and cannot afford confrontations and high defense budgets. ``We should harness the requisite political will to eliminate the root causes of suspicion and tension in our region.'' It was the international debut for both men, who each came to power the last two weeks, Sharif through general elections and Chandra Shekhar because of the collapse of a previous government. The summit opening was marked by impatience with the slow pace of regional development because of the conflicts and distrust among the members of the South Asia Association for Regional Cooperation, known as SAARC. Chandra Shekhar, who was granted a two-day delay of the summit while he assembled his government in New Delhi, said the differences should not be allowed to impede economic cooperation. ``Most of the time SAARC meetings and summits are just formalities. Why not try to take up the issues which are agitating the minds of the people?'' he said. India has sought to use the regional association to broaden trade, economic and financial ties in the region, but the smaller countries have been reluctant to move too quickly for fear their economies would be swamped by their huge neighbor. The other members of six-year-old organization are Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, Nepal, Bhutan and the Maldives. Afghanistan's application to join may be discussed by the summit, officials said. Preliminary talks by foreign ministers focused on whether to seek outside contributions to a regional development fund and on harmonizing laws against drug trafficking. Reporters have been kept at a distance from the delegations, but officials said Sharif and Chandra Shekhar had no opportunity to meet before the opening session. The seven leaders and their top aides were scheduled to spend all of Thursday in informal talks on an isolated tropical island. The heads of India and Pakistan have not met since the last regional summit two years ago. Escalating guerrilla violence and an Indian army crackdown in the northern Kashmir valley nearly brought a fourth war between the two countries earlier this year. India accuses Pakistan of aiding seccessionist insurgencies by Sikhs in Punjab state and by Moslems in Jammu-Kashmir. Pakistan denies actively helping the guerrillas, but supports their aims for self-determination. The two insurrections have claimed more than 4,400 lives this year. As the summit began, Maldives officials said three local magazines had been closed and their editors arrested on charges of publishing articles defaming the government. Residents said the offending articles accused defense officials of corruption, and that seven local journalists had been arrested. The archipelago nation, a chain of 1,190 islands with a population of 200,000, witnessed a coup attempt two years ago by dissidents who accused President Maumoon Abdul Gayoom of stifling all dissent. India rushed troops to its neighbor 400 miles off its southern coast to crush the coup attempt carried out by Sri Lankan Tamil merceneries.

DOC.HEAD: Accused Killer of Anti-Arab Zealot Pleads Innocent
DOC.TEXT: A municipal employee pleaded innocent Wednesday to charges that he murdered Jewish extremist Meir Kahane, while followers of the slain right-wing rabbi called for vengeance. ``No justice, no peace'' chanted about 40 demonstrators marching in a circle outside the courthouse. One of their placards read: ``Hand Nosair over, we'll take care of him.'' Defendant El Sayyid Nosair, 35, a native of Egypt, wore a white skullcap with Arabic script around its perimeter. His chin and neck were bandaged where he was shot by a postal police officer he encountered after allegedly shooting Kahane at a Manhattan hotel on Nov. 5. Nosair, of Cliffside Park, N.J., has been suspended from his city job of repairing heating and air-conditioning equipment. Kahane, a New York native, had served four years in Israel's Parliament but was barred from office in 1988 by a ban on racist parties. He had campaigned to drive Arabs from Israel. Before moving to Israel, Kahane founded and led the Jewish Defense League and urged American Jews to arm themselves against anti-Semites. When Nosair entered the courtroom, Suzanne Gruer shouted ``Revenge!'' in Hebrew. Gruer, 21, of East Northport, wearing a T-shirt bearing the symbol of Kahane's Kach Party, was among about 100 people crowding the courtroom. Gruer said they were there to ``show how strongly we feel. We will not permit a whitewash.'' Acting state Supreme Court Justice Sheryl Parker scheduled a hearing for Dec. 5. Supreme Court in New York state is a trial-level court. Nosair remained in custody without bail. An indictment announced Tuesday charged Nosair with murder, attempted murder, assaulting a police officer, assault, weapon possession, reckless endangerment and coercion. District Attorney Robert Morgenthau said federal and local investigators had developed no information connecting others to the slaying and that it appeared Nosair acted alone. The murder charge carries a maximum sentence of 25 years to life in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Department Lax In Overseeing Nuclear Weapons Security, Report Says
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 11th graf bgng: `The Energy ... with two new grafs to UPDATE with Energy Dept comment
DOC.TEXT: The Energy Department failed to take prompt action after inspections showed that some guards at nuclear weapons facilities could not shoot accurately and did not know how to arrest, search or handcuff intruders, congressional investigators said Wednesday. The General Accounting Office, an investigating arm of Congress, said some shortcomings uncovered in 1985 inspections at the department's Los Alamos, Argonne, Sandia and Savannah River sites went uncorrected for five years. It said the department gave the Argonne facility an unsatisfactory rating over the five-year period but continued to rate security at the others as satisfactory. The GAO report was requested by the House energy subcommittee on oversight and investigation and by Sens. Pete Domenici, R-N.M., and Jeff Bingaman, D-N.M., after a 10-week strike by the contract security force at the Los Alamos National Laboratory last year. The congressional investigators said many guards hired as replacements during the strike did not have the required skills. They also said an unannounced exercise conducted in April showed that 75 per cent of the regular security force failed at one or more of the skills required. ``For example, when the participants encountered an adversarial situation, many failed to stay behind cover and assess the situation,'' the report said. ``Instead, they left their cover and walked up to the potential adversaries to ask what they were doing.'' Consequently, it said, many of the adversaries were able to take out a visible weapon, theoretically kill the guard and make off with classified documents. It said 24 participants and hostages were ``killed'' during the test. The GAO said the department does not routinely conduct unannounced tests, which it considers disruptive, but did so at the request of the congressional agency. The Energy Department referred inquiries about the report to Los Alamos, where Anna Bachicha, a public affairs officer, said the ``report was just released today and we just received a copy of it this afternoon and have not had time to fully assess it.'' ``If after we review it we find there are any weaknesses we'll take whatever steps are necessary to correct those findings,'' she said. ``The department is confident that safeguards and security programs at Los Alamos are being managed in an effective and efficient manner.'' L. Ari Fleischer, Domenici's press secretary, said he had written to Energy Secretary James D. Watkins asking him to respond to the report. ``He is concerned about it, of course,'' Fleischer said. ``But we don't read that to say that there is an imminent crisis out there or that DOE facilities are in imminent danger or even in danger at all.'' The agency recommended that the department standardize skill requirements for all security force members, including strike replacements, and make sure they all receive required training. It also recommended that contractors have part of their fees withheld if they fail to correct weaknesses in security.

DOC.HEAD: Thanksgiving Hunger '90: More Hurting, Fewer Helping
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `Salvation Army...,' to restore first reference to Ferraez.
Eds: Also moved for PMs
DOC.TEXT: When it comes to Thanksgiving hunger in America this year, more people are hurting and fewer people are helping. ``Some of the people who had been giving are people who need help this year,'' said Wiley Cooper, director of the United Way of America's emergency food and shelter program. The slumping national economy and fears of war in the Middle East are cutting into donations, charity groups say. Joseph Zalenski, director of the Brotherhood Mission in Philadelphia, said some people are disheartened because they can't give. ``The only thing I can do is to graciously back off and say, `I appreciate your plight,''' Zalenski said. ```I understand and I only hope it doesn't get worse for you, so that you don't come down to where these people are right now.''' The National Coalition for the Homeless estimates there are 3 million homeless people nationwide. Cooper said there is no reliable way of counting the hungry, but ``the people who are providing the services are reporting to us their demand is up greatly.'' ``The economy and the Saudi Arabia thing have hurt us the most,'' said Ron Cool of the Kiwanis Club of Little Rock, Ark. Donations for Thanksgiving food baskets are off 10 percent to 15 percent, he said. ``People are a little afraid, and they're hanging onto their bucks.'' Some restaurants that helped supply the Rhode Island Community Food Bank have gone out of business, said Eileen Welly, executive director. A drive last week collected 300,000 pounds of canned foods - 100,000 pounds less than last year. Salvation Army Lt. Col. Leon Ferraez, the national spokesman, said demand for Thanksgiving and Christmas holiday relief services is up nearly 20 percent at the army's 9,000 centers. Last year, the Salvation Army spent $115 million for food, shelter, clothing, toys and parties over the holidays. This year, Ferraez said $138 million will be needed. He couldn't say how much has been raised so far. ``We just pray that the resources come in,'' said Ferraez, Salvation Army spokesman. Five-thousand households will celebrate Thanksgiving with canned hams and chickens from the Maryland Food Bank, even though the agency's holiday food drive has collected 180,000 pounds of food, far short of the 650,000 pounds it had hoped for. Feed the Hungry in Atlanta will serve 23,000 to 25,000 Thanksgiving dinners and deliver an additional 4,000. It served 21,000 last year. Its organizer, the Rev. Hosea Williams, said he needs $100,000 but has collected just $3,000 so far. ``We always bail ourselves out at Christmas,'' said Williams. ``(But) we've never been this short before.'' In Ohio, 547 turkeys were donated by Tuesday after the Toledo Seagate Food Bank announced last week that some 700 families would get only bologna and tuna for Thanksgiving. Alice Mosiniak, food bank executive director, said plant closings and layoffs have heightened the need as donations and surplus food dwindled. ``The ones who are bringing the turkeys in, for the most part, are the ones who are having a hard time themselves, but they know what it's like to go without something,'' Mosniak said. At the Salvation Army in Miami, donations on Monday were $793 ahead of last year, but there are 800 more homeless people, said Maj. Ted Arrowood, area commander. ``The faster we go, the more behind we get,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Milken, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are details of the six counts to which former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. junk bond executive Michael Milken pleaded guilty.
DOC.HEAD: Conspiracy
DOC.TEXT: Milken conspired with former speculator Ivan Boesky and fund manager David Solomon from 1984 to late 1986 to manipulate securities prices, rig transactions, evade taxes and regulatory requirements, and enrich Drexel.
DOC.HEAD: Helping To File False Information With the Securities and Exchange Commission
DOC.TEXT: Milken in 1984 and 1985 encouraged Boesky to buy more than 10 percent of Fishbach Corp., which was the target of a takeover attempt by Drexel client Victor Posner. Milken agreed to make up any losses to Boesky. Drexel's interest in Boesky's holdings in Fishbach was not disclosed to the SEC.
DOC.HEAD: Securities Fraud
DOC.TEXT: Milken enlisted the Boesky organization to artificially support the price of MCA Inc. common stock in late 1984 while Drexel client Golden Ngget Inc. sold its MCA holdings. Milken assured Boesky that Drexel would make up any losses.
DOC.HEAD: Violating SEC Reporting Requirements
DOC.TEXT: Drexel through Milken agreed to buy more than 1 million shares of Helmerich & Payne Corp. common stock in 1985 from the Boesky organization, but Boesky remained responsible for any losses. The arrangement allowed Boesky to claim falsely that his organization complied with SEC net capital requirements.
DOC.HEAD: Mail Fraud
DOC.TEXT: Milken agreed with Solomon, manager of the Finsbury Fund, an investment fund for foreigners, to overcharge clients in 1985 and 1986 to recoup fees paid to Drexel brokers who sold shares in the fund.
DOC.HEAD: Assisting the Filing of a False Tax Return
DOC.TEXT: Milken engaged in a series of prearranged securities trades to help Solomon claim false trading losses and reduce his 1985 income taxes.

DOC.HEAD: Interim Government Reportedly Goes to Liberia
DOC.TEXT: Amos Sawyer, the president of an interim government for war-shattered Liberia, left for the capital city of Monrovia to be installed in a ceremony expected Thursday, a source in the government said. Sawyer left unannounced Wednesday with his entourage, the source said, speaking on condition of anonymity. He would not say if the party went by ship or by air. Security apparently was the reason for the secrecy. Warring factions have killed prominent politicians and Sawyer's government is opposed by rebel leader Charles Taylor, whose army has overrun most of Liberia except Monrovia. Taylor's insurgents have been shelling the port of Monrovia this week. Three members of Sawyer's proposed Cabinet were threatened by rival rebel chief Prince Johnson, and it was not clear whether they left with the party. Sawyer, a veteran leftist opposition leader and a political scientist, was chosen as interim leader at a September conference of Liberian exiles. He has the backing of five Western African nations - Nigeria, Ghana, Guinea, Sierra Leone and Gambia - which have sent a regional task force to Liberia to enforce peace in that fellow West African nation of 2.3 million people. The five nations say the fighting and flood of Liberian refugees also affected them. Taylor and Johnson invaded Liberia from Ivory Coast last December to overthrow President Samuel Doe, whom they accused of corruption, tribalism and brutal repression of opposition. The rebels fell out in February. Johnson's fighters, a small band compared to Taylor's army, won the race to Monrovia, captured and tortured Doe to death, and since have been cooperating with the West African task force. Nigerian jets from the intervention force have been bombing rebel-held towns to force Taylor to negotiate an end to the 11-month-old war in which more than 10,000 civilians have been killed. Remnants of Doe's army have signed a cease-fire with Johnson. The two sides say they support Sawyer's interim administration and its mandate to organize fair elections. Taylor says Sawyer and his team are puppets of West African governments bent on dominating Liberia. Taylor has named a rival government. Installation of Sawyer's administration appears to anticipate a West African summit scheduled for Monday in Bamako, Mali, to discuss Liberia. Taylor has said he would attend the meeting, but he has promised to go to other peace conferences without showing up.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Say Loud Music May Have Been Factor in Fatal Accident
DOC.TEXT: Loud stereo music may have prevented a school bus driver from hearing a locomotive warning horn moments before the train and bus collided, killing him and a young passenger, authorities said. A side-view mirror on the bus also may have impaired the driver's vision and contributed to Friday's accident at a railroad crossing in downtown Miltona, officials said Tuesday. But the crucial factor in the crash was the driver's apparent failure to stop at the crossing as required by state law, said Douglas County Sheriff Terry Eilers. ``If he would have come to a proper stop as school buses are supposed to and taken a look, this accident would not have happened,'' said Eilers. ``You can put all kinds of possible causes and factors and probabilities into it, but unless the driver obeys the law and makes sure the track is clear, the other factors don't mean much,'' said Eilers. Driver Fred Beman, 66, and Kristian Rindahl, 9, of rural Carlos, were killed in the crash. Twenty-one students were injured. Eilers said mechanical difficulties had been ruled out as a possible cause after a preliminary investigation. He said a full report was expected in three to five weeks. The use of stereos on school buses and school bus driver training procedures will be reviewed, said Paul Tschida, state commissioner of public safety.

DOC.HEAD: Fox Cancels `American Chronicles'
DOC.TEXT: The future of the Fox series ``American Chronicles,'' the newest television offering from the makers of ``Twin Peaks,'' is up in the air, Fox Broadcasting Co. and its crew said Wednesday. ``People are picking up their final paychecks,'' segment producer David Jones said. But Fox said the show had not been canceled and that no decision had been made to end the series. ``It's not canceled,'' said Fox spokesman Brad Turell. ``We haven't decided whether we will pick it up'' for additional episodes. ``American Chronicles,'' a surreal travelogue from ``Twin Peaks'' creators Mark Frost and David Lynch, debuted this fall and fell to last place in the A.C. Nielsen Co. ratings. The program mixed music and video as it catalogued bits of Americana from decidedly skewed angles. The show has traveled to New Orleans for Mardi Gras, to the Lone Star state for the Miss Texas Pageant and to Sturgis, S.D., for the 50th Annual Bikers Convention. The last installment of the show's 13-episode contract is scheduled for Dec. 22. Members of the show's staff said they weren't told if Fox will air all 13 segments.

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Vatican Profited From Birth Control Pill Sales
DOC.TEXT: The Roman Catholic Church benefited financially from the sale of birth control pills, according to a German television report Wednesday night. Citing internal documents from the prosecutor's office in Milan, the report said the Vatican Bank in the late 1960s held a majority of shares in the Rome-based pharmaceutical firm Serono, which began producing birth control pills in 1968. That same year, the Roman Catholic Church reaffirmed its opposition to artificial birth control in Pope Paul VI's encyclical ``Humanae Vitae.'' The report came from the German news magazine Stern and was broadcast on the private television station RTL Plus. According to Stern, the Vatican Bank by 1970 had sold its shares in Serono to a Milan-based bank, which the report identified as Banca Unione. But the Vatican Bank had 20 percent of the shares of the Milan bank and so profited indirectly from the sales of birth control pills, according to the report.

DOC.HEAD: Another Batch of Eye Drops Found Contaminated With Different Bacteria
DOC.TEXT: Another batch of locally made eye drops was found to be contaminated, but with a different bacteria than the strain that caused infections so bad that two people lost eyes, hospital officials said Wednesday. The eyedrops in both cases were sold under the brand name Indocin by Hieber's Pharmacy during the second half of this year. In the most recent case, Eye & Ear Hospital found several strains of bacteria in three bottles of Indocin eye drops a suburban Pittsburgh man bought at the pharmacy in July, August and September. Results of tests to determine the origin and type of the bacteria were expected Friday, said hospital spokesman Mark Kanny. Prelimary test results ruled out pseudomonas, said Kanny. That highly toxic strain, found in a batch of the drops believed to have been made in October, caused at least 12 people to be hospitalized with eye infections, two of whom required surgery to remove the infected eye, he said. ``It appears one type of bacterium appears in two bottles and that some bottles have more than one bacterium growing in them,'' Kanny said. It wasn't clear if the bacteria were introduced during the manufacture of the eye drops, Kanny said. In the newly reported case, the bacteria were found in three bottles of Indocin purchased by Karl Smith, 60, of Aspinwall, with a prescription written by his ophthalmalogist. Smith began taking the drops in July and complained of pain and redness in the eyes in October. His doctor told him to decrease the dosage. When the pain continued, he sought treatment Tuesday at Eye & Ear's emergency room. ``It's like burning in the eyes, like fires in my eyes,'' Smith said Wednesday. Indocin is an anti-inflammatory agent commonly taken orally to treat patients with arthritis or osteoarthritis. Several Pittsburgh area doctors have prescribed its use in eye drop form, which was mixed at Hieber's, to reduce swelling following cataract surgery. Although not illegal, Indocin has not been approved by the Food & Drug Administration for use in eye drops. State and federal officials are investigating how the drops became contaminated and why Hieber's, allegedly without proper registration, was providing them to doctors and other pharmacists for resale to patients. Pittsburgh area officials earlier this month issued a recall of all eye drops containing Indocin or the generic equivalent indomethacin.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Urges Security Council Meeting; Bush Arrives in Mideast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Bush meeting Fahd and al-Sabah. Picks up 4th graf, `In Baghdad...' and trims thereafter
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DHA2
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Wednesday urged the U.N. Security Council to meet immediately on the gulf crisis, and French President Francois Mitterrand said a resolution backing military force against Iraq could be adopted within a month. President Bush arrived in Saudi Arabia, where he met King Fahd and Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, Kuwait's exiled emir. He planned to spend Thanksgiving with American troops deployed under operation Desert Shield and to meet Friday with Syrian President Hafez Assad. In Baghdad, Western officials said Iraq had agreed to release 157 Europeans it is holding. Many have said Saddam Hussein's policy of gradually releasing hostages is designed to break the world alliance against Iraq. Before flying to Saudi Arabia, Bush wrapped up a three-day visit to Paris where he had gone to attend a European security meeting. The Paris conference on peace in Europe, however, was dominated by talk of war in the Middle East. Bush had hoped to win Soviet backing for a Security Council resolution on using military might to drive Iraq out of Kuwait, which it invaded on Aug. 2. But the Soviets stopped short of supporting any such action. Bush tried to dismiss talk about a conflict of opinion, saying he and Gorbachev saw ``eye to eye'' on the subject of Iraq's occupation of Kuwait. He said any differences between the superpowers were ``extraordinarily minor.'' When asked if the United Nations might act this month on a resolution to use force against Iraq, Bush said: ``Stay tuned. There's certainly a chance.'' On Wednesday, Gorbachev seemed to move closer to Bush's position. The Soviet president urged a Security Council meeting be held ``without delay to discuss the situation'' in the Persian Gulf and ``take a decision there.'' But Gorbachev did not say what any U.N. meeting might discuss, or when the council might meet. At U.N. headquarters in New York, Soviet and U.S. officials said they had received no instructions on the matter. In Paris, Mitterrand said a U.N. resolution authorizing the use of force against Iraq was needed. ``We are prepared to discuss it,'' he said, reiterating France's declared readiness to talk about such a resolution. ``As far as its being put into effect, that's another matter. There is nothing automatic.'' He said the resolution ``should be adopted within the next three weeks.'' Resolutions already approved by the Security Council impose a trade embargo on Iraq, urge Baghdad's unconditional withdrawal, insist upon restoration of Kuwait's deposed government and demand Iraq free Western hostages. Iraq is holding hundreds of Westerners, many as human shields at strategic sites to deter attack by the multinational force arrayed against Iraq. Others have been released to visiting foreign dignitaries. French right-wing politician Jean Marie Le Pen, who arrived in Baghdad on Sunday, will take 83 European hostages to Strasbourg, seat of the European parliament, a member of his delegation said Wednesday. Le Pen belongs to the European Parliament, which is scheduled to discuss the gulf crisis on Thursday. Captives to be allowed to leave with Le Pen on Thursday included Britons, Italians, Germans, Irish, Dutch, Danes, Belgians, Portuguese and a Greek citizen. The head of a Swiss parliamentary delegation said an additional 36 hostages would leave Thursday on a Swissair charter flight to Zurich. Those captives were Swiss, Irish and British. Also Wednesday, the head of personnel for foreign workers at Ibn al-Bitar Hospital said 38 mostly Irish staff members would be allowed to leave, although it was unclear when they could go. Bush began his Middle Eastern tour in an effort to build the alliance against Iraq and bolster the morale of U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia. He said he would tell U.S. troops they were ``not there on a mission impossible.'' On Thursday, Bush was to spend Thanksgiving in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, with the 250,000 U.S. troops deployed there. It was to be the first visit by a U.S. president to front-line troops since Richard Nixon went to Vietnam in 1969. Bush was also to meet in Cairo with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak and then on Friday in Geneva with Assad. It would be the first meeting between a U.S. and Syrian president since President Carter met Assad in 1977. Syria is a hard-line Arab state accused by the State Department of sponsoring international terrorism and suppressing human rights. But relations have warmed since Syria joined the U.S.-led coalition against Iraq in August. The Syrians have promised 15,000 troops for the 350,000-strong multinational force arrayed against Iraq. They face an estimated 460,000 Iraqi troops deployed in southern Iraq and Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Council Agrees To Let Pension Fund Decide on Emergency Loan to City
DOC.TEXT: The City Council voted 11-6 Wednesday to authorize the city pension board to grant a loan back to the city, which is due to run out of money next month. The emergency council meeting was attended by labor leaders who fear the effect a loan to the city with its low credit rating would have on a $1.5 billion pension fund. ``We're very much interested in helping the city find funding sources, but not through our pension plan,'' Les Yost, president of Philadelphia Fire Fighters Union, Local 22, International Association of Fire Fighters, said Tuesday. The ordinance passed Wednesday does not order the pension board to make the loan but removes a ban on such loans. The board has hired an attorney to look into the legal issues. Mayor W. Wilson Goode and other Democratic leaders recently urged the sale of $250 million to $300 million in short-term notes to keep city coffers from running dry in December. The pension fund normally would not be allowed to invest in such notes because the city's credit rating has fallen below junk-bond levels to the lowest among major U.S. cities. The council vote allows the board to invest in Philadelphia notes, regardless of quality, until July 1. ``The pension fund is the linchpin of a cash financing at this point,'' Finance Director Elizabeth C. Reveal said last week. Pensioners and city employees counting on future pensions bombarded council members to protest the plan. ``They don't trust the mayor,'' Councilman Francis Rafferty said. ``That's the main beef. They're so afraid of this guy, and their pension is the only thing they've got left.'' Rafferty co-sponsored the legislation, but changed his mind and voted against it.

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin Says 15 Soviet Republics Can't Wait for Union Treaty
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with legislator asks Gorbachev's resignation, further Yeltsin quotes, details, minor editing. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MOSB1
DOC.TEXT: Boris N. Yeltsin said Wednesday the 15 Soviet republics could no longer wait for approval of a new union treaty and were proceeding on their own to create an economic union separate from the Kremlin. Also Wednesday, Victor Alksnis, leader of a group of right-wing legislators, threatened to call for Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev's resignation next month unless he ``begins at last to carry out his promises to prevent a breakup of the country,'' the newspaper Sovietskaya Rossiya reported. The developments amounted to the harshest indictment of Gorbachev since he proposed Saturday to dump his prime minister, Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, and revamp the executive branch under his presidential control. Russian President Yeltsin signed his republic's fourth bilateral treaty with another republic Wednesday, after saying earlier he could not be forced to accept Gorbachev's proposed union. That treaty would redefine the relationship between all 15 republics and the central government. Yeltsin's comments came as he continued butting heads with Gorbachev. Their divergent plans for saving the economy and for holding this nation of 285 million people together have paralyzed power in their rival governments. Yeltsin is more popular domestically than Gorbachev. Wednesday's actions indicated he was moving faster to consolidate his support among the republics while refraining from taking a stand on specific points of Gorbachev's plan. The Supreme Soviet legislature gave Gorbachev's proposals initial approval, but will consider them further Friday. Yeltsin and Nursultan Nazarbayev, president of the Central Asian republic of Kazakhstan, signed a treaty Wednesday to set up direct economic, political and cultural ties. Yeltsin signed a treaty Monday with the Ukraine and treaties earlier with Moldavia and Georgia. The five republics constitute more than two-thirds of the Soviet population and most of its raw materials. Other republics have signed bilateral treaties, but Russia is the focal point as the strongest republic. Yeltsin said officials planned to sign a treaty with Byelorussia in weeks. ``These bilateral treaties could constitute a major, solid foundation for the future signing of a new union treaty,'' he told a news conference in the Russian republic headquarters. ``They have to be signed to prevent chaos in the economy. They will be a salvation, because personally, I don't believe the union treaty will be signed in a week, in two weeks, in three weeks, even a month.'' Gorbachev, interviewed by French and Soviet TV reporters Wednesday in Paris, was asked if he could form a ``government of national unity'' with Yeltsin. He replied that he, Yeltsin and all Soviets ``are all tied together with our responsibility for the destiny of the country, and this ought to determine positions taken by each of those people who were positioned to lead those changes as a result of a democratic process.'' ``I don't see any obstacles for cooperation on the basis of the understanding of this responsibility.'' On Saturday, Yeltsin had said he would consider a ``coalition'' government with Gorbachev. Alksnis, leader of the 500-member Soyuz group of parliamentarians, said he and some colleagues would demand Gorbachev's resignation unless he showed progress on solving the country's problems during his address to the Congress of People's Deputies session starting Dec. 17. Alksnis said his group had not yet taken an official stand on the subject, but added ``this is not only my personal opinion,'' Sovietskaya Rossiya reported. What action Alksnis had in mind was unclear. Parliament rules require a two-thirds vote by the 2,250-member body to ``recall'' the president. Alksnis also said the group wants Vadim Bakatin to resign as interior minister. Bakatin came under fire from many republics for dispatching Interior Ministry troops in areas hit by ethnic violence. Yeltsin told reporters earlier Wednesday at the opening of a historical exhibition that Gorbachev's proposed strengthening of the national presidency seemed to be ``prepared in a hurry, probably as a result of the debates in the Supreme Soviet, or prompted by the staff of the Supreme Soviet or presidential aides.'' ``But they are not exactly logical, not quite consistent, for one thing, and for another such things should be discussed and adopted taking into account the will of the republics,'' he said, without elaboration. He said the union treaty would be signed only if Russia's ``real sovereignty'' is assured, either by the national president or the legislature, and if issues are resolved over ownership of the republic's bounty of gold, diamonds, oil, gas and other natural resources.

DOC.HEAD: New Poll in Poland Puts Dark Horse In Second Place
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Mazowiecki, Walesa rallies. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WAR52
DOC.TEXT: A new poll Wednesday put a previously unknown emigre in second place in Poland's first popular president election, behind Lech Walesa but ahead of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki. But the same survey, published days before Sunday's vote, indicated Mazowiecki could pick up enough votes to beat Walesa if they had to engage in a two-candidate runoff. The dark-horse candidacy of wealthy businessman Stanislaw Tyminski, who has returned to Poland after 21 years of making his fortune in Canada and Peru, created a sensation in Polish news media. One commentator said Tyminski risks making Poland ``the laughing stock of the world'' if he wins. Prosecutors have announced a slander investigation into Tyminski's charge on Saturday that Mazowiecki committed treason against Poland by creating economic chaos. But Tyminski continued his sharp attacks while on the stump Wednesday, saying he supports a wave of labor strikes against authorities. With campaigning required to end at noon Friday, Walesa was making a last dash around the country and Mazowiecki, direct from the Paris summit, drew one of his largest crowds to an evening rally in Warsaw. ``I believe we will win in these elections!'' Mazowiecki told more than 5,000 people at Warsaw Polytechnic Institute. ``There is no magic wand, there are no short cuts'' to repair Poland's economy, he warned. He arrived in a horse-drawn cart he was coaxed into sharing with four young women for a campaign picture. Solidarity chief Walesa, campaigning in Zamosc, said it would be ``something horrible'' to be in a runoff with Tyminski. ``He offers sausage to some people and they think he will save Poland,'' he said. ``One must have some background, one even must have been in prison here. One simply must have been living here.'' The government polling service's random survey of 1,490 people indicated Walesa had 27 percent of the vote, Tyminski 20 percent and Mazowiecki 17 percent. The remaining three candidates shared a total of 12 percent, and 24 percent were undecided or did not plan to vote. If no candidate wins more than 50 percent of the vote, the top two finishers face a Dec. 9 runoff. The poll indicated that if Walesa and Mazowiecki were in a runoff, 39 percent of those surveyed would vote for Mazowiecki and 36 percent for Walesa. The polling agency said its survey was conducted Saturday and Sunday, before the controversy over Tyminski gathered strength, and has a 2 percent margin of error. ``I think the election results will not reflect the polls, on the presumption that Poles are clever,'' said Piotr Nowina-Konopka, who resigned as an undersecretary to outgoing President Wojciech Jaruzelski on Wednesday to endorse Mazowiecki. Nowina-Konopka was Walesa's longtime adviser before moving to Jaruzelski's chancellory last year. Suddenly in the spotlight, Tyminski was being questioned about his international business dealings, his past in Canada and Peru, his long absence from Poland and his leadership of the ultra right-wing Libertarian Party of Canada. ``Poland used to be the conscience of Europe and now we have a chance to become the laughing stock of the world,'' Gazeta Wyborcza editor Ernest Skalski wrote in a front-page commentary. ``If Tyminski gets into the second round, Poland will stop being treated seriously.'' Appearing before thousands of supporters in Belchatow, Tyminski said he was being ``fiercely attacked'' because of his standing in the polls, according to the state PAP news agency - ``However, I am not afraid that they will find something in my past.'' PAP quoted Tyminski as saying he would ``support every strike,'' referring to recent labor unrest among miners and transit workers demanding higher wages refused by the government. Walesa and other candidates have tried to quell strikes at least until after elections. Tyminski gets free television and radio advertising time under newly democratic Poland's evenhanded election law. The press has tried to give roughly equal news coverage to all six candidates. Because he was given almost no chance, Tyminski escaped criticism until now. Tyminski, 42, describes himself as a self-made millionaire who left Poland penniless and made fortunes in Canada and the Amazon port of Iquitos, Peru. According to his campaign, he runs Transduction Ltd., a suburban Toronto computer automation company. He leads the Libertarian Party of Canada, a fringe party that has no representatives in Parliament.

DOC.HEAD: No Charges Filed Against Dallas Commissioner at Center of Racial Tensions
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors announced Wednesday that they would not pursue criminal charges against a black county commissioner whose dispute with a Hispanic policeman inflamed racial tensions. The district attorney's office decided not to try to bring Dallas County Commissioner John Wiley Price to trial on an arrest in March for painting over billboards with tobacco and alcohol ads in predominantly black neighborhoods. Price previously was allowed to take six months' probation in the sign-painting without the case going to trial. But after an incident in which a policeman accused him of pointing a submachine gun Nov. 5, prosecutors sought to revoke that probation and a judge agreed to hold a hearing that could have led to a trial and conviction. Price, who at one time issued a ``call to arms'' over the choice of a police chief, and police Officer Robert Bernal reached a truce during 12 hours of talks late Tuesday and early Wednesday. Bernal emerged from the talks saying he wanted the district attorney to drop the case, and a grand jury later agreed. ``Both Commissioner Price and Officer Bernal wish the incident had never occurred and apologize to the citizens of Dallas that their actions contributed to discord at a time when the city needed harmony,'' Price and Bernal said in a joint statement Wednesday. Bernal had told his superiors that Price pointed an Uzi gun at his head in retaliation for an insult the officer yelled at Price as he jogged past the commissioner's home. Price contended he was holding a pellet gun, which he denies pointing at Bernal. For his part, Price said: ``Officer Bernal is probably one of many police officers who have been thrust into communities that they probably know nothing about and have frustrations that are mounting.'' Acting Police Chief Sam Gonzales said an internal affairs investigation into Bernal's conduct was continuing. But he indicated discipline for Bernal could be tempered by his efforts to resolve his dispute with Price. ``We would be remiss if we didn't look at what he may have done to ease the tensions in this city,'' Gonzales said. Bernal's lawyer, Bob Baskett, said Wednesday he was not surprised that police would continue their internal investigation. ``It causes me no concern ... because we are confident that such an investigation will not result in any disciplinary action against (Bernal),'' he said. Some civic leaders have said the recent discord surrounding the incident could threaten a Dec. 8 vote on a proposed single-member-district city council system that proponents say would allow minorities more voice in the city's government.

DOC.HEAD: New Southern Command Chief Takes Over
DOC.TEXT: Gen. George A. Joulwan took over as chief of the U.S. Southern Command on Wednesday and vowed to help Latin American nations fight drug trafficking and terrorism. The vice director of the U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff, Adm. David E. Jeremiah, formally gave the command to Joulwan in a ceremony at Howard Air Force Base near the Panama Canal. He replaces Gen. Maxwell Thurman, who directed the military invasion of Panama last December. Thurman has retired after 37 years of military service. Joulwan told his audience that drug trafficking is ``a threat for the Latin American region and for the United States,'' and said the U.S. is ready to help local nations combat it. Joulwan, a Vietnam combat veteran who has also served in Europe and Washington, is responsible for all U.S. military activities in Latin America. Taking part in the ceremony were Panamanian Vice Presidents Ricardo Arias Calderon and Guillermo Ford, as well as U.S. Ambassador Deane Hinton.

DOC.HEAD: United States Renews Call for Democracy in Burma
DOC.TEXT: The State Department sharply accused Burma's military government Wednesday of persecuting two opposition leaders who this week were sentenced to 10 years in prison. ``We are dismayed by the sentences ... we strongly condemn this action,'' department spokesman Richard Boucher told reporters. ``We again call upon the military authorities in Burma to release political prisoners and to heed the overwhelming call for parliamentary democracy of the May elections,'' he added. The two who were sentenced, Kyi Maung and Chit Khaing, officials of the National League for Democracy, ``are clearly being persecuted by the regime in a further effort to negate the results of the national elections in May which the league won by a large margin,'' Boucher said. The league won more than 80 percent of the 485 seats in the national parliament. The arrest and sentencing of the two opposition leaders has been described as the Burmese military's toughest move thus far against the party which has been prevented from taking office. Kyi Maung and Chit Khaing were among the successful parliamentary candidates of the National League for Democracy. Political sources in Rangoon have reported that authorities have arrested at least 50 other members of the party, including about 15 elected to parliament, since the end of October.

DOC.HEAD: Fans Crowd in for Ava Gardner Auction
DOC.TEXT: Ava Gardner's many pairs of shoes sold briskly at an auction of the late actress' effects Wednesday that netted $678,000. Ms. Gardner, the sensous star of ``Show Boat,'' ``The Barefoot Contessa,'' ``On the Beach'' and scores of other films, died in January at age 67. She had lived in London since 1968. The 78 pairs of shoes were sold in six lots. One lot of 10 pairs, including Gucci loafers and stilettos by other designers, went for $1,270. The highest-priced item was a Louis XVI-period French bureau table, made about 1785, went for $73,300 dollars. ``There were many private buyers present who wanted a memento of a very beautiful actress,'' said Nigel Semmens, the auctioneers' spokesman. None of the buyers was identified. A man who paid $4,700 for an embroidered matador cape in ivory satin said it was a 21st birthday present for his daughter.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rules No Plagiary from `Gone With the Wind'
DOC.TEXT: An appeals court overturned a lower ruling and said Wednesday that French novelist Regine Deforges' best-seller, ``The Blue Bicycle,'' is not based on Margaret Mitchell's 1936 epic ``Gone with the Wind.'' A civil court in Paris ruled last December that the work borrowed heavily from the American Civil War romance classic. It ordered Miss Deforges and her publisher to pay $400,000 in damage to the Trust Company Bank, which manages the rights to Miss Mitchell's works. But Appeals Judge Myriam Ezratty said ``The Blue Bicycle,'' the first volume of a trilogy published from 1982-84 by Editions Ramsay, was ``not even a partial plagiarism'' of ``Gone with the Wind.'' The ruling said, ``The theme of a young girl who falls head over heels in love with a man who loves another woman, and at the same time is loved by a man older than she, is hardly original.'' Miss Deforges told a reporter last year, ``I know what plagiarism is, and it's a very bad thing. From the beginning `Blue Bicycle' was intended to be a pastiche. I never said it was suypposed to be anything else.'' Her book, set in Nazi-occupied France, has sold at least 6 million copies. French law forbids plagiarism, but permits pastiche, which it defines as a humorous take-off or remake of a recognizable original text.

DOC.HEAD: 4.3 Million Threatened With Famine, Ethiopia Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `The United ..' to RESTORE dropped word to show 1 million civilians trapped
