DOC.HEAD: Biodynamic Farmers Combine Organic Farming, Philosophy
DOC.TEXT: ``C'mon girls,'' a man in the doorway of the dairy barn shouted. ``Come o-o-on, get in here!'' From the dirt path came the steady sound of hooves and the lilting melody of a Japanese song. The Brown Swiss cows, horns intact, came around the corner first. Behind them was Yumiko Kan, swinging a short stick and singing. She came from Japan to Camphill Village Kimberton Hills for a three-year training course in biodynamic farming. She's learning to treat cows with homeopathic medicines, grow crops without chemicals, enrich soil by burying manure in cow horns and understand cosmic rhythms. The farmers and trainees, from all over the world, also come for a chance to live communally and provide a social service. Roughly one-third of the 130 people who live and work at Kimberton Hills, including the man in the dairy barn, are mentally handicapped. The farm, about 30 miles west of Philadelphia, is owned by Camphill Village U.S.A. The land is farmed without pesticides, herbicides or artificial fertilizers. Farmers rely on crop rotation, composting and a ``living'' soil to produce healthy crops. The 420-acre farm has fields of corn, wheat, oats, barley, soybeans and hay. Vegetable gardens, orchards and hilly pastures for sheep and cows complete the landscape. Not many farmers understand or accept the biodynamic approach and its combination of science and spiritualism. ``The few who have (heard of biodynamic) refer to it as cow (dung) and horns,'' said Roger Wentling, an agronomist. ``It's not a viable option to them.'' But Wentling, who worked several years for the federal Soil Conservation Service, said he has seen the benefits, citing a farm couple who used several methods to grow oats. ``The oats they had looked good until I got to see the biodynamic oats,'' he said. ``I've never seen oats look that good, and I've walked farms for over 10 years.'' There are about 100 biodynamic farms in North America, with pockets in Pennsylvania, North Dakota, Northern California, New England and Wisconsin, said Rod Shouldice, director of the national Biodynamic Farming and Gardening Association, based in Kimberton. Shouldice said the largest concentration is in southern Ontario, where government policies allow biodynamic farms to operate more profitably. Biodynamic farmers say their methods are discriminated against by U.S. subsidy programs, which reward single-crop agriculture and a high use of chemicals for increased yield. There are signs of change, however, as support grows in Congress and the Department of Agriculture for what is known as low-input sustainable agriculture. LISA seeks to reduce the use of chemical pesticides and fertilizers, thereby reducing farmers' costs and damage to the environment. A section of the 1990 farm bill authorizes $40 million a year to pursue these methods, an eightfold increase over the previous bill. ``A lot of it has to do with the changing perspective of the public that chemicals need to be reduced in our environment,'' said John Haber, staff member of the Senate Agriculture Committee. Howard Kerr, director of the USDA's Office of Small Scale Agriculture, resents the attention, and funding, given to LISA. ``If it works for them, we should support them,'' he said. ``But to say it's the path for everybody, I don't buy that.'' Cost-effectiveness is difficult to measure, Kimberton Hills farmers said, bristling even at the question. ``And who will pay the cost of groundwater pollution?'' asked Michael Wildfeuer, the dairyman. ``Biodynamics puts value back into the land.'' The aim of organic farmers has never been to produce the most for the least amount of money, and the issue is further complicated at Kimberton Hills. The farm is part of the international Camphill movement of 75 communities worldwide. The handicapped people work the farm and benefit from being contributing members of the community. The dairy is the center of the farm's operation. ``Cows are magic,'' he said. ``They go out and eat grass, and then they come back and give milk. They make manure and they give meat. They give back to the land and to humanity.'' In return, Wildfeuer said the farm's 30 dairy cows live as naturally as possible. They graze in large pastures and keep their horns. In conventional dairies, horns are usually removed to prevent cows from hurting one another when kept in close quarters, he said. The preparations are what many people focus on, perhaps because they sound mysterious and strange. In one preparation, fresh cow manure is packed into cow horns and buried for six months during the winter. When the horns are dug up, the manure has become compost, changing in a way it would not change if it were not in a horn, said Jim Barausky, who manages the field crops at Kimberton Hills. Barausky said one horn is prepared for each acre. The compost is combined with water, stirred for an hour in a vortex and then sprayed on the fields in the evening. ``It stimulates root hairs - that's been pretty clearly demonstrated,'' he said. ``It makes a big difference in plants, especially if there's a drought that year.'' Barausky is sensitive to what he said is too much emphasis on the preparations. He said biodynamics was one of the earliest forms of organized organic agriculture and pioneered many methods, including composting, which have since become standards. What has kept biodynamics apart, Barausky said, is its philosophy. Biodynamics grew out of a series of lectures given in 1922 in Silesia, a region in southwestern Poland, by the late Rudolf Steiner, a philosopher known for anthroposophy, meaning wisdom of man. Barausky said biodynamics incorporates science and spiritualism. Scientific research has been used to prove some biodynamic methods, he said, but unlike laboratory experiments, plants do not respond the same way for everyone. ``It seems to be something else that's involved there, which then people don't understand, and therefore it opens this whole realm of questions,'' he said. ``Some of the questions go into what people call the occult ... almost superstitions, which I think biodynamics doesn't want to fall into.'' Despite the criticism, the farm sells most of the crops it produces and three-fourths of the milk, Barausky said. The milk is not pasteurized or homogenized, and he said there is a larger market for raw milk than the farm can supply.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Studying Expanded Uses of Oil Eating Bacteria
DOC.TEXT: The use of oil-eating microbes has become an accepted and safe method of cleaning up oil spills, but not a panacea, researchers say. Scientists who used fertilizers to speed the biological degradation of Alaska's massive oil spill are pleased with the way bioremediation worked there. They are skeptical at best, however, about claims of overnight success on a spill in the Gulf of Mexico and the performance of laboratory-grown, rather than natural, bacteria. ``It's not a magic cure,'' said James Clark, an aquatic biologist at the Environmental Protection Agency lab in this panhandle barrier island community. ``There are times when it won't be very effective.'' Clark represents EPA in a joint program with Exxon and the Alaska Department of Environmental Conservation. It began last year after the tanker Exxon Valdez spilled nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil in Alaskan waters. In 1989, fertilizers were applied to 74 miles of shoreline to make oil-eating microbes already present grow and devour the crude faster. It was the first time bioremediation had been used on a U.S. spill and the largest such project ever undertaken. Prior uses have included treatment of sewage and hazardous wastes. ``The monitoring and research show that it had no adverse ecological effects. We saw no algae blooms, no toxicity to the fish,'' Clark said. ``The basic understanding of increasing the bacteria by adding nutrients is going to be an accepted technique.'' Bioremediation, however, represented only a fraction of the cleanup effort in Alaska, where 1,245 miles of coastline had been coated with oil. Studies show nitrogen and phosphorous fertilizer, some of it just like that used on lawns and gardens, increased the degradation rate by 30 percent to 50 percent, Clark said. That still means it could take from a few weeks to four years, depending upon the amount of oil present, to complete the decomposition, he said. The next step in the laboratory and at spills is to see how bioremediation strategies may vary from site to site. ``We may have to use different kinds of fertilizers or do something different in the Gulf of Mexico than Alaska,'' Clark said. Texas officials in July claimed a major success for bioremediation. They applied 100 pounds of laboratory-produced microbes to one acre of an oil slick in the gulf from the June 8 explosion of the supertanker Mega Borg, 57 miles off Galveston. It was the first time bioremediation had been used in open water. Texas Land Commissioner Garry Mauro said surface oil was reduced by 30 percent in some samples a day after the application, while no such reduction was found in an untreated portion of the slick. ``We remain skeptical of the results,'' Clark said. ``Our studies have shown oil degradation occurs in the course of days and weeks, not hours. It's very hard for us to understand how it would degrade overnight.'' Clark called the controversy ``a touchy issue'' for EPA, which officially says more research is needed about bioremediation at sea. A blunter assessment came from Jim Mueller, a microbiologist for Southern BioProducts, an Atlanta-based bioremediation company EPA has hired to help with research. ``I don't think it worked. I think they sank the oil,'' Mueller said. ``Studies we have done with very high concentrations of organism, optimum nutrient, optimum temperature, (show) it still takes days and weeks.'' Experiments are under way with two brands of commercially grown microbes, but preliminary evidence shows they are no better than natural bacteria, Clark and Mueller said. On the other hand, research on new ways to apply fertilizers has been promising. In Alaska, a special oil-attracting fertilizer known as Inipol EAP 22, made only by the French company Elfe Aquitaine, was sprayed in liquid form. Garden-variety water-soluble fertilizer was applied in granular form with lawn spreaders. While Inipol has been more effective in cleaning up visible oil, water-soluble fertilizers are better at seeping below the surface. Mueller is experimenting with simply hosing down oil-tainted shores with water-soluble fertilizer in liquid form. ``Potentially what we can do is get on a boat with a fire hose and just blast the beaches with soluble nutrient, let the rocks bathe in it during low tide,'' he said. That would make application simpler and cheaper. Bioremediation already costs less than most other cleanup methods. Bioremediation in the past has cost about as fourth as much as incineration for cleaning up hazardous waste sites, Mueller said. Clark figured the price difference would be at least that much for oil cleanups in which the alternatives include physically wiping off rocks or dumping them in landfills.

DOC.HEAD: Physicist Claims Einstein's Wife Helped Develop Theory of Relativity
DOC.TEXT: Albert Einstein's letters, and the example of couples like the Curies, contributed to the belief that his theory of relativity was a collaboration between Einstein and his first wife. Evan Harris Walker, a research physicist at the Army's Aberdeen Proving Grounds, said there are a dozen instances in which Einstein referred to ``our work'' in letters to his first wife Mileva Einstein-Maric. ``It becomes clear from what he has to say himself that Mileva played a significant role in the early work,'' Walker said recently. Several Einstein historians disagree. But Louis Pyenson, a science historian at the University of Montreal, said such a collaboration would not be unusual considering the number of other well-known husband and wife scientific teams at the turn of the century, including Marie and Pierre Curie, known for their work in radioactivity. Walker said his theory also would help solve a puzzle over the development of his landmark theory. Einstein denied later in life that previous work on the speed of light by the American physicist Albert Michelson influenced his work. Walker said the influence likely came from Einstein-Maric. In one letter, Walker noted, Einstein wrote: ``How happy and proud I will be when the two of us together will have brought our work on the relative motion to a victorious conclusion.'' The letters were part of the Einstein papers published in 1986 by Princeton University, where he worked for several years. The theory of relativity was the foundation for much of physics since Einstein published three groundbreaking papers in 1905 that eventually led to his winning the Nobel Prize in 1921. The theory deals with the relationship between time and space and proposes that time moves slower for objects traveling at greater speeds. ``I don't see that there's any evidence she contributed in the way they claim,'' said Clifford Will, a physics professor at the McDonnell Center for Space Science at Washington University in St. Louis. ``I guess they looked at some of the letters and tried to infer she was involved. ``Part of this is the myth that Einstein needed help with mathematics, and there is simply no evidence in his career that this is true,'' Will said. ``The mathematics in relativity is simple. All that was needed to develop the theory was physical insight, the brilliant physical insight that Einstein had.'' Einstein-Maric, a mathematician and physicist, was several years older than Einstein, who was in his early 20s when he began work on relativity, and may have been the leader early on, Walker said. The two met as students at the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Zurich and were married in 1904, a year before Einstein published the three papers. Strengthening Walker's case is their 1919 divorce agreement, in which Einstein agreed his former wife would receive any Nobel Prize proceeds Einstein might win. The case for her role also is bolstered by a German research linguist, Senta Troemel-Ploetz, of the German Research Society in Bonn. She reported reading an account by the late Russian physicist, Abram Joffe, who said he had seen the original manuscript of the paper on special relativity with the names of Einstein and his wife on it, Pyenson said. Walker said Einstein-Maric studied in Heidelberg, Germany, where Michelson had visited several years earlier. ``Without Michelson, the problem the theory of relativity would have answered wasn't there. That's why physicists said the theory was puzzling,'' Walker said. ``Mileva was on the scene and had access to information of that sort and she probably played the role of inseminating those ideas.'' Light, like other waves, had been thought to require a medium, dubbed the ether, to travel through. Some physicists theorized that because Earth was moving through this substance it would slow down or speed up light, depending on the direction the light was traveling in relation to the ether. Michelson's experiments in the late 19th century compared the amount of time it took two beams of light pointed in different directions to travel from their source, bounce off a mirror and return. Despite repeated attempts at increasing distances, the times were always the same, confusing scientists. Einstein's 1905 paper on the photoelectric effect of light disproved the ether theory. ``On one paper she helped with the mathematics, and on the papers on relativity and light, she did something very fundamental,'' Walker said. ``That she helped is beyond question. It's the degree of help.'' Einstein-Maric studied under Phillip Lenard, a German physicist, and most likely brought to Einstein's attention Lenard's work on light, Walker said. ``It is true we don't have any direct evidence for precisely which equation Einstein's first wife told Albert about. That kind of information is seldom available,'' Pyenson said. ``What does seem clear, and there is no question, is the pattern of young physicist couples in the 1900s is a clear trend in Europe,'' he said. ``All you have to do is look at the Curies.''

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Learning the Gift of Gab
DOC.TEXT: Barry Alpert is learning that the gift of gab can be as critical to his medical practice as skill with a scalpel. Doctors say poor communication with patients is a leading cause of missed diagnoses. Lawyers say the problem is cited in many malpractice lawsuits. ``A lot of malpractice cases go away simply because they like the doctor,'' said Pittsburgh attorney Edwin H. Beachler III. Alpert, a cardiologist at West Penn Hospital in Pittsburgh, said he can't evaluate his own communications skills. But he said patients have come to him after having difficulty dealing with other doctors. He said he suspects some of his own former patients may have the same complaint about him. Alpert is not alone. Roughly 80 percent of 300 doctors surveyed nationwide by the pharmaceutical division of Miles Inc. regard effective communication with patients as ``extremely important''; only one-third said they communicate ``very well.'' ``A lot of physicians are exceptionally sensitive about their relationships with their patients,'' Alpert said. They don't want to be told how to conduct their practice. In an effort to improve his abilities, Alpert took part in a seminar offered by Miles at West Penn earlier this year. The four-hour program has been presented this year at two dozen hospitals, medical schools and health maintenance organizations around the country. Vaughn Keller, who led the Pittsburgh session, told doctors part of the problem stems from differences in background. Physicians are trained to rely on a rigorous decision-making process in making a diagnosis, Keller said. Patients, on the other hand, rarely get right to the point with physicians, said J. Gregory Carroll, a corporate training specialist at Miles, a West Haven, Conn., company. ``A patient may start by telling a story about lower back pain and may be warming up to something they're not ready to talk about,'' Carroll said. ``The patient may wait 'til the end of the interview, when he has his hand on the doorknob, to say, `Oh, by the way, doctor, should I be worried about this swelling. ...''' Doctors need to be able to recognize when a patient is hedging and should try to draw out relevant ``pieces of the clinical puzzle,'' he said. ``It's not just an educational gap. It's really two different world views,'' Keller said. Terminology can be a problem, too. eller urged seminar participants to encourage their patients to be more open about medical problems and said doctors should give specific instructions for medication, exercise, therapy and other treatment. The extra effort Keller and Carroll prescribe can have benefits for doctors. Several attorneys said better relations can reduce a physician's chance of being sued for malpractice. ``The doctors who don't get sued are the ones who take the time to explain, `This could happen or this could happen' and give their patients what we call informed consent,'' said Beachler. ``Without exaggeration, in half if not three-quarters of these cases, one of the complaints these people have is they don't like the way they were treated.'' A typical patient's hospital stay might involve seeing four or five doctors. ``Sometimes, you feel like you're on a conveyor belt,'' said Pittsburgh attorney John C. Conti, who represents physicians. In the last decade, many medical schools added courses designed to teach students how to conduct efficient discussions with patients. ``It's one of those things that people used to say, `Well, you pick it up,'' said Dr. Stanley K. Dorst, who teaches a required course, introduction to patient care, at the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine. Dorst disagrees that communication is ``part of the art of medicine'' and can't be taught. ``It's a skill and you need to practice it.''

DOC.HEAD: French Physicist Named To Head San Francisco Exploratorium
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Goery Delacote is cq
DOC.TEXT: French physicist Goery Delacote has been named director of the Exploratorium, the city's innovative science museum. Delacote, 51, leader of the scientific research team that created La Villette, the French government's new sciece and technology museum in Paris, will join the museum in January. He said he hopes to expand the museum in the Palace of Fine Arts into a major international center to help foster understanding of nature and art and appreciation of scientific discovery. The Exploratorium was founded in 1969 by the late Frank Oppenheimer, with whom Delacote formed a close friendship. Oppenheimer's creative exhibit builders designed 50 interactive displays at La Villette. ``Now is a good time for a Frenchman to pay back some of what Frank Oppenheimer gave to my country,'' Delacote said. Robert L. White, a Stanford engineer, resigned in December and became a member of the Exploratorium's board of trustees. ---
DOC.HEAD: Seven Panthers Die, Captive Breeding Pushed
DOC.TEXT: The deaths of seven endangered Florida panthers this year have wildlife officials pushing for a captive breeding program by early next year. Three of the seven were killed in fights with other panthers, two died of infections and one was killed crossing a road. One cause of death hasn't been determined. Two deaths were particularly critical because the cats had ``founder'' genetic material, meaning they had some of the purest genetic material available and haven't been subjected to inbreeding, said Dennis Jordan, Florida panther coordinator for the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service in Gainesville. ``In terms of the goal of the program, to protect existing genetic material, we've lost some,'' Jordan said. Under the program, about half the existing Florida panthers would be captured for breeding programs at zoos and private preserves. That, some biologists say, could prevent the extinction of the cats. No more than 50 panthers are believed to exist, most of them in southwest Florida. Biolgists had hoped to begin capturing panthers last spring, but began reassessing the program after environmentalists complained that wildlife agencies were rushing into the project without proper studies.

DOC.HEAD: Genentech President's Wife Settles SEC Action
DOC.TEXT: The wife of Genentech Inc.'s president has settled insider trading allegations that she tipped her brother about confidential merger talks the company was holding with Roche Holding Ltd. According to the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mollie E. Raab did not trade for herself, but her brother told a friend who allegedly made some $127,400 in illegal profits. Genetech completed a merger with Roche in September. Without admitting or denying wrongdoing, Mrs. Raab, of Hillsborough, Calif., agreed to pay $162,400 in penalties and interest to settle a civil action filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission at federal court in San Francisco on Tuesday. Neither Genentech, nor Mrs. Raab's husband, G. Kirk Raab, chief executive officer of the San Francisco-based pharmaceutical and biotechnology company, were accused of any wrongdoing. ``Mrs. Raab did not profit on the stock trades,'' Raab said in a statement issued by Genentech. ``She knows it was wrong to have told her brother, who was having prolonged financial difficulty, and she accepts her penalty. We are both sorry for any embarrassment this incident has caused to Genentech and its employees,'' the statement concluded. Also settling with the SEC were Mrs. Raab's brother, Michael Gaylord Painter, and one of his friends, Joseph Jeffries, both of San Antonio, Texas. Some of the circumstances in the case resemble the controversial insider trading case against broker Robert Chestman in New York. A federal appeals court overturned Chestman's conviction earlier this year on the grounds there was insufficent evidence Chestman knew information he got from a family member of the Waldbaum supermarket chain owners about a pending merger with A&P was confidential. The government is appealing that court decision. ``Though the issues framed for litigation would have been interesting, Mr. Painter was not required to disgorge any money or to pay any penalty, and under the circumstances he decided to dispose of the matter rather than engage in costly litigation,'' said his lawyer, Washington attorney Richard Morvillo. But Harry Weiss, an associate director of the SEC's Enforcement Division, said the misappropriation theory used in the Raab case ``is not an issue in the Chestman appeal.'' In the Chestman case, said Weiss, the issue is the proof the government must offer to establish whether a person getting a confidential stock tip knows the tipster is illegally violating a trust or duty. In the Raab case ``we're alleging sufficient evidence to establish the exisitence of a relationship and a breach of that relationship,'' said Weiss. Mrs. Raab ``is not an officer of the company but she has a relationship of trust and confidence with her husband, the breach of that duty is the misappropriation (with which she was charged).'' Weiss noted that in any event, the defendants settled without going to trial. The SEC alleged that Jeffries made about $127,400 in illegal trading profits using the information Painter got from his sister with the understanding that the two men would split it, although lawyers declined to say whether Painter actually ever took possession of any of the profits. The SEC also alleged that Jeffries also told other people who made an additional $70,000 in trading profits. They were not accused of insider trading because there wasn't enough evidence to conclude they knew the information had been stolen, said Weiss. As part of the settlement, however, Jeffries will pay $133,700 in illegal profits plus interest. The government waived additional penalties for him and Painter after they gave sworn statements that they were unable to pay. Although there was no allegation Mrs. Raab, traded illegally for herself, under the Insider Trading Sanctions Act, however, she could have been ordered to pay penalties equal to the profits made by those she tipped. The $162,400 she will pay was part of the negotiated settlement, said Weiss. According to the SEC complaint, Mrs. Raab learned about the merger negotiations from her husband and sometime between Jan. 22 and Feb. 2 she told her brother to buy a few thousand dollars worth of Genentech stock, saying ``buy now'' even if he had to borrow money. She told her brother ``good things were about to happen to Genentech,'' and that he should keep his purchase and her comments confidential, according to the SEC. At the time, Genentech stock was trading at about $21 a share. Painter, in turn, told Jeffries, who bought option contracts to buy Genentech securities which he agreed to split with Painter. An option contract is an agreement to buy stock at a later date for a fixed price. If the price of the stock goes up before the contract date, the buyer makes the difference in profit.

DOC.HEAD: Thanksgiving Worst Time Of Year For Bassett's Turkey Stores
DOC.TEXT: Most people in the turkey business love November. Not Roger Bassett, owner of Bassett's Original Turkey fast-food restaurants. When home-cooked Thanksgiving leftovers make such good sandwiches at home, ``why would you pay $5 for a sandwich'' at one of his restaurants? The answer, he said, is they don't. Sales usually drop 50 percent for three days following the holiday. But Bassett said he understands. ``You have a wonderful dinner at home and you make sandwiches with the leftovers,'' he said. Bassett's Original Turkey has grown from a small oven set up at a Sundae bar to a nine-restaurant chain in Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Maryland and Virginia. The latest franchise opened to brisk business last week at a mall in downtown Philadelphia. Bassett, 29, stood back and watched the people line up to buy his cold sandwiches and his hot opened-faced platters. ``People like turkey,'' he said. ``People are tired of pizza and cheesesteaks.'' Bassett is a fifth-generation member of the century-old Bassett's Ice Cream Co. He originally carried on the family's tradition of selling ice cream. When he was 19, he opened a small sundae bar in Philadelphia's Reading Terminal Market. His father visited the market on a regular basis, but grew tired of eating greasy hamburgers and sloppy pizza. ``So he asked me if I would fix him a turkey sandwich whenever he came in,'' Bassett said. After setting up a small oven at the ice cream stall, Bassett wandered through the market and bought tomatoes, lettuce, bread and a turkey. ``I cooked a turkey sandwich for him,'' he said. ``Then some guy saw him eating and asked where he got the sandwich. The next day I cooked two turkeys. They sold out strictly on word of mouth.'' He finally gave in and bought the equipment to make turkey sandwiches on a larger scale. The business was an immediate success, he said. Within five years, he opened up three more stores of his own. In 1989, Bassett sold his ice cream stand as more malls wanted his turkey in their food courts. He turned to selling franchises for the next five stores. Bassett will concentrate on the Northeast first, but wants to sell franchises nationally in five years. ``I've already got offers in California, Florida, and Canada,'' he said. He said his menu is perfect in mall food courts because it offers an alternative for health-conscious consumers. Pat Glickman agreed as he sat down to eat the turkey sandwich he just bought. ``I love turkey,'' said Glickman, 26, of Philadelphia. ``It's healthier for you than McDonald's or Burger King.'' Another customer, Jennifer Landis, said she had passed Bassett's Turkey stores several times without stopping before she gave in and ordered a platter. ``One of my favorite lunches is an open-faced turkey sandwich,'' said Landis, 32, of suburban Jamison. ``I enjoy it. At home I eat it a lot.''

DOC.HEAD: Treasury Chief Asks Regulators to Soften Lending Policies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady broke his public silence on the so-called ``credit crunch'' with a plea to regulators to soften their crackdown on bank lending. ``Be mindful of the effect your behavior can have on the willingness of banks to take even the reasonable risk of lending to good credits,'' Brady said Tuesday in remarks directed at the nation's bank examiners. ``We need a banking system that is a taker, not a shedder, of such risks,'' he said. A text of the speech, delivered to the Arthritis Foundation in New York, was released in Washington. Brady also signaled that the administration wants the dollar to stop falling. His comments on the credit crunch come amid growing concern that banks' reluctance to lend is holding back an already weak economy. President Bush conducted a series of meetings last week, discussing the economic lull with top advisers, senior regulators and business executives. Bankers and some business owners have complained for nearly a year that regulators were cracking down too hard in the wake of the savings and loan debacle. Regulators responded that they were simply urging prudence in response to more fragile economic conditions, particularly in the commercial real estate industry. Brady conceded that ``traditional lending standards applied by many banks clearly eroded'' during the long economic expansion of the 1980s. But, he cautioned, ``To the regulators, I'd like to say publicly what I've said privately many times: use some judgment. Apply some balance. Don't use unrealistically negative scenarios in evaluating loans. Don't overreact.'' A Federal Reserve survey of lending officers released Monday found that bankers were becoming increasingly cautious about making loans, not only to commercial real estate developers, but also to large corporations and home buyers, two types of borrowers generally considered safe. ``Let me offer a word to banks,'' Brady said. ``I urge you to keep lending to your good customers. ... Let's not overreact to the economy or to the regulators. ``Your franchise depends upon your continued willingness to stand by your customers. I urge you not to walk away from those whose trust you have worked so hard to earn.'' Some banks have come under pressure to cut back lending by the need to meet stricter capital standards taking effect in January under an international agreement. But Brady said banks had alternatives, including cutting costs, reducing dividends or seeking a merger partner. Brady also sought to calm fears about the condition of the banking industry, saying, ``The banks of 1990 are not the S&Ls of the 1980s. They are as different as chalk and cheese.'' He said banks have a capital cushion of $200 billion to absorb losses, 6 percent of their assets, compared with $10 billion for S&Ls in 1987, or 1 percent of their assets. Regarding the dollar, Brady said the deficit reductions in the 1991 budget adopted by Congress last month ``should promote renewed and welcome stability in exchange markets.'' And, he said, ``policies that promote stability in the dollar exchange rate are a plus, not just for the United States, but for the world economy at large.'' Until Tuesday's speech, Treasury officials have expressed little concern about the dollar, which has been declining for most of the year and is trading near post-World War II lows against the German mark. It also has fallen sharply against the Japanese yen. A weak dollar worsens inflation in the United States by driving up the cost of imports, but it improves the U.S. trade performance by making American goods cheaper on overseas markets.

DOC.HEAD: United Receives Its First Boeing 737-500
DOC.TEXT: United Airlines says it has taken delivery of the first of four Boeing 737-500s it expects to use on routes into and out of its hubs in Denver and San Francisco. The 737-500 is a slightly shortened version of the Boeing 737-300 and seats 108 passengers. United announced Tuesday plans to put the planes into service this year. The airline said that by the end of the year, its operating fleet will reach an all-time high of 462 planes. United has 556 new aircraft on order and option, including a $22 billion order for Boeing 747-400s and Boeing 777s announced last month.

DOC.HEAD: Senior Ranks Shuffled At Honeywell
DOC.TEXT: Honeywell Inc. has streamlined its top management by reducing to three from six the number of top executives who report to chief executive James Renier and form the company's top policy-making committee. The changes had been in the works for several months, spokeswoman Susan Eich said Tuesday. The three, who were named to the company's board of directors, are: -Christopher J. Steffen, 48, executive vice president and chief financial and administrative officer. Steffen has been credited with masterminding much of the successful restructuring at Honeywell in the past year and a half - selling assets, spinning off defense operations, buying back shares and cutting costs. -D. Larry Moore, 54, executive vice president and chief operating officer for space and aviation operations and for industrial automation businesses. Moore has been the head of space and aviation, the company's fastest growing business. -Michael R. Bonsignore, 49, executive vice president and chief operating officer responsible for international operations and for the homes and buildings business. Bonsignore has been the head of international operations, where much of the firm's growth has come in recent years. The move gives broader duties to the three executives, who will control Honeywell operations and report to Renier. Earlier this year as many as six executives filled those roles. Honeywell is a global controls company that provides products, systems and services for homes and buildings, industry, and aviation and space. The company had 1989 sales of $6.1 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Closes After 69 Years
DOC.TEXT: The Lisbon evening newspaper Diario de Lisboa will close at the end of November after 69 years of publication, the editor said Wednesday. The daily is the latest victim of a Portuguese press crisis that has seen eight major daily and weekly papers close in the past two years. Chief Editor Antonio Ruella Ramos said Wednesday the last issue of Diario de Lisboa will hit the streets Nov. 30, after negotiations with the Projornal media group failed to find a formula to save the paper. The center-left tabloid was reportedly loosing 18 million escudos, or $138,000, a month and circulation had fallen to 10,000 from almost 30,000 in 1987. Ruella Ramos blamed the closure on a contraction of the Portuguese advertising market, a lack of state funding and a change in reading habits away from afternoon papers. In the 1960s, the Diario de Lisboa was one of the few papers to challenge the strict censorship imposed by rightist dictator Antonio Oliveira Salazar. After a 1974 revolution restored Portuguese democracy many leading journalists of the newly-freed press came from Diario Lisboa. The Portuguese press boomed at the end of the 1980s. But the market was unable to sustain the increasing number of titles in this country where almost 20 percent of the 10.3 population is illiterate. The center-right government is hoping to boost the press by privatizing state-owned papers. Several titles have been sold and the last remaining state-owned paper, the prestigious Diario de Noticias, is scheduled for privatization early next year.

DOC.HEAD: Union Wants Right To Match Offers for Steel Division
DOC.TEXT: If USX Corp. decides to sell off its steel business, the United Steelworkers union wants the right to match any offer the company receives. The union asked during contract negotiations for the right to equal any bid made by potential suitors. The union represents 18,000 USX employees. The union's chief negotiator, Andrew V. ``Lefty'' Palm, said Tuesday the USW wants to know more about the company's long-range plans for its steel business. ``Are they going to keep it in one piece? Chop it up? Spin it off?'' Palm asked. ``We're concerned about speculators coming in ... who could care less about our jobs, our community.'' Financier Carl C. Icahn has pressured USX to sever its cyclical steel business from its more profitable energy unit, which accounts for about 70 percent of the company's revenue and operating income. Icahn, USX's largest stockholder, thinks his 33.9 million shares would be worth a lot more if the steel business were shed. Last week, Icahn threatened to nominate his own slate of directors at USX's annual meeting in May unless the company quickly moves to restructure its steel business. Options include selling the steel division, in whole or individual plants, or spinning it off into a separate company and selling all or part of the stock. USX announced three weeks ago that its board had authorized the conversion of the steel unit into a wholly owned subsidiary. Chairman Charles A. Corry said the move gives USX ``the flexibility for any steel restructuring.'' Palm said the union's request to match offers for the steel division must be dealt with before there can be agreement on a contract to replace the one that expires Feb. 1. No date is set for resuming the talks, which broke off after the two sides failed to meet a self-imposed deadline on Nov. 10. The union said it would swing the deal through an employee stock ownership plan, a buyout technique that gained favor in the 1980s, particularly in the steel industry. Weirton Steel Corp. was created in 1984 when the West Virginia steel maker's 7,700 employees bought the company from National Steel for $386 million. Other employee-led buyouts in the industry include Northwestern Steel and Wire of Sterling, Ill., Republic Engineered Steels of Massillon, Ohio, and Pittsburgh Forgings. USX spokesman Thomas Ferrall declined to comment on the union's request to match any offer for the steel unit, but many analysts believe USX would balk at such a deal. However, several said the success of other steel employee stock ownership plans, pressure from Icahn, the softening steel market and other factors might force USX to accede to an employee buyout.

DOC.HEAD: Honda's U.S. Workers Get $1,712 Profit-Sharing Checks; Big Three, None
DOC.TEXT: Honda of America Manufacturing Inc. is handing out average profit-sharing checks of $1,712 for each of its hourly and salaried workers. The Big Three U.S. automakers, meanwhile, forecast no such check for their workers. About 9,400 workers at Honda's assembly and component factories in Marysville, East Liberty and Anna, Ohio, last week received the payments based on profits for the 1990 fiscal year, company spokesman Jeff Leestma said Wednesday. The payments are based on a formula computed from a variety of figures, including worldwide pre-tax income and the size of the work force. The Big Three automakers, which reported a combined $2.1 billion loss for the third quarter of this year, have said profit-sharing checks for their 650,000 or so eligible employees are in doubt. General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. compute their profit sharing checks on profitability of the companies' North American operations for a calendar year. When profits allow, profit-sharing checks are delivered in the spring. Last year, Ford workers got an average of about $1,025 each, GM employees got an average of $50 and Chrysler workers got none. The largest profit-sharing checks were handed out by Ford in 1988 when the average eligible employee got $3,700.

The stock market was little changed today in an indecisive preholiday session. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 1.48 to 2,531.68 in the first half hour of trading. But losers slightly outnumbered gainers in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 460 up, 496 down and 509 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 22.69 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Little economic news of any moment was expected on the eve of Thanksgiving. Trading was expected to taper off through the session as traders got an early start on the holiday. Stock prices have rallied briskly in recent weeks as hopes have mounted for lower interest rates. But analysts said traders seem reluctant to join too enthusiastically in the upswing until they can get a better fix on the likely extent of the recession. Among actively traded blue chips, Boeing rose 1\ to 43~; Coca-Cola gained ] to 46}; International Business Machines dropped [ to 113\, and American Express was down [ at 20]. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks edged up .05 to 172.53. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .59 at 295.42. On Tuesday the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 35.15 points to 2,530.20. Declining issues outnumbered gainers by about 2 to 1 on the NYSE, with 508 up, 1,028 down and 461 unchanged. DOC.HEAD: Out of the Frying Pan: Ex-Cook Becomes President of Restaurant Company
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto NS1 of Nov. 21
DOC.TEXT: When James W. Arnett flunked out of college and went to work as a Shoney's Inc. cook flipping burgers and stirring soup, the thought of running the company was the last thing on his mind. But in his 20-year career at Shoney's, Arnett has gradually moved from the frying pan of a kitchen into the fire of a big-business boardroom, making decisions that affect 28,000 employees in a network of restaurants and hotels in 30 states. ``I guess it's easier to teach somebody when you know how to do it yourself,'' said Arnett, 41. ``I said awhile back that I'd still like to be a teacher. Somebody pointed out that's what I do today.'' Arnett's elevation to president and chief operating officer of Shoney's, announced last month, is unusual in an era when companies usually fill top executive positions with number-crunching MBAs. Many executives don't necessarily have experience on the assembly line, shop floor or in this case, the kitchen, where Arnett began toiling in 1970 for a minimum wage. ``I worked hard,'' Arnett said in a recent intervew in his office at Shoney's Nashville headquarters. ``I took out the trash, swept, mopped, whatever it took.'' Arnett said his self-imposed discipline stems from flunking school and anxiety over becoming a loser in life. He was living with his parents when his casual attitude about studying and grades resulted in a near-zero grade point average at Tennessee Tech in Cookeville, a 90-minute drive east of Nashville. ``I think I made a C in something,'' he said. Arnett's father, a retired Marine Corps sergeant major, demanded repayment of $1,400 in tuition money and ordered his son to get a job. He found one at Shoney's, a growing chain of restaurants known for its Big Boy burgers and for pioneering the family style ``breakfast bar'' buffet. ``There's no doubt in my mind that fear of failure is what keeps Jim Arnett motivated,'' Arnett said. His father, he said, ``literally picked me up and carried me to work every day.'' Arnett gave most of the earnings from his 80-hour week to his father, eventually repaying the $1,400. At the same time, Arnett said, he discovered something he could do well. He soon became kitchen manager, then store manager before working his way up into the higher levels of the company. Shoney's has since grown into a large publicly held company that owns and operates 1,600 restaurants and motels including Shoney's Restaurants, Shoney's Inns, Captain D's fast-seafood chain, Lee's Famous Recipe Chicken, Fifth Quarter and Pargo's restaurants. Six feet tall and slightly overweight ``due to sampling our foods all the time,'' Arnett says he enjoyed his early cooking career and still makes occasional forays into a company kitchen. Just a few weeks ago, for example, he did a stint at a Captain D's to assess its efficiency. ``The reason is sometimes you have a tendency to overcomplicate things,'' Arnett said. ``You have to keep it simple to put the food out in a reasonable amount of time.'' Arnett's appointment has been widely praised among securities analysts who follow Shoney's, which is under pressure from a large debt load and must seek ways to economize and become more efficient. Arnett's experience in everything from menu planning to mixing vegetable soup gives him an advantage. ``In our opinion, that was the correct move for the company,'' said John Lawrence, of Morgan Keegan & Co. in Memphis. As the No. 2 executive, Arnett is heir-apparent to Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Leonard H. Roberts. Shoney's founder Ray Danner, who retired as chairman but is still on the company's board and executive committee, said Arnett ``was a good kid. And now he's a great man.'' ``I would say he has all the ingredients to maybe one day be a CEO of the company. In my opinion, he certainly has the qualities,'' Danner said. Arnett credits his success to simple hard work. ``I still consider myself an employee. I'll go around pouring coffee,'' he said. ``If you don't go to the stores, you're making your decisions in a void. It's easy not to go to the stores. It would be easy to have a fancy office.'' Arnett's office is not fancy. It has a desk, work area, five chairs and no paintings on the walls. Instead, a wall near his desk holds framed copies of the goals of Shoney's divisions, along with a statement of the company's business philosophy. ``Our philosophy is you can't run a business from an office,'' he said. Arnett declined to disclose his salary, though he said it was close to the compensation of predecessor Gary Spoleta, who according to the company's latest proxy statement earned $388,202 in fiscal 1989. That's a far cry from the $1.25 an hour Arnett pulled in 20 years ago. ``Let me put it this way,'' Arnett said. ``I owe more money now than I did then.'' The company plans to more than double its operations to 3,400 motels and restaurants - mostly Shoney's family style restaurants and the Captain D's and Lee's chicken fast food outlets - by 1995. Despite signs of a economic sluggishness that is huring many restaurant companies, Shoney's still anticipates a big jump in sales this year from the $860 million it earned a year ago. ``I'm positive. Other leaders will say their sales will by down 4.2 percent this year,'' Arnett said. ``And they'll hit their goals. We're looking for $1 billion.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Sunday, Nov. 25

DOC.HEAD: Big Accounting Firm Files For Bankruptcy Court Protection
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to UPDATE with bankruptcy case filed. Picks up 2nd graf pvs, ``A series ...''.
DOC.TEXT: Laventhol & Horwath, the nation's seventh-largest accounting firm, filed for bankruptcy protection today under the weight of lawsuits seeking damages for allegedly faulty audits. The firm filed a Chapter 11 bankruptcy case in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in New York, said Jaimie Walthour, a clerk in the court. Under Chapter 11 of the U.S. bankruptcy code, a company seeks to reorganize its operations while it remains in business. ``A series of tragic circumstances brought this proud firm to this sad day,'' Robert Levine, the firm's executive partner and chief executive officer, said Tuesday. Levine blamed the collapse on high litigation costs and the increasing number of lawsuits being filed against accounting firms. The lawsuits were filed primarily by businesses challenging audits or by shareholders contending they received faulty financial information. The company reportedly had to pay nine creditor banks at least $30 million last year, of which only $18.5 million was covered by insurance, over its auditing of the Grabill Corp. of Chicago. Laventhol's audits of Jim Bakker's PTL ministry are the subject of an ongoing trial in Charlotte, N.C. ``Most accounting firms are suffering from high litigation costs and our firm is no exception,'' Levine said on Tuesday. ``Because of the raised expectations of plaintiffs and the popular misconception of auditors as all-seeing and all-knowing, the number of lawsuits against accounting firms has skyrocketed.'' The firm had 4,200 employees - 360 of which were partners in the firm - in its 50 offices across the country. Laventhol reported $350 million in domestic revenue last year. Response in the firm's offices nationwide was diverse. ``We will close,'' said Nick Iacuzio, department head of accounting and auditing for the firm's Boston office, which let its 160 workers go. ``It's very devastating, there's a lot of sadness and grief.'' Offices in Ohio, Connecticut and Philadelphia also folded, but partners and senior executives in the Kansas City, Mo., office say they plan to open a firm of their own. Stanley H. House, managing partner in Kansas City, said the new firm will be known as House, Park, Morriss & Co. In Tampa, Fla., two Laventhol partners have already set up their own firm, Aidman, Piser, and Co. ``It's certainly very hectic right now, but we've gotten enthusiastic support from our clients,'' said Philip C. Piser who is setting up the new firm with Terry Aidman. They had previously headed Laventhol's audit and tax practice departments in Tampa. The firm's 360 partners could remain liable for debts created by the national firm, said Leslie D. Corwin, an attorney and partner in the New York City-based law firm, Morrison, Cohen, Singer & Weinstein. Once assets are sold off, whatever liabilities are left after the firm's insurance pays off becomes the responsibility of the individual partners, Corwin said. Two of the Laventhol's largest clients praised the accounting firm's work even while they scrambled to find new accountants. Ed Ashburn, accounting controller for Trans World Airlines Inc. in suburban New York, said Laventhol handled the airline's audits for the past four years. ``If they are unable to perform the audit work, we should not have any difficulty in awarding the contract to another firm,'' he said, adding that TWA has received several offers from other accounting firms. Chicago-based Hyatt Corp. had worked with Laventhol for 15 years, said Hyatt spokeswoman Karen Rugen, but is now reviewing other firms to do its year-end audits.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 347.02 down 1.27 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Once-Thriving Puerto Rico Tuna Industry in Deep Trouble
DOC.TEXT: Puerto Rico's tuna canning industry, which accounts for more than half of U.S. tuna processing, is struggling to stay afloat in a sea of Far East competition and efforts to save dolphins. This year, two of the island's five tuna canneries closed and a third reduced operations, putting about 2,000 people out of work. Puerto Rico is the center of the U.S. tuna packing industry, a $634 million-a-year business that at its height employed 8,000 people. Last year, 535,069 tons of tuna were processed in the United States - more than half of it in Puerto Rico, according to the U.S. Department of Commerce. Most of the tuna canned here comes from the eastern Pacific Ocean, where dolphin and tuna swim together. Dolphins are air-breathing mammals that drown when captured in nets along with tuna. In April, the three largest tuna canners in the world - Starkist, Bumble Bee and Chicken of the Sea - responded to an international outcry and said they would stop buying and selling tuna caught with dolphins. That led tuna fishing boats to move to the western Pacific and Indian Ocean, where tuna and dolphins swin separately, according to industry spokesmen. Companies say the expense of transporting tuna from those regions to Puerto Rico is too high to meet the competition. Also attracted by cheaper labor in the Far East, companies are relocating. In late July, Bumble Bee's plant in the Puerto Rican city of Mayaguez laid off 800 employees and said it was transferring part of its operation to Santa Fe Springs, Calif., and Thailand. ``This industry is labor-intensive. It will go where the rates are more beneficial,'' said Bumble Bee plant manager Pat Vella in an interview. In July, Van Camp, which cans Chicken of the Sea tuna, closed its plant in the southern Puerto Rican port city of Ponce and said it was moving operations to Indonesia and American Samoa. Neptune, the sole tuna cannery of the Japanese conglomerate Mitsui, closed its Puerto Rican operation in August. Puerto Rico is left with just three plants - Star Kist Caribe, the largest cannery in the world, the Mitsubishi-owned Caribe Tuna, and a scaled-down Bumble Bee. ``The main problem with the tuna industry is costs,'' said Jimmy Seda, a vice president at Neptune. Many fear such plant closings, if they continue, could topple Puerto Rico's tuna industry and hurt the island's overall economy. ``It would be catastrophic,'' said Jorge Orama Monroig, chairman of the Puerto Rico Senate's Treasury Committee, which is studying incentives for local tuna canneries. ``If an industry that big leaves the island, you're also going to have indirect job losses. In Mayaguez, it's an important part of the economy.'' In July, Star Kist and Bumble Bee were among the top 25 employers on the island, with Star Kist employing 5,900 workers and Bumble Bee 2,000. Puerto Rico, a U.S. Commonwealth, is subject to many U.S. laws. The minimum wage here matches the mainland's - $3.85 an hour. In Thailand, where much of the tuna is now being canned, it is about $2 to $3 a day. Seda said that with added expenses such as health insurance, workers here cost about $7 an hour. ``But it's not just wages,'' he said, adding that environmental and health regulations are less restrictive in Thailand than in the United States. ``Our waste water treatment plant alone was costing about $1 million to operate,'' he said. Lured by tax incentives and cheaper labor, the tuna canning industry expanded in this Caribbean island in the early 1980s when Star Kist, Bumble Bee and Van Camp closed their Pacific coast operations in California. American companies operating in Puerto Rico enjoy the benefits of a federal tax code provision that exempts them from paying federal income tax on profits earned by their Puerto Rican subsidiaries. Commonwealth officials are asking the International Trade Commission for higher tariffs on tuna imported to the United States. Under current tariffs, oil-packed tuna is taxed at a rate of 24 percent, while water-packed tuna, preferred by consumers, is taxed at 12.5 percent. ``If the United States does not review its import tariff policy, the whole industry here is going to be in trouble,'' said Seda, the Neptune vice president. Raul Velez, president of the Tuna Employees Association, is doubtful the lobbying will be effective because it faces opposition from the large tuna canneries themselves. Asian owners control the major tuna processors except Star Kist, so higher import tariffs are not in their interest, he said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Monday, Nov. 26

DOC.HEAD: Shadow SEC Second-Guesses Federal Market Regulator
DOC.TEXT: Who knows what evil lurks in the hearts of the Securities and Exchange Commission? The Shadow SEC thinks it does. The self-appointed panel of five - mostly free-market economists - intends to shadow and second-guess the real SEC, a presidentially appointed panel entrusted with keeping the stock markets fair and honest. The real SEC, an independent panel of five commissioners backed up by a staff of lawyers, accountants and economists, not only oversees the trading of stocks and bonds but oversees mutual funds and investment advisers - affecting the jobs, investments and futures of millions of Americans. At its first meeting in a swank Washington hotel, the Shadow SEC debated the real SEC's policies on two hot issues: the effect of program trading on stock market plunges and the voting rights of shareholders in takeover battles. The Shadow SEC voted for the elimination of a rule - approved this year by the real SEC - limiting index arbitrage, a form of program trading, on the New York Stock Exchange when the market rises or drops 50 points. The panel also called on the real SEC to revise rules governing shareholders' absentee ballots or proxies. Critics have called the body irrelevent or presumptious. Even those who think there is a place for a Shadow SEC think its role will be minor. Samuel Hayes, investment banking professor at Harvard University's business school, thinks the concept of economic criticism ``is an excellent idea. I just don't take too seriously the establishment of a regulator in exile.'' ``Frankly, I don't understand why some people are so upset about a Shadow SEC,'' said SEC Commissioner Philip R. Lochner. ``There are 1,000 conferences a year around the country on securities matters and this is one of them,'' he added. That's precisely the attitude the Shadow SEC, which includes 1990 Nobel Prize-winning economist Merton H. Miller and former SEC Commissioner Charles C. Cox, wants to change. Gregg Jarrell, a finance and economics professor at the University of Rochester and one of the shadow body's creators told reporters at the first meeting earlier this month: ``One of the big purposes of this is to spur greater progress in research among the academic community'' to create ``one more outlet besides the normal run of academic conferences. One that's a little different, perhaps a little more exciting.'' ``I don't know whether we'll reach the SEC itself,'' said Miller, who teaches at the University of Chicago. ``I think we will, but by a very indirect route.'' The SEC as an institution has no official position on its shadow self. Even Richard C. Breeden, the usually outspoken SEC chairman, declined to comment on the matter. But sources inside the commission say more than a few SEC feathers have been ruffled by the interlopers. Following its first meeting, SEC General Counsel James Doty needled the Shadow SEC in a speech to securities lawyers saying he was worried: ``Do they have a shadow general counsel, too?'' In an interview, Doty, said his speech was ``clearly facetious but it had a serious point'' about the importance of the private securities bar's input. ``There is room for all disciplines to comment on the law and the rules but I don't think economists can infer they have a superior vantage point, any more than lawyers can,'' he said. Meanwhile, the Securities Industry Association ``is totally against a Shadow SEC and believes it will be disruptive,'' said Art Samansky, a spokesman for the New York-based trade association. The Shadow SEC, sponsored by the University of Rochester's Simon Graduate School of Business Administration, is financed by the John M. Olin Foundation, IBM Corp., Twenty-First Securities Corp. and Mesa Limited Partnership, the firm of takeover strategist T. Boone Pickens. ``They're good people with basically a conservative economic viewpoint, trying to make sure everybody involved pays enough attention to economic theories in the regulation of the stock market,'' said prominent Washington securities lawyer Arthur Mathews. ``(But) I don't perceive it as a group that's going to have any power or particular influence.'' If the first Shadow SEC meeting had been a movie, it could have been called: ``The Revenge of the Economists.'' Panelists, noting that the five current SEC members are all lawyers, complained that statistical studies had been downplayed or ignored in the SEC rule-making process. In addition to Jarrell, Cox and Miller, who teaches at the University of Chicago, the Shadow SEC consists of Ronald J. Gilson, a law professor at Stanford University and Hans R. Stoll, a finance professor at Vanderbilt University. Steven Manaster, former chief economist for the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, now teaching at the University of Utah, heads the Shadow SEC staff. ``That's one hell of a line up,'' concluded Edward H. Fleischman, the only member of the real SEC to attend part of the shadow session. The reams of raw data presented was ``fascinating,'' he said adding: ``I think its very healthy for an organization, especially a so-called fourth branch of government agency, to be publicly to account - in a constructive way.'' Lochner, who did not attend the session but sent an observer, said ``economists have something to teach lawyers, but I think its kind of a foolish notion that we should wait until all the data is in, because all of the data is never in. You've got to make decisions with what's available at the time.''

DOC.HEAD: Prices Stabilize After Sharp Losses
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices stabilized this morning on the Chicago Board of Trade after Tuesday's sharp declines. The market is closely watching Persian Gulf developments and the interplay between President Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev. The theory is that the closer Gorbachev is to Bush's thinking, the more likely food aid or export credits becomes for the Soviets. On Tuesday, apparently seeking to dispel doubts about the Soviets' resolve on using military action, Gorbachev said the U.N. Security Council should address the situation in the Persian Gulf. In early trading, wheat was unchanged to \ cent lower with the contract for delivery in December at $2.45\ a bushel; corn was { cent lower to \ cent higher with December at $2.21} a bushel; oats were \ cent lower to } cent higher with December at $1.08 a bushel; and soybeans were 1 cent to 2{ cents higher with January at $5.70{ a bushel. At the Chicago Mercantile Exchange livestock futures were mostly higher while pork bellies were mostly lower. Live cattle were unchanged to .18 cent higher with the December contract at 79.25 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent lower to .07 cent higher with January at 87.67 cents a pound; live hogs were .25 cent lower to .23 cent higher with December at 53.30 cents a pound; and frozen pork bellies were .30 cent lower to 1.10 cents higher with February at 70.15 cents a pound. On Tuesday, livestock and meat futures were lower.

DOC.HEAD: Enigmatic Financier Rose Quietly, Fell Loudly
With PM-Milken
DOC.TEXT: Michael Milken climbed quietly to the mountaintop of American finance. His descent was much louder. Born and raised in California, Milken was a math whiz helping his father's accounting business by age 10. He studied arcane business tracts while others marched for civil rights and peace during the 1960s. In his early years on Wall Street, Milken digested financial documents during a two-hour commute. With the same passion, Milken avoided the limelight after gaining market prowess, shunning interviews and refusing to pose alone for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s annual report. Milken became a familiar figure only after named by speculator Ivan Boesky in the government's fraud investigation in late 1986. The most prominent financier in the securities industry in the booming 1980s, Milken became prosecutors' main target. His quirky personality and stupefying wealth have contributed to widely divergent public views of the 44-year-old financier. On the one hand, he is considered a financial genius, economic visionary and generous philanthropist who has enabled many businesses to prosper through his masterful selling of high-risk, high-yield ``junk bonds.'' On the other hand, Milken is an admitted felon whom some equate with the excesses of the takeo Iraq from Kuwait were ``on track.'' In addition to Bush's personal diplomacy, Secretary of State James A. Baker III met for several hours with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze to discuss the Persian Gulf conflict. The president, who has sought a tougher international stand against Iraq's Saddam Hussein, told reporters that ``I leave Paris feeling that we are still together as countries who want to see this situation reversed and want to see this man unilaterally get out of Kuwait.'' The president talked to reporters twice within two hours, once during a meeting with Greek Prime Minister Constantine Mitsotakis and again at the U.S. Embassy in Paris, where he spoke to officials. Both times, he sought to minimize any differences with the Soviets over a United Nations resolution authorizing force in the Persian Gulf. ``I'm encouraged, very encouraged about this holding together of a coalition in the sands and on the seas of the gulf,'' he said. Bush said he believes the United States is ``in good synchronization'' with other nations on how to cope with the Persian Gulf crisis. Asked whether he had set a deadline for Saddam to get out of Kuwait, he replied, ``Just watch the way all this develops. Everybody is convinced they must get out of Kuwait with no concessions, and that's what's emerging here.'' Asked if he was concerned about the risks of going into a potential combat zone, he replied, ``It really doesn't enter my mind at all. It is not a risky mission in my view. I'd tell you if I felt any tremors. I don't'' Bush spent three days in Paris for the 34-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, dealing with the future of Europe in the post-Cold War era. The Soviets did not rule out Bush's proposal for a U.N. resolution, but instead counseled patience. Gorbachev, interviewed on French television, said, ``All political leaders strive to avoid a military solution, but we cannot tolerate Saddam Hussein and his regime bringing the world community to its knees.'' He said the U.N. Security Council ``will make an analysis of the situation and will reach a well-considered solution.'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater refused to confirm a report that one resolution being discussed would call for automatic military action if Saddam did not withdraw within a few months. ``There are any number of approaches that are being considered. We will not comment on any one of them,'' he said. Resolutions already approved by the Security Council impose an economic boycott on Iraq and occupied Kuwait, call for Iraq's unconditional withdrawal and insist upon restoration of Kuwait's previous government. Even before one trip was over, Bush was planning a second. The White House said he would visit Greece and Turkey early next year. Meanwhile, U.S. and Soviet officials unveiled plans for a superpower summit in Moscow early next year to sign a treaty on reducing long-range nuclear weapons. Fitzwater said there was no firm date for the summit, although he said both countries were aiming for January. He said having a nuclear arms treaty to sign was a prerequisite for the summit, but holding the session in January ``is what we have been talking about and shooting for.''

DOC.HEAD: Stuart James Brokerage to Cease Stock Trading
DOC.TEXT: The brokerage Stuart James & Co. apparently will cease stock trading after Friday, turning over at least eight of its 23 retail branch offices nationwide to Chatfield Dean & Co. Chatfield Dean president Sandy Greenberg said Tuesday that the deal should be finished by Friday, and he hopes to have the leases for the branch offices on Monday. The Chatfield Dean agreement follows a National Association of Securities Dealers' order this month directing Stuart James to contract with an independent company to clear its cash and securities transactions for 100,000 customer accounts. Greenberg said his brokerage has contracted with an undisclosed New York clearinghouse. His seven-year-old company will absorb 150 to 250 of Stuart James' 800 brokers, he said. Chatfield Dean now employs 80 brokers, and another 15 are in training. Chatfield Dean is based in Englewood, a suburb of Denver. Greenberg said Chatfield Dean will not sell penny stocks, but will continue to concentrate on over-the-counter and mutual funds. Chatfield Dean has a ``much more conservative product mix'' than Stuart James, he said. C. James Padgett, Stuart James president, could not be reached by telephone for comment. But he was quoted in Wednesday's edition of the Wall Street Journal as saying the firm would no longer sell and trade stock as of Monday. The story said he blamed the slumping stock market but also said he sees no future in the penny-stock business. Stuart James was a leader in the sale of penny stocks, which get their name from their low prices and are traded over-the-counter.

DOC.HEAD: Santa Fe Sells 730 Miles of Track in Southwest to Private Rail Line
DOC.TEXT: Santa Fe Railway said Wednesday it has reached an agreement to sell 730 miles of track in the Southwest to the privately held Orient Railcorp. The terms of the deal were not disclosed. Santa Fe first announced its intention to sell the three segments of track - located in Oklahoma and Texas, and collectively known as the Orient Line - in February 1988. The segments involved are Cherokee, Okla., to Sweetwater, Texas; Sweetwater to Maryneal, Texas; and San Angelo Junction (Santa Ana), Texas, to Presidio, Texas. Orient Railcorp is a private corporation headed by Gary Kerley of Conroe, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Westinghouse Plans Energy Staff Cuts
DOC.TEXT: Westinghouse Electric Corp. plans to reduce the number of workers in its energy services division. Westinghouse spokeswoman Mimi Limbach said most of the reductions will be in management. ``We don't have a number to announce at this point,'' she said. The division employs 9,400 people, including 6,500 in western Pennsylvania. Last month, Westinghouse began offering retirement incentives for workers 57 and older, including a year's salary for those who terminated work by the end of the year. The division, which is based in suburban Pittsburgh, supplies and services nuclear and solar power plants and waste-to-energy facilities. Westinghouse does not itemize the sales or operating profits for the division in the company's financial results. The company said a downturn in the division's results did not prompt the cutbacks.

DOC.HEAD: British Steel to Buy Remaining 90 Percent of Tuscaloosa
DOC.TEXT: British Steel PLC said Wednesday it has agreed to buy the 90.4 percent of Tuscaloosa Steel Corp. it doesn't already own from the Alabama-based company's other shareholders. British Steel refused to disclose the price. Tuscaloosa, a producer of plate and hot-strip steel, was formed in 1984 as a joint venture between British Steel, Tippins International, O'Neal Steel and American Cast Iron Pipe Co. British Steel is the main supplier of semi-finished steel slabs to the Tuscaloosa mill. Tuscaloosa has annual sales of about $150 million and net assets of about $21 million, British Steel said.

DOC.HEAD: Criticism Mounts over Handling of Failed Black-Owned Bank
With AM-Deposit Insurance, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators' liquidation of tiny Freedom National Bank earlier this month has prompted a wave of protest from state and federal officials against what they call the government's double standard for insolvent institutions. In closing the bank, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. was unable to come up with a buyer. The FDIC's $100,000 limit on guaranteed deposits caused painful losses to many charities that invested money at the bank, one of two black-owned banks in New York. But critics assert the episode illustrates a federal policy that favors the giants and squeezes the meek. They say the FDIC has been much more accommodating to larger busted banks. This week, Rep. Henry Gonzalez, Texas Democrat and chairman of the House Banking Committee, and Rep. Charles Rangel of New York fired off separate letters to FDIC Chairman William Seidman asking for a full explanation of the circumstances surrounding Freedom's liquidation. New York state Attorney General Robert Abrams also wrote to Seidman asking him to reimburse charitable organizations with accounts in Freedom. Critics say that federal regulators, in their handling of hundreds of troubled institutions these past two years, have pursued an unwritten ``Too Big To Fail'' doctrine. Regulators, critics say, will go all out to save large banks to prevent repercussions from rippling through the financial community. Freedom's lack of political and economic clout, they say, made it a candidate for a less common option - Too Small To Rescue. ``Freedom's largest depositors stand to take substantial losses as a result of this kind of two-tiered policy - one for the larger banks and one for the smaller banks,'' said Stephen Verdier, senior legislative council at Independent Bankers Association of America, a group representing community-based banks. Following the Freedom liquidation, several large charitable groups - which provide programs including foster care, elderly services and housing assistance to crime victims - stand to lose hundreds of thousands of dollars in deposits. These depositors were under the mistaken impression that as long as each of their accounts did not exceed the $100,000 limit covered by federal insurance, their deposits would be covered. But last Friday the groups learned that the FDIC totaled all their accounts in applying the $100,000 cap. All told, roughly $11 million in 100 Freedom accounts exceeded the insurance limit, compared to about $80 million that was covered, according to the FDIC. Some of the charities assert that their separate accounts are actually being held in trust for different depositors, which may enble the FDIC to apply a separate $100,000 cap to each account. The FDIC is looking into these claims. Accounts of more than $100,000 often make it through a bank failure. In one recent case more typical of the way the FDIC handles insolvency, all depositors of the National Bank of Washington, D.C. - even those with accounts in a branch in the Bahamas - were able to recover their funds regardless of the size of their deposits. In this instance, the FDIC arranged a sale of the $1.5 billion bank to Riggs National Bank of Washington, which took over the failed bank's assets. In the process, the FDIC decided to cover $37 million in the failed bank's Nassau, Bahamas branch. The FDIC justified the decision at the time by saying it was meant to help soothe foreign investors, who account for a large percentage of deposits in big American banks. But the decision was vigorously opposed by small banks, which are being hit hard by increases in their deposit insurance premiums. ``These larger banks and particularly their foreign depositors are totally protected, while for small banks in the middle of depressed areas the FDIC finds it somehow more convenient just to liquidate them,'' said Verdier. The FDIC says that of the 153 troubled banks it handled in 1990, Freedom was one of only six for which the FDIC could not find buyers and had to liquidate instead. FDIC officials maintain they did all they could to find a buyer for Freedom, spending four weeks sifting through a list of 55 banks and investors, including minority banks and investors. ``In most instances four weeks is more than enough time,'' said FDIC spokesman David Barr. Just after the bank's failure was announced, New York City business leaders met to raise the $6 million needed to replenish the bank's depleted capital. But the FDIC says it was too late by then to consider the offer, because the bank had already been shut down, and the group of investors needed to obtain a bank charter to be considered. Critics, however, argue that the federal regulators should have tried harder to rescue the black-owned bank. ``What we are trying to investigate is why in this particular incidence, they chose a bank that is in an area that has a tremendous problem keeping any banks at all,'' said Peggy Miller of the Consumer Federation of America, a group representing depositors. ``Why suddenly in this particular case did they choose to get hard-nosed?''
