DOC.HEAD: Important Dates in Milken Case
With AM-Milken, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of key developments in the prosecution of former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. junk-bond chief Michael Milken: Nov. 14, 1986 - Stock speculator Ivan Boesky pays $100 million to settle charges of insider trading on information supplied by investment banker Dennis Levine. He agrees to cooperate with investigators and plead guilty to a single criminal charge. Boesky later is sentenced to three years in prison. Late 1986 - Published reports link Milken to an illegal insider trading network led by Boesky. Sept. 7, 1988 - The Securities and Exchange Commission accuses Drexel, Milken and three others of violating a wide range of securities laws, most in connection with Boesky. Dec. 21 - Drexel agrees to plead guilty to six felonies and pay a record $650 million in fines and restitution to settle the biggest securities fraud probe in history. March 29, 1989 - A federal grand jury indicts Milken, brother Lowell, and former Drexel trader Bruce Newberg on 98 counts of racketeering and fraud largely based on information supplied by Boesky. Potential penalties and fines total $12 billion plus possible prison terms. April 7 - The Milkens plead innocent. Newberg enters an innocent plea later. April 13 - Drexel and the SEC announce a settlement of the civil fraud case that subjects the firm to federal monitoring for three years and forces it to sever ties with Milken. June 15 - Milken resigns after 19 years at Drexel to form his own consulting firm. Lowell Milken quits to return to practicing law. Sept. 11 - Drexel formally pleads guilty to six felonies and begins paying its fine. Feb. 13, 1990 - Drexel's parent company files for federal bankruptcy court protection after defaulting on debts and begins laying off employees. March 19 - Prosecutors promise to bring a new indictment with broader charges against Milken by the week of April 16. April 4 - Boesky is released from federal custody after completing two years of a three-year term. April 19 - Four months of negotiations intensify between the government and Milken for a possible plea bargain to settle the case as a deadline looms for the new indictment. April 20 - Milken agrees to settle his case and reaches a plea bargain guilty plea with the government. April 24 - Milken tearfully pleads guilty to six felonies including conspiracy, securities fraud, mail fraud and assisting in the filing of a false tax return, carrying a total maximum sentence of 28 years imprisonment. Four of the counts directly involve Boesky. Milken also agrees to pay $600 million in restitution and fines and cooperate with the government after sentencing, set for Oct. 1. Sept. 24 - U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood orders pre-sentencing memorandums released to the public because of enormous interest in the case. Federal prosecutors urge her to give Milken a severe punishment, based partly on crimes Milken hasn't admitted. Defense attorneys ask Wood to consider only the six charges in his guilty plea and urge her to sentence him to community service. Sept. 27 - Wood delays sentencing to hold a special two-week hearing in mid-October to consider the government's array of unproven charges against him. She says the purpose of the hearing is to gain a greater insight into Milken's character in order to fashion a fair sentence. Oct. 11-25 - Eight days of testimony by more than a dozen government witnesses fail to link Milken decisively to lawbreaking in three transactions. Former Drexel employees describe secret bathroom conversations, cryptic orders, document destruction and questionable behavior, but hard evidence against Milken is scant. Ex-Drexel chief executive Frederick Joseph testifies against his star employee for the first time. Milken and Boesky do not take the stand. Oct. 30 - The defense, in written closing arguments, says the government failed to prove Milken guilty of the additional crimes. Prosecutors sat they proved their case conclusively. Nov. 21 - Milken is sentenced by U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood to 10 years in prison and three years of probation, during which he must do 1,800 hours of community service annually.

DOC.HEAD: Litton, Rockwell Join Long List of Companies Cutting Defense-Related Jobs
DOC.TEXT: Litton Industries, Inc., and Rockwell International Corp., have joined a growing list of major military contractors paring their workforces. Litton confirmed this week it eliminated 600 of its 6,000 jobs in Southern California from October 1989 to September. Defense facilities in Woodland Hills and Van Nuys were hit the hardest, losing 550 of 4,400 jobs, Litton spokesman Robert Knapp said. Also this week, Rockwell officials said the company had cut 161 union employees at its Rocketdyne division in Canoga Park. Rocketdyne's union membership accounts for about one-fifth of its 9,100-employee work force. A week ago, TRW Inc.'s Redondo Beach-based space and defense operations acknowledged eliminating 1,600 jobs, about one-tenth of the work force, through attrition and layoffs. Most of the layoffs were in California. All three companies acknowledged the layoffs and other job eliminations only after inquiries from newspapers, the last two in response to the Los Angeles Daily News. Because the numbers are relatively low and have taken place gradually, the companies are not required to announce the reductions formally. The cuts are further evidence of hard California's aerospace industry has been hit by cuts in defense programs. McDonnell Douglas Corp., Lockheed Corp. and Northrop Corp. announced plans over the last year to reduce their Southern California work forces by 22,000. In 1989, Hughes Aircraft Co. said it was eliminating 9,300 jobs, most of them in Southern California.

DOC.HEAD: WPP Shares Stabilize
DOC.TEXT: Shares in WPP PLC, the world's largest ad agency group, stabilized on Wednesday after losing 71 percent of their value in the previous two sessions. WPP's shares finished at 128 pence, or about $2.52, on London's Stock Exchange, up 13 pence (26 cents) from Tuesday's close. The shares sank 164 pence ($3.23) on Tuesday and 113 pence ($2.23) on Monday, after the company announced its 1990 profit wouldn't match analysts' expectations. The announcement from London-based WPP, which owns the J. Walter Thompson and Ogilvy and Mather ad agencies, raised concerns about the company's ability to meet its debts next year, analysts said.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Accused Of Industrial Espionage
DOC.TEXT: A suburban Philadelphia woman faces charges that she tried to sell a secret SmithKline Beecham marketing plan to one of the drug maker's main competitors, the FBI said Wednesday. Rebecca J. Lindquester, 42, of Newtown Square, was arrested Tuesday after exchanging photocopies of the marketing plan with a representative of a competing drug company, which had notified the authorities of her offer, said FBI Special Agent Wayne R. Gilbert. The competing drug company, Glaxo Inc. of Raleigh, N.C., produces Zantac, an anti-ulcer drug that competes on the market with the SmithKline Beecham product Tagamet. Tagamet is SmithKline's biggest seller, with annual sales in the hundreds of millions of dollars. Lindquester and her husband, David, co-own Horizon Productions, a video-production firm that had obtained the marketing plan Sept. 5 when SmithKline asked the firm to bid on a contract to produce a videotape to train sales representatives on a new use for Tagamet. Her husband was not charged in the case. Shortly after obtaining the marketing plan, Lindquester contacted Jim Daly, product manager for Glaxo. Identifying herself as ``Mary Anne Riley,'' she said she was willing to sell material to Glaxo that would give it ``a competitive advantage'' over Tagamet, the FBI said. Daly notified Glaxo's security office, which contacted the FBI on Sept. 11. Over the next two months, Lindquester sent several fax messages to Daly, demanding $500,000 for the material, the FBI said. On Friday, in a telephone conversation recorded by Glaxo security, the woman agreed to accept $25,000 for the material, the FBI said. Daly and the woman agreed to meet at the Airport Marriott near Philadelphia International Airport. After making the exchange, Lindquester went out to her car in the hotel parking lot, where the FBI arrested her. She was arraigned before U.S. Magistrate Judge M. Faith Angell and released on $2,000 bail. Lindquester was charged with fraud by wire and faces five years in prison and a $1,000 fine if convicted.

DOC.HEAD: Fleet-Norstar Cuts Dividend
DOC.TEXT: Fleet-Norstar Financial Group Inc., considered to be one of New England's strongest banking companies, slashed its dividend by almost 43 percent Wednesday. Fleet directors declared a quarterly dividend of 20 cents per share, down from 35 cents, payable Jan. 1 to stockholders of record Dec. 15. Analysts had expected some sort of cut. Terrence Murray, Fleet chairman and chief executive, said Fleet retains a 7 percent capital-to-assets ratio, compared with the industry average of almost 5 percent. But ``retention of capital is the most prudent course of action at this time.'' The region is in the throes of an economic downturn, with slumping real estate values and higher loan defaults eroding the value of bank stocks and the banks' bottom lines. Fleet, with $33.6 billion in assets, joins a growing list of banks that have cut shareholder returns as loan losses have increased. As of Sept. 30, Fleet reported non-performing loans of $852 million, up almost $100 million from the previous quarter. Fleet reported a loss of 5 cents per share for the nine months ended Sept. 30, compared with earnings of $2.51 the year before. It had third-quarter earnings of 33 cents per share, down from 86 cents last year.

DOC.HEAD: Milan Stock Traders Suspend Strike
DOC.TEXT: The association of Italian floor traders decided Wednesday to suspend their protest strike, which has blocked trading since Friday. The suspension will be effective until Nov. 30, when traders will evaluate the progress made in adopting legislation modernizing the stock market and simplifying a proposed capital gains tax. The decision followed a meeting early Wednesday between representatives of striking floor traders and members of the Finance Committee of the Chamber of Deputies. Trading on Italy's 10 regional stock exchanges, which are dominated by the Milan bourse, is expected to resume Thursday. The floor traders had called the strike to protest a new government proposal for a 30 percent capital gains tax. They fear that the way the government intends to collect the tax will scare investors away from the stock market and shift business to other European markets. The government has said it is willing to consider technical improvements in the implementation of the law, but that it isn't willing to renounce the capital gains tax itself.

DOC.HEAD: Beans Finish Higher
DOC.TEXT: Heavy usage of soybean oil and meal sent futures prices higher Wednesday in the soybean complex at the Chicago Board of Trade. Corn weakened in late trading, while wheat futures advanced a few cents a bushel. The U.S. Census Bureau's soybean crush report for October, released after the close of trading on Tuesday, showed inventories of oil and meal below analysts' expectations. ``The census crush showed record domestic use for October for both oil and meal,'' said Dan Cekander, an analyst in Chicago with Rodman & Renshaw Inc. Soy oil inventories were put at 1.222 billion pounds and soy meal at 302,550 tons. Cekander noted there was growing pressure, from farm groups and others, to extend credit to the Soviet Union for U.S. farm goods. He said, however, the pressure did not add much to the market's sensitivity to the huge export potential. At the close, wheat was 1} cents to 5 cents higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.47 a bushel; corn was unchanged to 1{ cents lower with December at $2.02\ a bushel; oats were unchanged to 1\ cents lower with December at $1.07 a bushel; and soybeans were 1{ cents to 6} cents higher with January at $5.75 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Guinness Makes Offer for Spain's Largest Brewer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS in 10th graf, Guinness said, to show purchase price of $35.5 million is only for Henniger stake. Picks up 11th graf, Cruz del.
DOC.TEXT: Guinness PLC, the British beer and liquor group, said today it has agreed to make an offer of 518 million pounds, or $1.02 billion, for La Cruz del Campo, Spain's largest brewer. The deal would be one of the largest ever foreign buyouts in Spain. Guinness said it has the backing of shareholders in control of more than half the ordinary shares of Seville-based La Cruz del Campo, which controls 22 percent of the Spanish market. But the Spanish firm's board insisted all shareholders receive the same opportunity to sell shares, meaning the board-recommended offer hinges on a vote planned at an extraordinary Cruz del Campo shareholders meeting set for the first half of December. The takeover would make Guinness the world's 12th largest brewer by volume, up from its current position as 17th. ``The acquisition of Cruzcampo provides Guinness with a key strategic base'' in the fast-growing Spanish beer market, now the second-largest in Europe, Guinness Chairman Anthony Tennant said. The Spanish company, whose shares are not traded publicly, had been up for sale for more than a year drawing offers from the world's premier brewing firms, including the Netherlands' Heineken N.V., Denmark's Carlsberg and Elders IXL Ltd. of Australia. The Guinness purchase could be completed as early as the end of next January, Cruz del Campo said. Talk of a Cruz del Campo sale emerged after the U.S.'s Stroh Brewery Co. of Detroit sought to sell its 28 percent share in Cruz del Campo. Guinness said it had reached an agreement with Stroh not only to purchase its Cruz del Campo shares, but Stroh's 30 percent stake in the Cruz del Campo unit, Henninger Espanola SA. It will pay 18 million pounds, or $35.28 million, for the Henninger stake. Cruz del Campo owns all or part of five other smaller Spanish brewers. Guinness said it also planned to offer to buy those minority shares not owned by Cruz del Campo in its subsidiaries for an estimated price of 15 million pounds, or $29.4 million. Cruz del Campo currently holds a 22 percent share of the fast-growing Spanish market, up from 17 percent a decade ago. Net profit last last year rose 18 percent to 10.59 billion pesetas, or $98 million, and in the five years prior to last year rose an average 26 per cent per year, the company said. ``The decision to sell the group has not been an easy one, but we reached the conclusion in 1989 that (Cruz del Campo) had reached the limits of what it could achieve on its own,'' Cruz del Campo chairman Ignacio Ybarra Mendaro said in a statement. ``To continue development and profitable expansion, we needed the resources and experience of an important and solvent international group,'' he added.

DOC.HEAD: Guinness Buys Spain's Largest Brewer, Becomes World's 12th Largest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 4th graf, Guinness said, to show $35.5 million purchase price is for Henninger stake only.
DOC.TEXT: Guinness PLC said Wednesday it has agreed to buy Spain's largest brewer, La Cruz del Campo, for $1.02 billion, in a deal that will make the British company the world's 12th largest brewer. The acquisition would be one of the biggest foreign takeovers in Spain, where closely held Cruz del Campo commands a 22 percent share of the fast-growing beer market. Guinness, which ranks 17th among the world's brewers, said it already had the backing of shareholders who control more than half the Seville-based company's stock. Guinness said it also has reached an agreement with the Stroh Brewery Co. of Detroit to buy both its 28 percent holding in Cruz del Campo and its 30 percent holding in Henninger Espanola SA, a Cruz del Campo subsidiary. The purchase price of the Henninger stake is 18 million pounds, or $35.5 million. ``The acquisition of Cruzcampo provides Guinness with a key strategic base'' in Spain, said Guinness Chairman Anthony Tennant. ``The decision to sell the group has not been an easy one, but we reached the conclusion earlier this year that (Cruz del Campo) had reached the limits of what it could achieve on its own,'' said Cruz del Campo Chairman Ignacio Ybarra Mendaro. The Spanish brewer, whose shares are not publicly traded, was on the block for nearly a year and had attracted interest from a variety of foreign brewers. Guinness said it would pay for the acquisition with cash and existing credit lines. It said the purchase was not expected to dilute its earnings per share in the first year after the deal is completed. The purchase subsequently should enhance earnings, Guinness said. The deal is expected to be completed in January 1991. Philip Morrisey, an analyst with the London investment firm Kleinwort Benson Securities, said the acquisition would help balance Guinness' income from brewing and distilling. Morrisey estimated that adding Cruz del Campo would raise brewing results from 17 percent to about 21 percent of Guinness' pre-tax profit. But analysts questioned whether Cruz del Campo would be able to continue expanding at its current rate. Industry projections called for a slowdown in the growth of Spanish beer sales to about 1 percent this year, from the 4 percent average of the 1980s. Analysts said nationwide expansion could be difficult because of strongholds that other brewers have in regions outside Andalucia, where Cruz del Campo dominates. ``Spaniards are loyal to regional brands and it won't be easy to convince them to change,'' said Carlos de la Serna, an analyst with Iberagentes SA in Madrid. Cruz del Campo's after-tax profit jumped 14 percent last year to $81 million dollars. Sales rose 12 percent to $467 million. Guinness had after-tax profit of 472 million pounds, or $930 million, last year on revenue of 3.07 billion pounds, or $6.05 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Financier Rose in the Shadows, Fell in the Spotlight
With AM-Milken
DOC.TEXT: Michael R. Milken climbed quietly to the pinnacle of high-finance in the 1980s. He descended with a shattering crash into disgrace and prison, where he'll likely spend a good chunk of the 1990s. Born and raised in California, Milken was a math whiz helping his father's accounting business by age 10. He studied arcane business tracts while others marched for civil rights and peace during the 1960s. In his early years on Wall Street, Milken digested financial documents during a two-hour commute. With the same passion, Milken avoided the limelight after gaining market prowess, shunning interviews and refusing to pose alone for the annual report of his employer, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Milken became a familiar figure only after speculator Ivan Boesky fingered him in the government's fraud investigation in late 1986. The most prominent financier in the securities industry in the booming 1980s, Milken became prosecutors' main target. After insisting he was innocent, Milken changed his mind in April. Under a plea bargain, he pleaded guilty to six felony counts and agreed to pay $600 million in penalties and restitution to defrauded investors. The 44-year-old former head of Drexel's junk-bond department was sentenced Wednesday to a 10-year imprisonment and three years of probation. He must serve at least a third of the prison term. ``To some it might sound ironic, but I have spent a lifetime trying to avoid publicity,'' Milken wrote in letter to U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood prior to sentencing. ``My parents taught me if you worked hard and knew you did a good job, you should not need recognition from others.'' Milken was born on the Fourth of July in 1946. As a child he was a star student, and said he was embarrassed when his fourth-grade teacher singled out his perfect scores. He graduated the University of California at Berkeley in 1968 and went on to the University of Pennsylvania's prestigious Wharton School. In between, he married Lori Anne Hackel, his high school sweetheart. In 1970, at age 24, Milken joined Drexel's New York office as head of fixed-income research, commuting from his southern New Jersey home by bus. By 1973, he was head of high-yield bonds. His compensation was set in a 1975 formula - and never altered - that gave him a portion of the department's profits. Milken was to become infamous for the $1.1 billion he earned from 1983-87, $550 million in 1987 alone. Milken has said the wealth was a byproduct of his work raising money for companies. ``I went to Wall Street with the desire to help change society for the better, not to find a fortune,'' Milken told the judge. ``I felt that working in the financial community created the best opportunity for social change: making capital available where it hadn't been before,'' he wrote. Prompted by his father's illness, Milken was allowed to move Drexel's high-yield bond department to Beverly Hills, Calif., in 1978. As the economy prospered in the mid-1980s, Wall Street and junk bonds developed into a $200 billion market by the decade's end. They were used in the biggest takeover deals ever, helping to reshape American business and creating an inner circle of corporate raiders. Milken became linked to the mock title of Drexel's annual junk bond conference, ``the predator's ball.'' He worked 18 hour days and scheduled 4 a.m. meetings with corporate executives soliciting his financial acumen. He and his lawyers maintain Milken still had time for a quiet home life with his wife and three children in a modest house 10 blocks from the Encino, Calif., home his parents bought in 1954. In his letter to the judge, Milken said of his ordeal: ``I have been forced to face the challenge that not only am I portrayed as a fraud, but everything my life stood for is called a fraud and all the principles I have spoken about my whole life are hollow.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Milken
DOC.TEXT: Here are short profiles of some of the major figures in Wall Street's financial scandals besides Michael Milken: -MICHAEL R. MILKEN, former head of junk-bond trading at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., sentenced to a 10 year imprisonment and three years probation on six counts of violating federal securities and tax laws. He also agreed to pay $600 million in penalties. Four of the six charges involved dealings with chief accuser Ivan F. Boesky, though none in insider trading or racketeering. Milken is widely regarded as the most powerful financier of the 1980s. -IVAN BOESKY, former speculator in takeover stocks, paid $100 million and pleaded guilty to one count of lying to federal regulators in a broad insider trading network. He was released from federal custody in April after completing two years of a three-year prison term. His confessions in late 1986 led investigators to Milken. -DENNIS LEVINE, paroled last year after serving 17 months of a two-year prison term for securities fraud, tax evasion and perjury. Levine's confessions about a broad insider trading ring led prosecutors to Boesky. The former Drexel managing director, who accepted satchels of money and arranged deals from pay phones, pleaded guilty to four felonies and returned $11.6 million in alleged illegal profits. In a first-person article in a business magazine this year, Levine said he started an investment advisory firm. -MARTIN SIEGEL, pleaded guilty in 1987 to illegal stock trading and tax evasion while head of mergers and acquisitions at Kidder, Peabody & Co. He also agreed to return $9 million in cash and securities to settle civil charges for his role in illegal dealings with Boesky. Siegel, a former Drexel managing director, was sentenced in June to a two-month prison term, which he has completed. -BOYD L. JEFFERIES, a Los Angeles stockbroker snared in the Boesky web, was placed on probation and fined $250,000 after two years of helping the government. He pleaded guilty to two felony counts in 1987 and then testified in the trials of GAF Corp. and corporate raider Paul Bilzerian. He is living and working in Palm Springs, Calif., and Aspen, Colo. -PAUL A. BILZERIAN, the Florida investor, last year received four years in prison for his conviction on nine counts of securities fraud, conspiracy and making false statements, and fined $1.5 million. The sentence for the former Singer Co. chairman was the stiffest in the Wall Street scandals. Bilzerian is is free pending appeal. -ROBERT FREEMAN, former head of arbitrage for Goldman, Sachs & Co., was arrested along with two other executives for insider trading in the most dramatic of the government's string of cases. Implicated by Siegel, Freeman pleaded guilty to one felony count and in April was sentenced to four months in prison and fined $1 million. He completed the term Aug. 30. -BRUCE NEWBERG, a former Drexel trader, was indicted along with Milken and convicted with five others in the Princeton-Newport Partners racketeering and fraud trial. He was sentenced to three months in prison in the Princeton-Newport case. Newberg was Milken's assistant at Drexel's Beverly Hills, Calif., high-yield bond division. His status in the Milken case is unresolved. -JOHN A. MULHEREN JR., a former wunderkind stock speculator, was convicted earlier this year of conspiracy and securities fraud in connection for manipulating Gulf & Western Inc. stock at Boesky's behest in 1985. Mulheren was sentenced this month to one year and one day in prison and fined $1.86 million. He's free pending appeal.

DOC.HEAD: Production Goes Down This Week
DOC.TEXT: Domestic automakers were scheduled to produce 163,107 cars and light trucks in North America in a week shortened by the U.S. Thanksgiving Day holiday, down from last week's 196,362, Ward's Automotive Reports said Thursday. This week's production is lower than the same week a year ago, in which 168,149 cars and light trucks were produced, the trade journal said. U.S. automakers were scheduled to make 77,022 cars this week, compared with 100,925 a week ago and 80,647 in the same week in 1989. Light truck production for the week was scheduled at 47,124, compared with last week's 58,033 and last year's 48,012. Canadian automakers were to build 24,409 cars this week, up from 21,244 a week ago and up from last year's 19,919. Canadian light truck production was scheduled at 14,552, compared with 16,160 a week ago and 19,571 in the same week last year.
Stock prices turned in a mixed showing today in a quiet preholiday session. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 7.42 at 2,537.62.

DOC.HEAD: German Unification Creates New Ground For Coke and Pepsi Battle
DOC.TEXT: A flash point of the Cold War has become a focus of the cola wars. Since the Berlin Wall opened last year, Coca-Cola and Pepsi-Cola have spent millions of dollars trying to establish a presence in what was formerly East Germany. Pepsico Inc. representatives, with television cameras rolling, handed out cans of Pepsi when the wall was dismantled. And when East Germany allowed advertising on national TV for the first time this spring, a Coca-Cola Co. spot was among the first to air. ``The first unification of Germany was soft drink unification,'' said Emanuel Goldman, an industry analyst for PaineWebber Inc. in San Francisco. The cola makers are concentrating now on building a distribution system and inching toward full-scale manufacturing in the region, which for nearly half a century was closed to most Western products. The companies also are moving along with the type of aggressive public relations and advertising that have characterized soft drink competition elsewhere for decades. Already, Coke says it is outselling its nearest competitor 10-to-1, a contention which Pepsi dismisses. Atlanta-based Coke, which has a bottling operation running in what was East Berlin, says it has sold 7 million cases of Coca-Cola products since entering the former Communist country in February. Pepsi, a division of Purchase, N.Y.-based Pepsico, entered the new German market in January, but says it does not yet have reliable sales figures. ``Either sideis guessing. It's a little too early in the game,'' said Tod MacKenzie, a Pepsi-Cola spokesman. ``There's no independent measurement (in the eastern sector) to represent what your share of the market is. ``We can say we shipped so much, but that's not a measure of consumer take ... just how much we sent out the door.'' The soft drink makers say they're expecting great things in the newly united Germany. That assessment is shared by analyst Goldman. ``It's good for both companies,'' Goldman said, adding that Coke begins with a head start because of the commanding presence it had in West Germany and most of Europe. ``We think East Germany ... will reach the consumption levels of West Germany in the next few years.'' Ralph Cooper, president of Coke's European Community Group, said in a recent interview. ``We think that's a very achievable target.'' ``Nearly 70 percent of the people have tried Coca-Cola in the first months,'' said Cooper, whose division accounts for about one-quarter of Coke's international sales. According to Coke, East German soft drink consumption in 1989 was 315 eight-ounce servings per person, compared with 334 in West Germany. West German consumption of Coke products was 167 eight-ounce servings per person in 1989, and company officials estimate that East German per capita Coke consumption is now about 30. In the United States - the world leader in soft drink consumption - the per capita rate for Coca-Cola products was 283. Coke is the No. 1 soft drink company in the United States, with about 41 percent of the domestic market, though most of the company's recent growth has come overseas. Pepsi's per capita figures were unavailable. Goldman said it is easier for Coke to get established in the new market because it literally can move its West German operations next door. Pepsi has a much smaller operation there, about one-fifth the size of Coke's, he said. ``For Pepsi, it's good,'' he said. ``For Coke, it's spectacular. They know how to sell it there. They know the whole market there.'' Pepsi, however, says its strong presence for nearly 20 years in such Eastern bloc nations as the Soviet Union, Poland, Yugoslavia and Czechloslovakia gives it an advantage. ``Pepsi's historical leadership position throughout the Eastern bloc has provided significant leverage to power us into the East German market as well,'' said MacKenzie. Pepsi's initial activity in eastern Germany has involved building a distribution system across the key southern commercial belt, which includes Leipzig and Dresden. Manufacturing is still down the road for Pepsi, MacKenzie said. Coke has concentrated its efforts on distribution, but it also is creating an infrastructure for manufacturing, bottling and sales, Cooper said. ``We want to be a part of everyday life there,'' he said. Cooper said the company tapped into its West German operation for help on the other side of the border once the wall opened. Coke has plastered cities with advertising posters and has sponsored a number of local events. Pepsi put up a 40-foot permanent billboard on a major thoroughfare in East Berlin and advertises on public transportation. ``It's amazing how quickly a consumer open goods market has taken over there,'' MacKenzie said. MacKenzie said Pepsi also has tried to respond to the Germans' heightened environmental awareness by offering its products in recyclable plastic bottles.

DOC.HEAD: Employee Group Announces Buyout Bid For Georgia-Pacific; Company Dismisses It
DOC.TEXT: An employee group said Wednesday it planned to launch a bid to buy Georgia-Pacific Corp., a move the giant forest products company dismissed as the work of a disgruntled former worker. The employees group, in conjunction with International Business Consultants, a Dallas consulting and management firm, announced through a press release that it was trying to recruit workers to participate in an employee stock ownership plan to buy Georgia-Pacific's mills and subsidiaries. Joe Greer, a spokesman for IBC, said it would be the largest ESOP buyout of a public company in U.S. history. The group did not put a dollar figure on the bid. Georgia-Pacific immediately dismissed an employee buyout as having ``absolutely no chance of success.'' ``Georgia-Pacific does not take seriously the possibility that the group in question, IBC, could affect the buyout of the company using an employee stock ownership plan,'' Georgia-Pacific Chairman T. Marshall Hahn said in a statement. He said Georgia-Pacific has identified the people behind the move as two Arkansas realtors and a disgruntled former employee of Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. Georgia-Pacific this year concluded a $5 billion buyout of Great Northern after a long and bitter struggle, creating the world's largest forest products company. Hahn added that G-P has not been presented with a proposal, and said the company planned to ask the Securities and Exchange Commission to investigate for possible stock manipulation. Trading of Georgia-Pacific stock was halted on the New York Stock Exchange around the time the press release was issued. The stock resumed trading and closed down 87{ cents at $34.50 per share.

DOC.HEAD: Bonds Rise Modestly
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices climbed Wednesday in light, pre-holiday dealings as speculation grew that interest rates are headed lower. The Treasury's key 30-year bond rose 7-16 point, or $4.40 per $1,000 in face amount, while its yield to 8.42 percent from 8.46 percent late Tuesday. Trading was sluggish on the day before the Thanskgiving holiday, with the market closed at 2 p.m. An early close is also slated for Friday. Elliott Platt, who follows the bond markets for the investment firm Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette Securities, said weak economic reports are contributing to speculation that interest rates may be headed lower. On Wednesday, a government report said initial jobless claims rose 39,000 to 488,000 in the latest week. ``It indicates the economy is in a recession and the recession is deepening,'' he said. He said many traders expect the Federal Reserve will take more steps to lower interest rates before the end of the year. When interest rates fall, the prices of bonds already in the hands of investors rise. It is widely believed that the central bank relaxed its monetary policy last week amid mounting evidence of economic deterioration. The Fed does not announce such actions, but it is believed that it demonstrated its intentions by allowing a quarter-point drop in the federal funds rate, the rate banks charge each other for overnight loans. That rate stood at 7{ percent Wednesday, unchanged from late Tuesday. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, short-term maturities rose 5-32 point to \ point, intermediate maturities advanced 11-32 point point and long-term issues rose as much as 7-16 point, according to Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, added 3.15 to 1,174.99. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds rose 3-32 point. The average yield to maturity fell to 7.48 percent down from 7.49 percent late Tuesday. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 7.23 percent as the discount lost 7 basis points to 7.02 percent. Yields on six-month bills fell to 7.31 percent as the discount fell 8 basis points to 6.97 percent. Yields on one-year bills dropped to 7.23 percent as the discount lost 8 basis points to 6.77 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Up In Light Trading Before Thanksgiving
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices rose moderately Wednesday, as the futures market turned bullish over a drop in the crude supply and France's prediction that the U.N. Security Council will authorize military action against Iraq. Light sweet crude oil moved up 72 cents to $29.63 per barrel for January delivery contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange, erasing much of Tuesday's fall of $1.81 per barrel. Volume was about as light as it has been for any session since Iraq invaded Kuwait in August, as traders prepared to take off for the Thanksgiving holiday. The oil market reopens Friday, but some traders planned to take a four-day weekend. ``I suppose we're having one of the dullest days we've had in several weeks around here,'' said Bob Baker, an oil analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Traders were generally unwilling to enter into new oil contracts because of the possibility of unexpected developments in the Persian Gulf, where President Bush was spending the holiday with U.S. troops. ``In the back of people's minds, they're thinking anything could happen with him over there,'' said Peter Beutel, an analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., in Hoboken, N.J. Oil opened higher in response to an American Petroleum Institute report issued that night before that showed stocks of crude oil and refined products dropped in the previous week. Crude then hit its high for the day of $30.20 per barrel after French President Francois Mitterrand said he had told Bush that a U.N. resolution authorizing force against Iraq was needed. The French leader said such a resolution would likely be passed within three weeks. Adding to the market's bullish mood were perceptions that the United States and the Soviet Union had become closer in their views on the Gulf crisis. ``The Soviets, who were talking about being against military intervention earlier in the week, have kind of backpedaled,'' said Brian Tagler, a broker with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ``Each day, we find they agree more and more with President Bush.'' Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Wednesday urged the U.N. Security Council to meet immediately on the Gulf crisis. As oil moved ahead, refined petroleum products tagged along. Unleaded gasoline rose 1.48 cents to 78.95 cents a gallon on December contracts, with later contract months moving higher as well. Home heating oil was higher for all delivery months, with the December contract up .79 cent at 85.24 cents a gallon. Baker said heating oil's relatively weaker performance reflected a belief among traders that no supply problems seem likely this winter. Natural gas futures traded lower, with the January delivery contract falling 2 cents to $2.61 per 1,000 cubic feet.

DOC.HEAD: Money Funds Rose $6.36 Billion in Latest Week to Record $423.52 Billion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report Investment Company Institute are for week ended Tuesday. Bank Rate Monitor figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 524 money market mutual funds rose $6.36 billion in the latest week to an all time high as investors reacted to a lower interest rate target by the Federal Reserve, the Investment Company Institute said Wednesday. The rise, to $423.52 billion in the six-day period ended Tuesday, broke the record of $418.33 billion set in the week ended Nov. 7. The most recent period was shortened by the Thanksgiving holiday. The surge followed a revised $1.17 billion drop in the funds' assets the previous week, according to the Washington-based mutual fund trade group. Jacob Dreyer, chief economist at the institute, said the rise came as investors, particularly insitutions, shifted from money market securities to mutual funds as the Fed allowed short-term interest rates to fall slightly. The biggest weekly rise in the funds' assets - $9.64 billion in the week ended Oct. 21, 1987 - came during the stock market collapse as investors sought safe havens for their money. The Investment Company Institute said that in the latest week, assets of 260 general purpose funds rose $1.3 billion to $149.9 billion, assets of 104 broker-dealer funds increased $1.32 billion to $166.29 billion, and assets of 160 institutional funds rose $3.74 billion to $107.24 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds rose in the week ended Tuesday to 7.35 percent from 7.34 percent the previous week, according to Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield fell to 7.38 percent from 7.40 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 51 days, up from 49 days, Donoghue's said. Separately, the newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts fell to 6.00 percent as of Wednesday from 6.01 percent a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, was unchanged from the previous week at 5.08 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.55 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, down from 7.58 the previous week. Yields were 7.66 percent on 1-year CDs, down from 7.71 percent; 7.77 percent on 2{-year CDs, down from 7.80 percent; and 8.01 percent on 5-year CDs, down from 8.03 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Finds Mobil Unjustly Fired Environmental Officer
DOC.TEXT: Mobil Chemical Co. unjustly fired a top executive after he refused to go along with a company cover-up of environmental problems, a federal jury found Wednesday. The jury awarded the employee, Valcar Bowman, $375,000 in compensatory damages and $1 million in punitive damages. It also found in favor of his wife, Pamela, for loss of spousal support, but awarded her no money. The jury rejected two counter-claims filed by Mobil against Bowman. The panel was asked to decide whether the oil giant fired Bowman in 1986 because he would not go along with company attorneys who wanted to sanitize reports that documented Mobil's environmental problems. Valcar also claimed he was fired because he objected to plans to remove records from a company plant when attorneys realized a raid by law enforcement officials was imminent. ``Justice prevails,'' Bowman said after the verdict was read. ``Of course the money is important, but the fact that the jury recognized that something wrong was happening here was also very important.'' Mobil attorneys had argued that Bowman's job as the No. 2 environmental officer at Mobil Chemical Co. was eliminated as part of a cost-cutting program. ``It's a bad decision and Mobil plans to appeal,'' said Mobil attorney Richard Ribstein. ``There was no evidence to support any of the claims.'' Company attorneys attacked Bowman in closing arguments as a ``fraud'' and a ``liar,'' intent on starting his own business by getting money from Mobil, the nation's second largest oil company behind Exxon Corp. Bowman's attorneys responded that Mobil was trying to distract the jury from the evidence with a well-funded smear campaign. In his closing arguments, attorney Stephen Wiley produced a series of memos that indicated Mobil planned to abolish the position of the manager of environmental affairs as a way to get rid of Bowman. ``We should be prepared to live without the position of environmental manager for some time, e.g. up to two years,'' said a company memo dated six weeks before Bowman's dismissal. Wiley scoffed at Mobil's contention that Bowman was dismissed in a cost-cutting move. He noted that in 1986, the year Bowman lost his job, Mobil's chemical division earned a record $140 million, up 164 percent from 1985. Mobil attorneys spent most of their closing arguments trying to shred Bowman's personal credibility with a parade of resumes, applications and affidavits that showed Bowman had lied in the past. In one case highlighted by Mobil attorneys, Bowman swore on an affidavit about 10 years ago that his wife's daughter from a previous partner was his. The jury also witnessed a parade of excerpts from the dictionary - blown up and highlighted on 2-by-4-foot cards - of the definitions of the words ``bogus,'' ``swindle,'' ``hypocrite'' and ``heist.''

DOC.HEAD: Domestic Usage, Soviet Potential Push Soy Complex Futures Higher
DOC.TEXT: Soybean traders, eyeing both domestic usage and the potential for exports to the Soviet Union, sent prices higher Wednesday at the Chicago Board of Trade. Soybeans were up to 9 cents higher while soy oil more than recovered losses suffered Tuesday. Wheat also was higher, while corn lost a penny or so. On other markets, livestock and meat futures were mostly higher, as were precious metals and petroleum futures. The U.S. Census Bureau's soybean crush report for October, released after the close of trading on Tuesday, showed inventories of oil and meal below analysts' expectations. ``The census crush showed record domestic use for October for both oil and meal,'' said Dan Cekander, an analyst in Chicago with Rodman & Renshaw Inc. Soy oil inventories were put at 1.222 billion pounds and soy meal at 302,550 tons. The soybean and grain markets derived initial firmness from Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev's remarks Tuesday about the need for the U.N. Security Council to address the crisis in the Persian Gulf. ``If Bush get's Gorbachev's support in the Persian Gulf, then we're more likely to give him food aid or export credits,'' said Victor Lespinasse, assistant vice president of grains for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Cekander noted that there was growing pressure, from farm groups and others, to extend credit to the Soviet Union for U.S. farm goods. He said, however, that the pressure didn't add much to the market's extreme sensitivity to this huge export potential. Wheat settled 3{ cents to 5} cents higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.49 a bushel; corn was \ cent to 1{ cents lower with December at $2.20{ a bushel; oats were unchanged to 1 cent lower with December at $1.07{ a bushel; soybeans were 1{ cents ot 9 cents higher with January at $5.77\ a bushel; soybean oil was 10 cents to 36 cents higher with December at $20.21 per 100 pounds; and soybean meal was 50 cents to $2.60 higher with December at $174.50 a ton. Livestock and meat futures were mostly higher at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, with frozen pork bellies regaining most of their limit losses of the previous session. The firmness in cattle futures was mostly a consolidation after Tuesday's losses that reflected the largest Nov. 1 cattle-on-feed inventories in a dozen years. Live cattle settled .15 cent lower to .15 cent higher with the December ontract at 79.15 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .17 cent higher, live hogs were unchanged to .55 cent higher with December at 53.65 cents a pound; and frozen pork bellies were 1 cent to 1.45 cents higher with February at 71.65 cents a pound. Precious metals futures advanced on the Commodity Exchange in New York. The markets got support early in the session from a decline in the Dow Jones industrial average and a softer U.S. dollar. Gold settled 50 cents to $1.30 higher with the December contract at $379.80 a troy ounce; silver was 1.2 cents to 1.8 cents higher with November at $4.12 a troy ounce. Petroleum futures moved moderately higher at the New York Mercantile Exchange, responding to a decline in the supply of crude oil and France's prediction that the U.N. Security Council will authorize military action against Iraq. Light sweet crude oil settled 35 cents to 72 cents higher with January at $29.63 a barrel; heating oil was .31 cent to .86 cent higher with December at 85.24 a gallon; and unleaded gasoline was .50 cent to 1.77 cent higher with December at 78.95 cents a gallon.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended mixed in lackluster, pre-holiday trading Wednesday, with little news to affect the currency, traders said. Gold prices rose. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold settled at $378.90 a troy ounce, up $1.30 from Tuesday. Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $379.15, up $1.55. David Ethridge, a vice president and currency trader at Merrill Lynch & Co., said most activity in the thin market appeared to be ``mopping-up operations'' ahead of Thanksgiving. However, he said, some long-term investors continued to sell dollars to buy the Japanese yen, in part due to a belief that Japanese interest rates were headed higher while U.S. rates could drop. Higher interest rates tend to support a nation's currency by making securities denominated in those currencies more valuable. The dollar rose against the German mark but fell against the yen and the British pound. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 127.68 yen from 128.93 yen Tuesday. Later in London, it rose to 128.90 yen. But in New York, one dollar bought 127.17 yen, down from 128.85 yen late Tuesday. In London, the British pound fell to $1.9680 from $1.9695 late Tuesday. But in New York, one pound cost $1.9670, more expensive than $1.9660 Tuesday. The mark traded at 1.4815 to the dollar in Europe, up from 1.4760 Tuesday. In New York, one dollar fetched 1.4770 marks, up from 1.4740 marks the day before. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.2472 Swiss francs, up from 1.2450; 4.9800 French francs, up from 4.9760; 1,109 Italian lire, unchanged; and 1.1582 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1593. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday, included: 1.2505 Swiss francs, up from 1.2470; 5.0000 French francs, up from 4.9780; 1.6717 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6650; 1,112.75 Italian lire, up from 1,110.50; and 1.1587 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1598. Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $378.25 a troy ounce, up from $377.75 bid late Tuesday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $378.50, up from $377.50 bid late Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $8.17 to close at a bid $372.13. Silver prices rose. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.125 a troy ounce, up from $4.11 late Tuesday. In London, silver rose to a late bid of $4.11 a troy ounce, up from $4.10 late Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Judge OKs Reorganization For Sharon Steel
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge on Wednesday confirmed a plan to spin off financially ailing Sharon Steel Corp.'s steel division to a New York merchant bank and sell brass, railroad and mining interests to unsecured creditors. The reorganization plan brings the nation's 18th largest steelmaker out of Chapter 11 proceedings in U.S. Bankruptcy Court, said merchant banker Castle Harlan Inc. and Quantum Overseas N.V., the company's largest unsecured creditor. U.S. District Judge Warren Bentz approved the plan the day after confirmation hearings in his Erie courtroom. Castle Harlan will pay $300 million to acquire Sharon Steel's Mercer County steel mill, which employs 2,500 people, and assume some of the company's steel debt, according to Castle Harlan and Quantum Overseas. They said Quantum Overseas would pay $50 million for a 30 percent share of a company formed from Sharon Steel-owned Mueller Brass Co. and Arava Natural Resource Co., with the rest of the new company going to other unsecured creditors. The brass, railroad and mining divisions, to be renamed Mueller Industries Inc., employs 2,500 and posted income of more than $500 million in 1989, Castle Harlan and Quantum Overseas said. The firms said outstanding shares of Sharon Steel stock would be canceled, with holders of those shares receiving no compensation for their holdings. Fifty-eight percent of United Steelworkers union members at Sharon Steel approved a new contract for the steel spinoff, said Castle Harlan and Quantum Overseas.

DOC.HEAD: Control Data To Sell Micrognosis To Japanese Company
DOC.TEXT: Control Data Corp. will sell Micrognosis, which devises computer systems for the financial industry, to CSK Corp., Japan's largest independent computer services company, the two companies said Wednesday. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. Closing is expected by the end of the year. Connecticut-based Micrognosis supplies trading room systems for the financial services industry worldwide, serving 250 banks, insurance companies, securities firms and major corporations from 25 offices in 15 countries. It had revenue of about $100 million in 1989. The company's approximately 430 employees, most of whom work in Danbury, Conn., New York and London, will be retained, Control Data said. ``Micrognosis is a market leader in Europe, Asia and the United States,'' said Lawrence Perlman, president and chief executive officer of Control Data. ``With CSK's commitment to the market and to investing in Micrognosis, customers can be confident that Micrognosis will continue to provide advanced trading systems and features, as well as excellent service.'' ``Globalization is essential if CSK is to achieve its goal of generating $10 billion in revenues by the year 2001,'' said Isao Okawa, president and chairman of CSK. ``By acquiring Micrognosis, we are establishing an excellent foundation to do business beyond Japan.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Who Put Milken Away: Young, Widely Admired, Thorough, Tough
With AM-Milken, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Kimba M. Wood, the rookie federal judge who gave Michael R. Milken a 10-year prison term Wednesday, lived up to her reputation. Friends and acquaintances of Wood said the judge's handling of the most explosive case in her short tenure on the Manhattan federal bench was characteristically thorough and precise. ``I think she went through the most searching, careful and methodical and thoughtful process,'' said Lloyd Constantine, head of antitrust enforcement for New York state and a friend of Wood. ``She did not treat the matter lightly,'' Constantine said. ``I can't recall a sentencing where a judge invested so much time and effort.'' Wood was besieged with hundreds of letters from Milken supporters and critics alike. She blazed through mountains of legal documents from thedefense and prosecution, one portraying Milken as a gentle philanthropist, the other painting him as an arrogant crook. It was clear she believed neither. Perhaps most important, acquaintances said, was the extraordinary hearing Wood convened last month into unproven allegations of Milken's wrongdoing beyond the six felonies he admitted. It showed both her skepticism and desire to leave no question unresolved in her final reckoning of Milken's fate. Laura Handman, a Manhattan attorney and another friend of Wood, said she felt confident the judge ``reviewed all the evidence and weighed all the considerations very closely in reaching her decision.'' Wood, 46, is the youngest judge on the Manhattan federal bench, one of the busiest in the nation. She was appointed two years ago and received Milken's case through the court's random assignment system. She had no prior sentencing history in major criminal cases, leaving legal experts little on which to speculate. Few anticipated she'd give Milken 10 years of the maximum 28 he faced. The severity of the term, more than triple the time given Milken's chief accuser Ivan F. Boesky, was seen as a strong message to the financial community that securities-law abusers will be dealt with severely. People familiar with Wood have described her as a sensitive, hard-working judge whose quiet demeanor and dark good looks belie a sharp mind and a gift for remembering detail. Even her husband, Time magazine journalist Michael Kramer, recently described Wood's appearance as misleading to the unwary. ``She's always had this very calm exterior and yet she's very tough,'' Kramer said. ``I mean in the judicial sense, in a steel-trap mind way.'' The few nationally prominent cases Wood handled prior to the Milken case suggested she was willing to be bold. In October 1988, she reversed a ruling by the Immigration and Naturalization Service that had denied refugee status to a Ghanian soldier who plotted a coup against his government. Last year, she upheld the right of a 76-year-old New York state judge to seek reappointment although he had passed retirement age. Wood was born Jan. 2, 1944, in Port Townsend, Wash. Her parents decided to name her Kimba after a small town in South Australia's Eyre Peninsula they'd found on a map. She attended the Sorbonne in Paris, got her B.A. from Connecticut College, master's degree from the London School of Economics and law degree from Harvard University. Before she became a federal judge she practiced antitrust law in Washington and New York.

DOC.HEAD: Mylan Pharmaceuticals Sues American Cyanamid For $1 Billion
DOC.TEXT: A Pittsburgh-based drug maker sued American Cyanamid Co. for allegedly violating a marketing agreement on a drug used to treat high blood pressure. Mylan Pharmaceuticals Inc. is seeking $239 million from American Cyanamid for allegedly failing to ``exercise its best efforts ... to advertise, promote and market'' the drug Maxzide from 1987 through this year. The suit also seeks at least $176 million from American Cyanamid for failing to try hard enough to launch an improved version of Maxzide. In addition, the suit seeks $100 million for American Cyanamid's alleged promotion of its other hypertensive products, as well as royalties, $500 million in punitive damages and the exclusive right to market the drug and the bow-tie shape of Maxzide tablets. The suit says American Cyanamid agreed to introduce and sell Maxzide through its Lederle Laboratories Division in March 1984 on Mylan's request. Mylan, a major generic drug manufacturer, developed the drug in the early 1980s to compete with other potassium-saving, hypertensive medications, the company said in the suit filed Tuesday in U.S. District Court in Clarksburg. American Cyanamid, based in Wayne, N.J., has paid Mylan $36.1 million in royalties on Maxzide products since 1988 on net sales of $212.4 million, the lawsuit said. Jeff Hoyak, a Lederle spokesman, said the company hadn't seen the lawsuit and declined comment.

DOC.HEAD: Campbell to Make 24 Million Cans of Soup for Troops
DOC.TEXT: Campbell Soup Co. said Wednesday it will supply 24 million cans of soup to U.S. troops stationed in the Persian Gulf. The Camden-based soup maker said it received a defense contract to supply four varieties of soup to servicmen participating in Operation Desert Shield in Saudi Arabia. The soup, to be produced at Campbell plants in Napoleon, Ohio and Paris, Texas, will be packaged in ready-to-serve cans. Campbell said 167,000 cases of soup will be shipped to Delaware, where they will be airlifted from Dover Air Force Base. The balance will be shipped by sea.

DOC.HEAD: Government Applauds Milken Sentence, Friends Call It Sledgehammer Justice
With AM-Milken
DOC.TEXT: Law enforcers praised the 10-year prison term given to Michael R. Milken on Wednesday, but some legal experts said it was unusually stiff and the financier's supporters called the punishment excessively brutal. From Washington to Wall Street to the West Coast where Milken made his home, the sentence provoked the kind of mixed reaction that underscored the widely divergent public opinion of the famous junk-bond pioneer. Milken, former head of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s high-yield bond division, was sentenced by U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood for six felonies stemming from his role as a powerful investment banker of the past decade. ``Outstanding. Richly deserved,'' said Bruce Baird, a former assistant U.S. attorney who led the initial stages of the prosecution. ``I think Judge Wood is sending a message to Wall Street that it's time to stop mewing about technical offenses and time to start obeying the law.'' Attorney General Dick Thornburgh praised the sentence Milken received as ``both fair and appropriate to the circumstances.'' Former Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman David S. Ruder said he was pleased and surprised. ``I did not expect it to be that severe but I think the penalty is quite in accord with the severity of his conduct.'' Some lawmakers, though, said that the sentence, no matter how severe, could not undo what they called the damage brought by Milken's crimes. ``The harsh fact of the matter is that it will take the American public much longer than 10 years and much more than $600 million to pay for the mess these financial engineering schemes have left behind,'' said Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, which oversees the SEC. On the other hand some legal experts said the sentence's severity, while justified, seemed to outstrip the nature of Milken's crimes. ``I think the sentence is all symbolic - it's got nothing to do with the need to protect society from any future threats from Milken,'' said Arthur Mathews, the lawyer for takeover speculator Paul A. Bilzerian, who received what had been the stiffest sentence in the Wall Street fraud scandal - four years - before Wood announced Milken's fate. ``Implicit in the sentence is that this was more than an aberration in her view and this was systemic,'' he said. There was also little sympathy on Wall Street, where nearly everyone has a friend who has been laid off as a result of the downturn in the financial markets since the stock market crash three years ago. When th sentence was handed down shortly before noon, a loud commotion could be heard for about five seconds on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, brokers said - similar to the reaction when a stock price takes a quick dive. ``It was nothing like a wild panic. The damage is done already and we've all got to go on from here,'' said Steven Schaeffer, a floor broker with Lawrence Helfant. ``Hopefully he's the last of the yuppies to go.'' Frank Kettles, 31, a Wall Street telecommunications worker, learned of Milken's sentence while drinking with a friend at Houlihans bar in Manhattan's downtown financial district. ``Yeah!'' he shouted, raising his fist. ``Wall Street got a bad name because of people like him.'' Down the block, Kecia Montgomery, 25, a former Drexel worker who quit two years to become a nurse because the profession ``is about caring not taking,'' took time out from chatting with a hot-dog vendor to say that Milken's sentence inspires little sympathy with her. ``If you can't do the time, don't do the crime,'' said Montgomery. ``It's not fair that he did his dirty work and hurt a lot of people.'' But in greater Los Angeles, where Milken lives and used to work, many of his friends reacted with dismay and outrage. ``It's like they hit me over the head with a sledgehammer. What a waste of talent,'' said Richard Riordan, a prominent lawyer and philanthropist who has been an ally of Milken in many business and charitable activities.

DOC.HEAD: Midway, Pilots Reach Contract Accord
DOC.TEXT: Ailing Midway Airlines said Wednesday it had reached a tentative agreement with the Air Line Pilots Association on a three-year contract to replace a pact that expired in May. The Chicago-based airline did not provide details about the proposed contract, which is subject to ratification by the 681 Midway cockpit crew members represented by ALPA. Midway recently decided to sell its year-old hub at Philadelphia International Airport and cut its workforce by 10 percent, blaming high jet fuel costs. The company has posted losses in the last five quarters. Chairman David R. Hinson recently said the carrier plans to add new service from Chicago.

DOC.HEAD: National Semi Sells Washington Plant to Matsushita
DOC.TEXT: National Semiconductor Corp. announced Wednesday it would sell its Puyallup, Wash., chip plant to Matsushita Electronic Corp. The deal, expected to close early next year, calls for payment of about $86 million for two buildings and 92 acres where Matsushita plans to make DRAMS and MOS logic components. No technology will be transfered in the deal, National said in a statement. ``The sale of the Puyallup facility allows National to reduce the excess manufacturing capacity that results from the company's decision to exit the high-end SRAM business,'' said Charles E. Sporck, National Semiconductor president and chief executive officer. National, which reported a net loss of $165.5 million or $1.63 per share for its most recent quarter, ceased development of the very high-speed, high-density SRAMS as part of a restructuring. The losses included a restructuring charge of $143 million. The high-tech company announced in August that it would stop making computer chips at the Washington plant and was laying off 300 people, leaving about 550 workers at the facility.

DOC.HEAD: Nutrasweet Loses Bid To Trademark Blue Packets
DOC.TEXT: NutraSweet Co. officials were singing the blues Wednesday about a federal appeals court decision that the pastel blue color of the company's Equal brand sweetener packets is not a trademark. NutraSweet, based in north suburban Deerfield, went to court in February 1989 seeking to halt Stadt Corp. and Cumberland Packing Corp.'s use of blue packets for their low-calorie Sweet One brand sweetener. The U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois denied NutraSweet's motion for an injunction in the fall of 1989. NutraSweet, a division of Monsanto Co. of St. Louis, appealed the case to the Seventh U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, which upheld the lower court ruling in a decision issued earlier this month. NutraSweet spokesman Rich Nelson said the company is considering appealing the decision to the U.S. Supreme Court. ``We believe the use of color alone can be used as a tredemark, just as other courts have found,'' Nelson said Wednesday. NutraSweet's lawsuit contended that the blue packets in which it has packaged Equal since 1982 distinguish the aspartame sweetener from other sugar substitutes such as Sweet 'N Low, which comes in pink packets, and Sugar Twin, which is packaged in yellow. NutraSweet conceded the Sweet One's packets are not the same shade of blue as Equal's, but said the color is ``confusingly similar'' to Equal's. NutraSweet based its argument mainly on a 1985 federal appeals court ruling from another circuit in a case involving Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corp., maker of pink fiberglass insulation. In that case, the court established a limited rule that in certain situations a particular color could be registered as a trademark. In the NutraSweet decision, Senior District Judge John W. Reynolds wrote that the general rule prohibiting registration of color as a trademark ``should continue to be the law in this circuit,'' partly because changing the law would result in infringement actions ``that could soon degenerate into questions of shade confusion'' similar to the NutraSweet case. ``How different do the colors have to be?'' Reynolds wrote. ``Under NutraSweet's proposed test, the only way to answer that question is through litigation.'' Officials of Stadt and Cumberland could not be reached Wednesday for comment.
